Seventy patients with spontaneous and 21 with traumatic extracranial internal carotid artery dissections were studied clinically and angiographically with mean follow-ups of 64 (spontaneous group) and 40 months (traumatic group). Sixty percent of the patients in the spontaneous group and 71% in the traumatic group also had follow-up angiograms. In traumatic dissections aneurysms were common, significantly fewer aneurysms resolved or became smaller and fewer stenoses resolved or improved, whereas more stenoses progressed to occlusion. Traumatic dissections were more likely to leave the patients with neurological deficits. A significantly higher percentage of the patients with spontaneous dissections were asymptomatic at follow-up compared with the traumatic group. Although both spontaneous and traumatic dissections of extracranial internal carotid arteries mostly carry a good prognosis, the outcome may be somewhat less favorable for the traumatic group.

Partial laryngectomy after irradiation failure. Forty-three patients who had partial laryngectomies after radiotherapy were evaluated. Forty-two had failed irradiation for laryngeal carcinoma. Nine had supraglottic procedures, 3 endoscopic, and 31 vertical partial. Twelve (28%) required subsequent completion laryngectomy. Major complications included laryngeal stenosis in 1, incompetent laryngeal sphincters in 2, mucocutaneous fistulas in 3, and delayed deglutition in 3. Six patients had positive permanent section margins. In 5 of those, intraoperative frozen sections had been taken and were negative. Recurrent or persistent disease was eventually demonstrated in all patients with positive margins. The 2-year determinant disease-free survival rate for stage I and II disease was 85%. Three-year disease-free survival was 50% for stage III and IV disease. Partial laryngectomies, including supraglottic, can be done after irradiation failure with a high expectation of cure and acceptable morbidity. Immediate additional operation should be considered in patients with positive margins.

Magnetic resonance imaging of experimental rat brain tumors: histopathological evaluation. Using RG-C6 glioma-transplanted rats, we studied precontrast and postcontrast magnetic resonance imaging, extravasation of Evans blue, and histology. In all rats, tumor was enhanced with gadolinium-diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid (Gd-DTPA). The necrotic portion in the tumor, however, was not enhanced. Hemorrhage and hydrocephalus were clearly visualized on both the precontrast and postcontrast images. Blood-brain barrier-disrupted areas stained with Evans blue and areas enhanced with Gd-DTPA on magnetic resonance imaging were nearly consistent. It is suggested that the mechanism of brain tumor enhancement with Gd-DTPA on magnetic resonance imaging is simply related to the degree of alteration of the blood-brain barrier. The Gd-DTPA-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging, even with low magnetic field, is useful for the evaluation of size, shape, and location of experimental rat brain tumors.

Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome. A clinical case series of 21 patients. New Mexico Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome Study Group. We reviewed 21 cases of eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome to describe the range of clinical findings in these patients. Most patients were women (20 [95%]) and middle-aged (mean, 46 years) and had taken the food supplement L-tryptophan (95%). All cases involved eosinophilia (eosinophil count, greater than or equal to 2.0 x 10(9)/L) and incapacitating myalgias. Fourteen (88%) of the 16 patients tested had mild liver function abnormalities. Aldolase levels were abnormal in all patients tested. Muscle biopsies were done in five patients; four showed eosinophilic perimyositis, and one had interstitial inflammation. No physical finding was pathognomonic or universal, but muscle tenderness, tachycardia, and rash were the most common signs found during physical examinations. Seven patients were treated with prednisone, and six showed improvement in muscle pain and a decrease in eosinophilia. The cause of this disorder is still unknown.

Ichthyosis, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, impaired neutrophil chemotaxis, growth retardation, and metaphyseal dysplasia (Shwachman syndrome). Report of a case with extensive skin lesions (clinical, histological, and ultrastructural findings). The Shwachman syndrome comprises exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, growth retardation, and bone marrow hypoplasia resulting in neutropenia. Clinical, morphological, and ultrastructural studies, as well as hair analysis, were performed in a patient with Shwachman's syndrome and severe ichthyosis. Clinical findings were lamellar ichthyosiform desquamation on the extremities. The hair was scanty and short on the scalp, in the eyelashes, and in the eyebrows. The nails were hyperkeratotic. Morphologic findings were slight, regular acanthosis and severe diffuse hyperkeratosis with variable parakeratosis. The granular layer was thickened. The papillary dermis showed very slight perivascular lymphocyte infiltration. The most prominent ultrastructural finding was the presence of solitary or multiple droplets of varying size in the cytoplasm of the keratinocytes. Hair analysis revealed no abnormalities; the cystine concentration in hair specimens was normal.

mtDNA depletion with variable tissue expression: a novel genetic abnormality in mitochondrial diseases. We studied two related infants with a fatal mitochondrial disease, affecting muscle in one and liver in the other. Quantitative analysis revealed a severe depletion of mtDNA in affected tissues. This genetic abnormality was also observed in muscle of an unrelated infant with myopathy and in muscle and kidney of a fourth child with myopathy and nephropathy. Biochemistry, immunohistochemistry, and in situ hybridization showed that the depletion of mtDNA in muscle fibers was correlated with a respiratory chain defect and with lack of mitochondrially translated proteins. Although the differential tissue involvement in these infants suggests mtDNA heteroplasmy, sequence analysis of mtDNA replication origins did not reveal any abnormality that could account for the low copy number.

SPECT imaging of pediatric brain tumor with hexakis (methoxyisobutylisonitrile) technetium (I). Technetium-99m-Hexamibi [Hexakis (methoxyisobutylisonitrile) technetium (i)] was developed as a myocardial perfusion agent with biologic properties similar to those of thallium-201 (201TI). As 201TI has recently been observed to be of value for the diagnosis of brain tumors when used in conjunction with single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) imaging technology, the possibility that the biologic similarity of the two radiopharmaceuticals extended to their affinity for tumors was tested. A 5-yr-old female patient with a brain stem astrocytoma showed marked focal uptake of 99mTc-Hexamibi at the site of tumor recurrence as defined by biopsy and prior 201TI/SPECT study. Tumor-to-normal cortex radioactivity ratios for the 99mTc-Hexamibi/SPECT study were 132:1 and the spatial resolution of the 99mTc-Hexamibi images was high. This observation suggests that 99mTc-Hexamibi merits further study as a potential agent for SPECT imaging of human brain tumors.

Pulmonary acinar development in diaphragmatic hernia. Pulmonary acinar development was assessed in 17 autopsy cases of pulmonary hypoplasia associated with diaphragmatic hernia. Morphologic examination was conducted by light and electron microscopy, and morphometric study was achieved by radial alveolar count and biochemical quantitation of surfactant phospholipid. In most cases of unilateral diaphragmatic hernia, the ipsilateral lung was underdeveloped morphologically and biochemically compared with the contralateral lung. However, both ipsilateral and contralateral lungs were well developed in some cases of unilateral diaphragmatic hernia. Thus, acinar development of hypoplastic lung in diaphragmatic hernia is varied. The influence of other conditions, such as oligohydramnios, polyhydramnios, and other anomalies that may influence retention of lung fluid or fetal respiratory movement, should be considered to assess the acinar development of hypoplastic lung in diaphragmatic hernia.

Developmental dysmnesia in a poor reader. A 22-yr-old subject with moderate developmental dyslexia experienced poor memory from an early age. In spite of normal intelligence he had great difficulty in learning historical and geographical names, mathematical formulae, poems and songs, and verbal series such as the letters of the alphabet and the months of the year. His recognition of familiar faces was also faulty at times. A battery of memory tests confirmed a moderate deficit of verbal as well as visual memory, whereas spatial memory was preserved. Other cognitive functions were intact, except for a mild reading disability. No evidence of brain pathology was provided by his history, neurological examination and CT scanning.

Treatment of vaginal candidiasis: orally or vaginally? Vaginal candidiasis continues to be the most common cause of vaginal discharge. A large variety of topical drugs and a selection of orally active antifungals are currently available. The choice between the use of oral drugs or intravaginal agents will depend on the therapeutic results obtained with the different agents, side effects, pregnancy status, and patient preference. The results obtained in the Maria Hospital, Tilburg, The Netherlands, and a review of foreign data suggest the following: (1) For acute infection oral and topical agents produce equivalent results. (2) For chronic infections oral medication is preferred. (3) Oral therapy should not be given to pregnant patients or to patients not using reliable contraceptive measures. (4) Half the patients prefer oral medication; only 5% prefer intravaginal therapy, and the others had no clear preference.

Pseudocyst of the auricle: successful treatment with intracartilaginous trichloroacetic acid and button bolsters. Pseudocyst of the auricle is an asymptomatic, noninflammatory cystic swelling that typically involves the anthelix of the ear and results from an accumulation of fluid within an unlined intracartilaginous cavity. We report a patient with a recurrent pseudocyst of the auricle and describe a new surgical technique for treating this condition by applying 50% trichloroacetic acid to the intracartilaginous cavity and utilizing external button bolsters for compressive therapy. This therapeutic approach is simple to perform in the office, results in permanent resolution of the pseudocyst, preserves the normal architecture of the external ear, and provides excellent postoperative and long-term cosmetic results.

Immunohistochemical demonstration of pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor in normal and neoplastic colonic mucosa. Specimens of normal and neoplastic colonic mucosa from 52 patients were analysed by immunohistochemistry using a monospecific polyclonal antiserum against human pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor (PSTI). In normal colonic mucosa PSTI was found in the goblet cells in the basal parts of the crypts. In adenomas of tubular, villous, and tubulo-villous types PSTI was also found in the upper parts of the polyps, usually occurring in the regeneration zone. There was a more intense staining reaction in polyps with increased atypia. Carcinomas of different types and of various grades of differentiation and of in situ type did not contain PSTI. These findings indicate that PSTI could be a marker for adenomatous rather than carcinomatous epithelium in the colon. Furthermore, the absence of the inhibitor in malignant cells might facilitate tissue invasion by malignant cells because of deficient protease inhibition.

Enveloping the bladder with displacement of flap of the rectus abdominis muscle for the treatment of neurogenic bladder. Neurogenic bladder is a frequent occurrence. A new surgical technique has been designed and was used successfully in 18 patients with ideal results. The key point of the operation is to turn over a flap of rectus abdominis muscle to envelop the bladder. Contraction of the muscle flap and the abdominal muscles would enhance voiding ability. In the meantime, the bladder is displaced forward and the resultant change in the bladder-posterior urethral angle also favors voiding. Since the bladder is near the anterior abdominal wall manual compression during voiding is made easier. All of these advantages greatly facilitate voiding.

Percutaneous urinary diversion in patients with hormone-refractory prostate cancer. The efficacy of percutaneous urinary diversion was evaluated in patients with hormone-refractory prostate cancer. A total of 84 patients underwent the procedure between 2005 and 2010. The most common indication for urinary diversion was urinary obstruction. The procedure was successful in relieving urinary symptoms in 78% of patients. Complications included urinary tract infection, stent blockage, and ureteral stricture. Patients who received adjuvant radiotherapy had a significantly higher rate of complications. Mean survival time after the procedure was 14 months. Percutaneous urinary diversion provides effective relief of urinary symptoms in patients with hormone-refractory prostate cancer, however, it is associated with a risk of complications that should be carefully considered in the management of these patients.

Histologic evaluation of the larynx in sudden infant death syndrome. Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is a devastating condition that claims the lives of seemingly healthy infants. In an effort to better understand the pathogenesis of SIDS, we conducted a histologic evaluation of the larynx in SIDS cases. We found that a significant number of SIDS cases showed abnormalities in the larynx, including inflammation, edema, and epithelial cell necrosis. These findings suggest that the larynx may play a role in the pathophysiology of SIDS. Furthermore, we observed a correlation between the severity of laryngeal abnormalities and the age of the infant at the time of death, with younger infants exhibiting more pronounced changes. This information sheds light on the potential involvement of the larynx in SIDS and may contribute to future efforts in preventing this tragic syndrome.

Immunohistologic properties of benign and malignant mixed tumor of the lacrimal gland. Benign and malignant mixed tumors of the lacrimal gland are rare neoplasms that exhibit varied immunohistologic characteristics. In this study, we aim to evaluate the immunohistologic properties of these tumors to improve their diagnosis and management. We analyzed the expression of cytokeratins (CK), epithelial membrane antigen (EMA), Ki-67 proliferation antigen, and the presence of specific genetic mutations in a cohort of patients with lacrimal gland mixed tumors. Our results showed that CK7 and CK20 were differentially expressed in benign and malignant tumors, with CK7 showing higher expression in benign tumors and CK20 showing higher expression in malignant tumors. EMA was strongly expressed in both benign and malignant tumors. The Ki-67 proliferation antigen was significantly higher in malignant tumors compared to benign tumors, indicating increased cell proliferation. Additionally, specific genetic mutations, such as PLAG1 and CTNNB1, were found in a subset of malignant tumors, suggesting their potential role in tumor progression. In conclusion, our study reveals distinct immunohistologic properties of benign and malignant mixed tumors of the lacrimal gland, providing valuable insights for their accurate diagnosis and targeted therapy.

Collagen metabolism in gynecologic patients: changes in the concentration of the aminoterminal propeptide of type III procollagen in serum. Patients with gynecologic conditions often experience changes in collagen metabolism. This study aimed to investigate the concentration of the aminoterminal propeptide of type III procollagen (PIIINP) in serum as a marker of collagen metabolism in gynecologic patients. Serum samples were collected from 50 patients with gynecologic conditions and 50 healthy controls. The PIIINP levels were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). The results showed that the serum PIIINP levels were significantly higher in gynecologic patients compared to healthy controls (p < 0.001). Additionally, the PIIINP levels were significantly elevated in patients with advanced stage gynecologic cancer compared to those with early-stage disease (p < 0.05). These findings suggest that collagen metabolism is altered in gynecologic patients, particularly in those with advanced disease. Measurement of serum PIIINP levels may serve as a useful biomarker for monitoring collagen metabolism in gynecologic conditions.

Elevated soluble interleukin-2 receptor levels in patients with active multiple sclerosis. Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation and demyelination in the central nervous system. Dysregulation of cytokines has been implicated in the pathogenesis of MS. Interleukin-2 receptor (IL-2R) plays a crucial role in immune activation and has been linked to MS. In this study, we aimed to investigate the levels of soluble IL-2R (sIL-2R) in patients with active MS. We recruited 50 patients with active MS and 50 healthy controls. Serum levels of sIL-2R were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. Our results showed significantly elevated levels of sIL-2R in patients with active MS compared to healthy controls (p < 0.05). Furthermore, the levels of sIL-2R correlated positively with disease severity as assessed by the Kurtzke Expanded Disability Status Scale (r = 0.45, p < 0.01). These findings suggest that sIL-2R may serve as a potential biomarker for disease activity in MS and provide insights into its pathophysiology.

Further evaluation of radical surgery following radiotherapy for advanced parotid carcinoma. The effectiveness of radical surgery after radiotherapy for advanced parotid carcinoma was evaluated. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 58 patients who underwent radical surgery following radiotherapy for advanced parotid carcinoma. The patients were divided into two groups based on the interval between radiotherapy and surgery: group 1 with an interval of less than 6 months and group 2 with an interval of 6 months or more. The overall survival rate, disease-free survival rate, and complications were compared between the two groups. The results showed that group 1 had a significantly higher overall survival rate and disease-free survival rate compared to group 2. However, the complication rate was higher in group 1. Based on these findings, it is suggested that radical surgery performed within 6 months after radiotherapy can improve the overall survival and disease-free survival rates in patients with advanced parotid carcinoma, although it may increase the risk of complications. Further studies are needed to validate these results.

Does auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation reverse hypersplenism and portal hypertension? In this study, performed to assess the effect of auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation on portal hypertension and hypersplenism, eight patients with chronic liver disease who underwent the procedure and had functioning grafts for at least 6 months were analyzed. The aim of this study was to evaluate the impact of auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation on portal hypertension and hypersplenism in patients with chronic liver disease. Eight patients who underwent the procedure and had functional grafts for at least 6 months were included in the analysis. The results showed that auxiliary heterotopic liver transplantation successfully reversed hypersplenism and improved portal hypertension in these patients. This suggests that this transplantation technique may be an effective treatment option for patients with chronic liver disease who exhibit these complications. Further research is warranted to validate these findings and determine the long-term outcomes of this approach.

Interphase cytogenetic analysis in the diagnosis and study of neoplastic disorders. This article discusses the application of interphase cytogenetic analysis in the diagnosis and study of neoplastic disorders. Interphase cytogenetic analysis, specifically using techniques such as fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and comparative genomic hybridization (CGH), provides valuable information about the genetic abnormalities present in neoplastic cells. The method involves the analysis of genetic material in interphase, when chromatin is dispersed and not condensed into visible chromosomes. It allows for the detection of specific chromosomal rearrangements, gene amplifications, deletions, and other genomic alterations that are associated with various neoplastic disorders, including hematological malignancies and solid tumors. The article highlights the advantages of interphase cytogenetic analysis, such as its ability to analyze non-dividing cells, detect subtle genetic changes, and provide important diagnostic and prognostic information. The authors also discuss the potential limitations and challenges of the technique and its future role in personalized medicine and targeted therapies for neoplastic disorders.

Unusual haemostasis for an unusual tumour. This case report presents a unique case of a patient with an unusual tumour who presented with atypical haemostasis. The tumour, an angiomatosis-like fibrous hyperplasia (ALFH), is a rare vascular neoplasm that presents diagnostic challenges. The patient experienced chronic epistaxis, gastrointestinal bleeding, and haematuria, which required multiple interventions to manage. Laboratory investigations revealed a coagulation profile within normal limits, ruling out any primary haemostatic disorder. Histopathological examination of the tumour showed a proliferation of fibroblasts and malformed blood vessels, consistent with ALFH. Despite various therapeutic interventions, the patient continued to experience bleeding episodes. This case highlights the challenges in managing unusual tumours with atypical presentations and emphasizes the need for a multidisciplinary approach to ensure optimal patient care. Further research is warranted to understand the underlying mechanisms of haemostasis in ALFH and develop more effective treatment strategies.

Functional heart replacement with the spindle pump: first results. This study presents the initial outcomes of functional heart replacement using the spindle pump. The spindle pump is a novel device designed to provide circulatory support in end-stage heart failure patients. Six patients with severe cardiomyopathy underwent implantation of the spindle pump as a bridge-to-transplantation therapy. The surgical procedure was performed without any major complications. Postoperative clinical parameters demonstrated significant improvement in cardiac function, including increased cardiac output and reduced pulmonary artery pressures. Additionally, there was a notable reduction in the need for inotropic support and improvement in patients' overall quality of life. These preliminary results suggest that the spindle pump may be a promising option for functional heart replacement in selected patients. Further studies are warranted to evaluate long-term outcomes and patient selection criteria.

Memory-contingent saccades and the substantia nigra postulate for essential blepharospasm. Essential blepharospasm is characterized by involuntary eyelid closure due to abnormal muscle contractions. The etiology of this condition remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate the potential involvement of memory-contingent saccades and the substantia nigra in essential blepharospasm. A total of 30 patients with essential blepharospasm and 30 age-matched controls were enrolled in the study. Memory-contingent saccades were assessed using an eye-tracking paradigm, and substantia nigra hyperechogenicity was evaluated using transcranial sonography. The results showed a significant impairment in memory-contingent saccades in patients with essential blepharospasm compared to controls. Additionally, substantia nigra hyperechogenicity was more prevalent in patients with essential blepharospasm. These findings suggest that abnormal memory-contingent saccades and substantia nigra dysfunction may contribute to the pathogenesis of essential blepharospasm. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets for this debilitating condition.

Pressor systems in hypertension and congestive heart failure. This review examines the pressor systems involved in hypertension and congestive heart failure (CHF). Both conditions are characterized by increased sympathetic activity, renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) activation, and endothelin production. In hypertension, sympathetic activity is elevated, leading to increased peripheral vascular resistance and blood pressure. The RAAS is also stimulated, causing vasoconstriction and sodium retention. Endothelin, a potent vasoconstrictor, is upregulated in hypertensive patients. In CHF, there is sympathetic overactivation due to reduced cardiac output and baroreceptor dysfunction, leading to vasoconstriction and fluid retention. The RAAS is also activated in CHF, resulting in salt and water retention. Increased endothelin levels are observed in CHF patients, contributing to vasoconstriction. Understanding the pathophysiology of these pressor systems is crucial for developing targeted therapies to manage hypertension and CHF. Further research is needed to investigate potential therapeutic interventions that can modulate these systems to improve patient outcomes.

A dentist's dilemma: nonsurgical endodontic therapy or periapical surgery for teeth with apparent pulpal pathosis and an associated periapical radiolucent lesion. This study examines the dilemma faced by dentists in choosing between nonsurgical endodontic therapy and periapical surgery for teeth displaying pulpal pathosis and a periapical radiolucent lesion. Nonsurgical endodontic therapy is a conservative approach that aims to preserve the natural tooth through root canal treatment, eliminating the need for surgery. Periapical surgery, on the other hand, involves removing the periapical lesion and addressing any underlying issues directly. The decision to choose between these two treatment options can be challenging, as both have their advantages and drawbacks. Factors influencing this decision include the size and location of the lesion, the condition of the tooth structure, and the individual patient's preferences and expectations. A thorough examination and assessment of the tooth and surrounding tissues, along with careful consideration of these factors, is crucial in making an informed choice and achieving successful outcomes.

Inhibition of neutrophil migration by tumor necrosis factor. Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) is known to play a crucial role in inflammation and immune response. In this study, we investigated the effect of TNF on neutrophil migration, a key process in the immune system's response to infection and injury. Our results show that TNF significantly inhibits neutrophil migration in a dose-dependent manner. Furthermore, we found that this inhibitory effect is mediated through the downregulation of key chemokines and adhesion molecules involved in neutrophil recruitment. These findings provide valuable insights into the mechanisms by which TNF regulates neutrophil migration and suggest potential therapeutic targets for modulating inflammatory responses. Further studies are warranted to explore the clinical implications of these findings.

Right ventricular infarction: a clinical case study.  In this article we review the specific case of Mrs. This article presents a clinical case study of a patient with right ventricular infarction. Mrs. X, a 55-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, presented with chest pain and shortness of breath. ECG and echocardiography confirmed the diagnosis of right ventricular infarction. The patient was managed with reperfusion therapy and supportive care. The clinical course, complications, and outcomes of Mrs. X were discussed. Right ventricular infarction is a rare but serious complication of coronary artery disease and has a high mortality rate. Early recognition and prompt intervention are crucial in improving patient outcomes. Further studies are needed to explore optimal management strategies for this condition.

Apparent reduction in the size of one side of the face associated with a small retrosplenial haemorrhage. This case report describes a patient presenting with an apparent reduction in the size of one side of the face, which was found to be associated with a small retrosplenial haemorrhage. Retrosplenial haemorrhage is a rare condition characterized by bleeding in the retrosplenial region of the brain. The patient experienced facial asymmetry and mild neurological symptoms, such as headache and dizziness. Imaging studies revealed a small haemorrhage in the retrosplenial region, which resulted in facial muscle weakness and atrophy on one side of the face. Treatment consisted of supportive care and close monitoring. This report highlights the importance of considering retrosplenial haemorrhage as a potential cause of facial asymmetry.

Open-heart surgery in Jehovah's Witnesses.  During a 7-year period, 11 adult members of the religious sect Jehovah's Witnesses underwent cardiac surgery with extracorporeal circulation. Open-heart surgery in Jehovah's Witnesses is a complex and challenging scenario due to their refusal of blood transfusions. This study retrospectively analyzes the outcomes of 11 adult Jehovah's Witnesses who underwent cardiac surgery with extracorporeal circulation over a 7-year period. The patients' demographic characteristics, types of cardiac procedures performed, intraoperative management strategies, postoperative outcomes, and follow-up data are presented. Despite the absence of blood transfusions, none of the patients experienced perioperative mortality. However, longer cardiopulmonary bypass times and higher rates of reoperation were observed compared to non-Jehovah's Witness patients. Careful preoperative planning, meticulous surgical techniques, and close collaboration between the surgical and anesthesia teams are crucial in successfully managing this unique patient population.

The use of gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging to determine lesion site in traumatic facial paralysis. Traumatic facial paralysis can result in significant facial dysfunction and impair quality of life. Determining the underlying lesion site is crucial for appropriate management. This study aimed to investigate the use of gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in identifying the lesion site in traumatic facial paralysis. A total of 30 patients with traumatic facial paralysis underwent MRI with gadolinium enhancement. The location of the lesion was successfully determined in 28 out of 30 patients (93.3%) using this imaging technique. The most common site of the lesion was the facial nerve canal (71.4%), followed by the geniculate ganglion (14.3%) and the stylomastoid foramen (14.3%). Furthermore, gadolinium-enhanced MRI detected additional lesions in 25% of the patients, which were not identified on conventional MRI. This study highlights the efficacy of gadolinium-enhanced MRI in accurately localizing the lesion site in traumatic facial paralysis, providing valuable information for appropriate treatment planning and improving patient outcomes.

Laser placement in noncontact Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation.  We treated 40 eyes of 40 patients by using noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation to determine whether treatment 1. 5 or 3. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation as a treatment for glaucoma. Forty patients with glaucoma underwent this procedure in 40 eyes. The study compared the effects of two different treatment durations, 1.5 or 3 seconds. The primary outcome measures included intraocular pressure reduction and visual acuity changes. Secondary outcomes included the need for additional glaucoma medications and complications. Results showed that both treatment durations effectively reduced intraocular pressure, with no significant difference between the two groups. Visual acuity remained stable throughout the follow-up period. There were no major complications associated with the procedure. Based on these findings, noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation appears to be a safe and effective option for glaucoma treatment. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these results.

Relationship of ischemic heart disease to sudden death. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between ischemic heart disease (IHD) and sudden death. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients who died suddenly and underwent postmortem examination. The study included 100 cases of sudden death, with 60 cases showing evidence of IHD on autopsy. The majority of patients with IHD were males above the age of 50. The most common cause of death in the IHD group was acute myocardial infarction. Other significant findings included coronary artery stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy. Furthermore, the presence of multiple risk factors such as hypertension and smoking was observed in the majority of IHD cases. In conclusion, this study highlights the strong association between IHD and sudden death, emphasizing the importance of primary prevention strategies for reducing the risk of sudden cardiac events.

Spontaneous renal rupture during pregnancy. Spontaneous renal rupture during pregnancy is a rare and life-threatening condition that requires prompt recognition and intervention. We present a case of a 32-year-old woman who presented at 28 weeks gestation with acute abdominal pain and hematuria. Imaging studies revealed a ruptured right kidney with retroperitoneal hematoma. Emergency laparotomy with nephrectomy was performed due to the severity of the rupture. Pathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of spontaneous renal rupture. Although rare, spontaneous renal rupture during pregnancy should be considered in the differential diagnosis of acute abdominal pain and hematuria. Prompt surgical intervention is crucial to prevent maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality. Close monitoring and awareness of this rare complication are essential for timely intervention and optimal outcomes.

Transient cyst-like cortical defects following fractures in children. Transient cyst-like cortical defects are a rare radiographic finding following fractures in children. We retrospectively analyzed 32 cases of these defects in pediatric patients presenting with fractures. The majority of fractures occurred in the long bones, with the tibia being the most commonly affected site. Radiographs and CT scans revealed well-defined, round or oval-shaped cystic lesions in the cortical bone adjacent to the fracture site. Follow-up imaging showed spontaneous resolution of the defects within 3 to 12 months. No clinical symptoms or complications were associated with these cyst-like defects. We propose that these findings represent a self-limited reactive process of the cortical bone following fractures in children. Awareness of this entity is important to avoid unnecessary intervention or misdiagnosis.

Cervicography for evaluating the "atypical" Papanicolaou smear. Cervicography is a useful tool for evaluating atypical Papanicolaou (Pap) smears. This study aimed to assess the effectiveness of cervicography in diagnosing cervical abnormalities in patients with atypical Pap smears. A total of 100 patients with atypical Pap smears were included in the study. Cervicography was performed on all patients and the results were compared with colposcopy findings. The sensitivity and specificity of cervicography in detecting high-grade cervical abnormalities were calculated. The results showed that cervicography had a sensitivity of 90% and a specificity of 84% in detecting high-grade abnormalities. The positive predictive value and negative predictive value were 79% and 93% respectively. These findings indicate that cervicography is an effective tool for evaluating atypical Pap smears and may aid in the diagnosis of cervical abnormalities. Further studies are needed to validate these results and determine the role of cervicography in routine cervical cancer screening.

Comparison of characteristics of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma associated with head and neck cancer and those with gastric cancer.  In ongoing reviews of 339 patients with surgically treated primary squamous cell carcinoma, there were 19 (5. This study aimed to compare the characteristics of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) associated with head and neck cancer (HNC) and those with gastric cancer (GC). A total of 339 patients with surgically treated primary squamous cell carcinoma were included in the analysis. Of these, 19 patients (5.6%) had concurrent HNC and 17 patients (5.0%) had concurrent GC. The ESCC-HNC group had a higher proportion of male patients and a higher rate of alcohol consumption compared to the ESCC-GC group. Tumor location and stage were similar between the two groups. The ESCC-HNC group had a higher prevalence of lymph node metastasis compared to the ESCC-GC group. These findings suggest that ESCC associated with HNC and GC may have distinct characteristics, and further investigations are needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and develop tailored treatment strategies for these patients.

Hypocalcemia and hypercalcitoninemia in critically ill children.  To study Ca metabolism in critically ill children, we measured ionized Ca (Ca2+), parathyroid hormone (PTH), calcitonin, 25 hydroxycholecalciferol (25[OH] D3), 1-25 dihydroxycholecalciferol (1-25[OH]2D3, and gastrin levels in critically ill children and in healthy controls. Hypocalcemia and hypercalcitoninemia are common in critically ill children but the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. In this study, we measured several markers of calcium metabolism including ionized calcium, parathyroid hormone, calcitonin, 25 hydroxycholecalciferol, 1-25 dihydroxycholecalciferol, and gastrin levels in both critically ill children and healthy controls. Our results show that critically ill children have significantly lower ionized calcium and 25 hydroxycholecalciferol levels compared to healthy controls. Additionally, they have significantly higher calcitonin levels. However, PTH, 1-25 dihydroxycholecalciferol, and gastrin levels showed no significant differences between the two groups. These findings suggest that abnormal calcium metabolism, particularly decreased 25 hydroxycholecalciferol and increased calcitonin levels, may contribute to hypocalcemia and hypercalcitoninemia in critically ill children.

Tissue expansion in the treatment of pressure ulcers. This study presents the use of tissue expansion in the treatment of pressure ulcers. A total of 20 patients with stage III and IV pressure ulcers were included in the study. Tissue expanders were placed adjacent to the ulcers and gradually filled with saline to promote the growth of healthy tissue. The expansion process was carried out over a period of 4 to 6 weeks, with regular monitoring of the patients' progress. After expansion, the excess expanded tissue was used to cover the ulcer defect. The results showed that tissue expansion was successful in all patients, with complete wound closure achieved in 16 patients. The remaining 4 patients showed significant improvement in wound size and healing. Complications such as infection and necrosis were minimal, indicating the safety and effectiveness of this technique. Tissue expansion proves to be a valuable option in the treatment of pressure ulcers, offering improved outcomes and quality of life for affected individuals. Further research is warranted to evaluate its long-term effects.

Ganglioglioma: a clinical study with long-term follow-up. Gangliogliomas are rare, low-grade brain tumors consisting of both neuronal and glial components. This clinical study aimed to investigate the clinical characteristics and long-term outcomes of patients with ganglioglioma. A total of 42 patients diagnosed with ganglioglioma were included in the study and followed up for a median duration of 8.5 years. The median age at diagnosis was 24 years, with a slight male predominance. Seizures were the most common presenting symptom, occurring in 83% of patients. Surgical resection was the primary treatment modality, with adjuvant therapy used in selected cases. The overall survival rate at 10 years was 88%, and the progression-free survival rate was 81%. The study provides valuable insights into the clinical course and prognosis of gangliogliomas, highlighting the importance of long-term follow-up for optimal management and patient outcomes.

Novel antigens characteristic of neuroendocrine malignancies. Neuroendocrine malignancies are a group of tumors arising from cells of the neuroendocrine system, and their diagnosis and treatment pose significant challenges. This study aimed to identify novel antigens that are characteristic of neuroendocrine malignancies using a proteomics approach. Tumor samples from patients with neuroendocrine malignancies were analyzed, and several potential candidate antigens were identified. Subsequent validation experiments using immunohistochemistry confirmed the expression of these antigens in neuroendocrine tumor tissues. Furthermore, the specificity of these antigens for neuroendocrine malignancies was assessed by analyzing samples from patients with other types of malignancies as well as normal tissues. The results demonstrated a significant association between the expression of these antigens and neuroendocrine malignancies, with minimal expression in other tumor types or normal tissues. These findings suggest that these novel antigens may serve as potential biomarkers for the diagnosis and targeted therapy of neuroendocrine malignancies. Further studies are warranted to explore the functional significance of these antigens and their potential as therapeutic targets.

A cellist with arm pain: thermal asymmetry in scalenus anticus syndrome.  We report on a cellist with pain and coldness of the upper extremity. We present the case of a cellist who presented with persistent pain and cold sensation in the upper extremity. After thorough evaluation, a diagnosis of scalenus anticus syndrome was made. Further examination revealed thermal asymmetry in the affected arm, with decreased temperature compared to the contralateral side. Scalenus anticus syndrome is a rare condition caused by compression of the brachial plexus and subclavian artery by the scalenus anticus muscle. Symptoms typically include pain, numbness, and weakness in the upper extremity. However, thermal asymmetry has not been commonly reported in this syndrome. This case highlights the importance of considering scalenus anticus syndrome in musicians presenting with upper extremity symptoms and the potential role of thermal imaging in its diagnosis. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and optimize management strategies for this condition.

The progression of mild idiopathic dementia in a community population. The aim of this study was to investigate the progression of mild idiopathic dementia in a community population. A total of 100 patients with mild idiopathic dementia were followed for an average of 5 years. The progression of dementia was assessed using standardized cognitive tests, functional assessment scales, and behavioral assessments. Over the course of the study, there was a gradual decline in cognitive function, as evidenced by a decline in scores on cognitive tests. Functional abilities also showed a decline, with patients experiencing difficulties in activities of daily living. Behavioral symptoms, such as agitation and wandering, increased over time. The rate of progression varied among individuals, with some patients showing a more rapid decline than others. These findings highlight the progressive nature of mild idiopathic dementia and emphasize the need for ongoing monitoring and support for patients and their caregivers.

Renal disease in noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. Renal disease is a common complication of noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM). This study aimed to investigate the prevalence and characteristics of renal disease in NIDDM patients. A total of 100 NIDDM patients were included in this prospective study. Renal disease was defined as the presence of albuminuria or a reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Among the participants, 35% had renal disease, with albuminuria being the most common manifestation (24%). The remaining patients had a reduced GFR. There was a significant association between the duration of diabetes and the prevalence of renal disease. Other factors such as age, gender, and glycemic control were not found to be significantly associated with renal disease. These findings highlight the high prevalence of renal disease in NIDDM patients and emphasize the need for early detection and management to prevent further renal deterioration.

Cellular internalization, transport, and esterification of iodine-125-NP59 by MA-10 Leydig tumor cells.  The present studies were directed toward understanding the cellular processing of the cholesterol analogue, NP59. The cellular processing of NP59, a cholesterol analogue, was investigated in MA-10 Leydig tumor cells. The study aimed to understand cellular internalization, transport, and esterification of iodine-125-NP59. The results showed that NP59 was rapidly internalized by the cells, reaching maximum uptake within 15 minutes. The internalized NP59 was then transported to the Golgi apparatus, where it underwent esterification. The esterified NP59 was found to be localized in lipid droplets within the cells. Inhibition studies using various inhibitors of cellular processes demonstrated that NP59 internalization and esterification were dependent on energy-dependent processes and protein synthesis. Overall, these findings provide insights into the cellular processing of NP59 in Leydig tumor cells, which may have implications for understanding cholesterol metabolism and its role in Leydig cell function.

Thoracic spinal fractures and aortic rupture: a significant and fatal association.  We analyzed the frequency of occurrence of traumatic aortic rupture (TAR) in patients with and without thoracic spinal fractures. Thoracic spinal fractures and traumatic aortic rupture (TAR) are often associated and can result in fatal outcomes. This study aimed to analyze the frequency of TAR occurrence in patients with and without thoracic spinal fractures. Medical records of trauma patients were reviewed, and patients with both thoracic spinal fractures and TAR were included. The control group consisted of patients with thoracic spinal fractures but without TAR. The study found that TAR occurred significantly more frequently in patients with thoracic spinal fractures compared to those without fractures. The findings highlight the potential danger and lethality of this association. Timely recognition and appropriate management of thoracic spinal fractures is crucial to prevent or minimize the risk of TAR and its devastating consequences. Further research is needed to identify effective strategies for the early detection and intervention of TAR in patients with thoracic spinal fractures.

Use of gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging in the diagnosis and management of posterior fossa hemangioblastomas. The aim of this study was to evaluate the role of gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in the diagnosis and management of posterior fossa hemangioblastomas. A total of 48 patients with suspected posterior fossa hemangioblastomas underwent gadolinium-enhanced MRI. The presence of enhancing lesions on MRI was compared to the histopathological diagnosis. Of the 48 patients, 42 were confirmed to have posterior fossa hemangioblastomas based on histopathology. Gadolinium-enhanced MRI showed enhancing lesions in all 42 confirmed cases, resulting in a sensitivity of 100%. No enhancing lesions were seen in the six cases without histopathological confirmation, resulting in a specificity of 100%. Furthermore, gadolinium-enhanced MRI provided valuable information on the tumor size and location for surgical planning. In conclusion, gadolinium-enhanced MRI is a highly sensitive and specific imaging modality for the diagnosis and management of posterior fossa hemangioblastomas.

Prognostic factors for survival of patients with advanced urothelial tumors treated with methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin chemotherapy. The use of methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin (MVAC) chemotherapy has been established as a standard treatment for patients with advanced urothelial tumors. However, there is limited data on prognostic factors that may influence patient survival. In this retrospective study, we aimed to identify patient characteristics that may impact survival outcomes in patients receiving MVAC chemotherapy for advanced urothelial tumors. A total of 150 patients were included in the analysis. Multivariate analysis revealed that Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status, presence of visceral metastases, and hemoglobin levels were significant prognostic factors for overall survival. Furthermore, patients with a complete response to MVAC chemotherapy had a significantly longer survival compared to those with a partial response or progressive disease. These findings highlight the importance of patient selection and response to treatment in the management of advanced urothelial tumors treated with MVAC chemotherapy.

Brain protection: physiological and pharmacological considerations. This article discusses the importance of brain protection and the various physiological and pharmacological considerations involved in achieving this goal. The brain is a vital organ that is highly susceptible to damage and requires special attention in terms of protection. Physiological considerations include maintaining proper blood flow, oxygenation, and nutrition to the brain. Pharmacological considerations involve the use of medications to prevent or minimize brain injury, such as neuroprotective agents and drugs that target specific mechanisms of injury. The article also emphasizes the need for further research and development in this field to improve brain protection strategies and outcomes. Overall, understanding and implementing effective brain protection measures are essential in preventing neurological disorders and improving patient outcomes.

Metastatic tumors of the umbilicus: a review 1830-1989. We present a review of metastatic tumors of the umbilicus, spanning the years 1830 to 1989. A total of 122 cases were identified, with primary tumors originating from various sites including the gastrointestinal tract, breast, genitourinary system, and hematological malignancies. The most common primary tumor site was the gastrointestinal tract, followed by the ovaries and uterus. The majority of cases presented with a visible umbilical mass, often accompanied by pain and local inflammation. Metastatic tumors of the umbilicus are rare but can serve as an important clinical sign, indicating advanced disease and presenting diagnostic challenges. A thorough understanding of the underlying primary tumor is crucial for appropriate management and prognosis.

The pharmacology of aspirin, heparin, coumarin, and thrombolytic agents. This review article discusses the pharmacology of commonly used antithrombotic agents, including aspirin, heparin, coumarin, and thrombolytic agents. Aspirin, a widely used antiplatelet medication, inhibits cyclooxygenase enzyme and reduces platelet aggregation. Heparin, a parenteral anticoagulant, activates antithrombin III and inhibits thrombin and factor Xa, resulting in a prevention of clot formation. Coumarin derivatives, such as warfarin, act as vitamin K antagonists, inhibiting the synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X. Thrombolytic agents, including tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) and streptokinase, lyse existing blood clots by activating the fibrinolytic system. While these agents are effective in preventing or treating thrombotic events, they also carry a risk of bleeding. Understanding their pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic properties is crucial to optimize their use and minimize adverse effects. This article provides an overview of the mechanisms of action, indications, contraindications, dosing, and monitoring of these antithrombotic agents, aiding clinicians in making informed decisions for their patients.

Cheilitis granulomatosa: report of six cases and review of the literature. Cheilitis granulomatosa is a rare inflammatory condition affecting the lips. We present six cases of cheilitis granulomatosa and review the relevant literature. The mean age of our patients was 33.5 years, with a slight female predominance. All patients had persistent swelling and fissuring of the lips. Histopathological examination showed non-caseating granulomas in all cases. Four patients had associated systemic diseases, including Crohn's disease, sarcoidosis, and multiple sclerosis. Treatment with corticosteroids, immunomodulatory agents, and surgical interventions led to improvement in symptoms for most patients. Cheilitis granulomatosa is a chronic and challenging condition, often associated with systemic diseases. Early diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial in achieving optimal outcomes.

Steroids induce acetylcholine receptors on cultured human muscle: implications for myasthenia gravis. The effects of steroids on the induction of acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) on cultured human muscle cells were investigated in this study, with implications for myasthenia gravis (MG). Primary cultures of human skeletal muscle cells were exposed to various concentrations of dexamethasone or prednisolone for different durations. The expression of AChRs was then assessed using immunocytochemistry and electrophysiological techniques. Results showed that both steroids significantly increased AChR expression on cultured human muscle cells. The effect was dose-dependent and persisted even after steroid withdrawal. Furthermore, the induction of AChR expression was similar in both dexamethasone and prednisolone-treated cells. These findings suggest a potential mechanism of action for steroids in the treatment of MG, a neuromuscular autoimmune disorder characterized by reduced AChR levels. The induction of AChR expression by steroids may help restore neuromuscular transmission and improve muscle strength in patients with MG. Further studies are needed to explore the clinical implications of these findings.

Trapped-lung syndrome after cardiac surgery: a potentially preventable complication of pleural injury. Trapped-lung syndrome (TLS) is a rare complication following cardiac surgery that is associated with pleural injury. This study aims to investigate the incidence, clinical features, and potential preventive measures of TLS in patients undergoing cardiac surgery. A retrospective analysis of 320 cardiac surgery patients was conducted, identifying 10 cases (3.1%) of TLS. All patients presented with dyspnea, chest pain, and decreased breath sounds on physical examination. Diagnostic imaging showed signs of pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Surgical interventions, such as drainage or decortication, were required in 80% of cases. Factors associated with TLS included longer ventilation time, higher inotropic support, and emergency surgery. Preventive measures, such as gentle and meticulous handling of the lungs during surgery and early recognition of pleural injury, can potentially reduce the incidence of TLS. It is essential for clinicians to be aware of this preventable complication and take appropriate measures to minimize its occurrence.

Preoperative selection for curable renovascular hypertension. Curable renovascular hypertension (RVH) is primarily caused by renal artery stenosis (RAS). Accurate preoperative selection of patients with RVH who will benefit from revascularization is crucial. This review aims to summarize the current evidence on preoperative selection criteria for curable RVH. Various imaging modalities have been used to diagnose RAS, including renal doppler ultrasound, computed tomography angiography (CTA), magnetic resonance angiography (MRA), and renal scintigraphy. Additionally, clinical factors such as the presence of severe hypertension, uncontrolled blood pressure, bilateral or solitary kidney, resistant hypertension, and impaired renal function have been considered in selecting candidates for revascularization. Despite the advancements in imaging techniques and clinical criteria, no single modality or criteria has shown optimal diagnostic accuracy. Therefore, a comprehensive approach involving a combination of clinical and imaging assessments is recommended for the preoperative selection of patients with curable RVH.

Myeloproliferative disorders. Myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs) are a group of hematological malignancies characterized by abnormal proliferation of blood cells in the bone marrow. Mutations in genes such as JAK2, CALR, and MPL have been identified as drivers of MPDs; however, the exact mechanisms and causative factors are still not fully understood. This study aimed to investigate the role of oxidative stress in MPDs by measuring plasma levels of malondialdehyde (MDA), an end product of lipid peroxidation, and total antioxidant capacity (TAC) in patients with MPDs compared to healthy controls.

The results showed significantly higher plasma MDA levels and lower TAC in MPD patients compared to controls, indicating increased oxidative stress. Furthermore, the severity of the disease, as assessed by markers of bone marrow function and spleen size, correlated positively with MDA levels and negatively with TAC. These findings suggest that oxidative stress plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of MPDs and may contribute to disease progression.

In conclusion, this study provides evidence of increased oxidative stress in MPDs, highlighting its potential involvement in the pathogenesis and progression of these disorders. Targeting oxidative stress pathways may offer novel therapeutic strategies for the treatment of MPDs.

Congenital angiotropic lymphoma (intravascular lymphomatosis) of the T-cell type. Congenital angiotropic lymphoma, also known as intravascular lymphomatosis, is a rare and aggressive form of lymphoma primarily involving small blood vessels. We present a case of congenital angiotropic lymphoma of the T-cell type. This case involves a 25-year-old female patient who presented with fever, weight loss, and multiple skin lesions. Biopsy of the skin lesions confirmed the diagnosis of intravascular lymphomatosis, and subsequent immunophenotyping revealed a T-cell subtype. The patient was treated with a combination of chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Despite early intervention, the patient showed only a partial response to treatment and succumbed to the disease. This case highlights the aggressive nature of congenital angiotropic lymphoma and the importance of early diagnosis and multidisciplinary management. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal treatment strategies for this rare and challenging malignancy.

Lack of change in neurochemical markers during the postepileptic phase of intrahippocampal tetanus toxin syndrome in rats. Intrahippocampal tetanus toxin (Ttx) administration in rats induces a postepileptic phase characterized by behavioral changes and neurochemical alterations. This study aimed to investigate the changes in neurochemical markers during the postepileptic phase of Ttx syndrome. Thirty-two rats were divided into Ttx and control groups, and Ttx was injected into the right hippocampus. Behavioral assessments were conducted for 8 weeks post-injection. Neurochemical markers, including glutamate, gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), dopamine, and serotonin, were measured in the hippocampus and cortex using high-performance liquid chromatography. Compared to controls, Ttx-treated rats exhibited increased anxiety-like behavior and decreased locomotor activity during the postepileptic phase. However, there were no significant changes in the levels of glutamate, GABA, dopamine, or serotonin in either brain region. These findings suggest that while Ttx administration induces behavioral changes associated with the postepileptic phase in rats, there are no significant alterations in the levels of key neurochemical markers. Further investigations are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of the postepileptic phase in Ttx syndrome.

Two urogenital sinus syndromes.  Interstitial cystitis and focal vulvitis. This study examines two urogenital sinus syndromes: interstitial cystitis and focal vulvitis. Interstitial cystitis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the bladder, while focal vulvitis involves inflammation of the vulva. Both syndromes can cause significant discomfort and pain in affected individuals. The study aims to compare the clinical features, risk factors, and treatment options for these conditions. Preliminary findings suggest that interstitial cystitis and focal vulvitis may share common underlying mechanisms and could benefit from similar therapeutic approaches. Further research is needed to better understand these conditions and improve patient outcomes.

Complications in percutaneous transluminal angioplasty: relationships with patient age.  Five hundred consecutive attempted lower limb angioplasties for ischaemic disease (370 patients, mean age 65. The study aimed to determine the relationship between complications in percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) and patient age. Five hundred cases of lower limb angioplasties were examined in 370 patients with ischaemic disease, who had a mean age of 65.3 years. The overall complication rate was 9.2%. The most common complications were dissection (3.8%), thrombosis (2.6%), and perforation (1.8%). Patients aged 65 years or older had a significantly higher rate of complications compared to younger patients (11.3% vs. 6.5%, p<0.05). Age was found to be an independent predictor of complications in PTA after adjusting for other confounding factors. The study provides evidence that older patients undergoing lower limb angioplasty for ischaemic disease are at a higher risk of complications, highlighting the importance of careful consideration and evaluation in this patient population.

Hepatic arterial embolization in cases of extensive celiac arterial stenosis. Hepatic arterial embolization (HAE) is a well-established treatment for hepatic malignancies. However, there is limited evidence on the use of HAE in cases of extensive celiac arterial stenosis (CAS). This case series presents four patients with extensive CAS who underwent HAE for management of liver tumors. All patients had previously undergone unsuccessful attempts at revascularization. HAE was performed using polyvinyl alcohol particles and/or microspheres. The technical success rate was 100%, with complete occlusion of the CAS achieved in all cases. Clinical follow-up at a median of 12 months showed improvement in liver function and tumor response in all patients. HAE appears to be a safe and effective treatment option for patients with extensive CAS, providing a viable alternative when revascularization is not feasible or unsuccessful.

Gallbladder carcinoma producing human chorionic gonadotropin. Gallbladder carcinoma is a rare malignancy and its association with human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) production is even more uncommon. We present a case of a 59-year-old man who presented with symptoms of right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and weight loss. Imaging studies revealed a mass in the gallbladder with liver involvement. Laboratory investigations showed markedly elevated levels of hCG. A diagnosis of gallbladder carcinoma producing hCG was made based on histopathological examination. The patient underwent surgical resection followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. Despite treatment, the patient's prognosis remained poor, and he succumbed to the disease within a year of diagnosis. This case serves as a reminder of the rare association between gallbladder carcinoma and hCG production, highlighting the need for appropriate diagnostic evaluation and management in such cases.

Unusual haemostasis for an unusual tumour. Unusual haemostasis, characterized by a bleeding tendency, is often observed in patients with unusual tumors. These tumors, also known as rare neoplasms, present challenges in diagnosis, management, and treatment due to their rarity and limited understanding of their pathophysiology. The underlying mechanisms behind the abnormal bleeding in these tumors remain unidentified, and further investigation is required to elucidate the factors contributing to this phenomenon. Additionally, the management of hemostatic disturbances in these patients is complex, necessitating a multidisciplinary approach involving hematologists, oncologists, and surgeons. This abstract highlights the need for increased awareness and research regarding unusual neoplasms and their associated haemostatic complications to optimize patient care and outcomes.

Unilateral hydrocephalus in adults. Unilateral hydrocephalus is a rare condition in adults, characterized by the accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the ventricles of one hemisphere of the brain. This condition can lead to various neurological symptoms, including headache, cognitive impairment, and motor deficits. The etiology of unilateral hydrocephalus in adults is often related to previous brain trauma, infections, or tumors. Diagnosis is typically made through neuroimaging, such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), which shows ventricular enlargement on one side of the brain. Treatment options include surgical interventions, such as shunt placement or endoscopic third ventriculostomy, to restore the normal flow and drainage of CSF. Prognosis varies depending on the underlying cause and the timeliness of intervention.

Immunoscintigraphy of ovarian cancer with indium-111-labeled OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 monoclonal antibody.  The safety and diagnostic accuracy of immunoscintigraphy with the indium-111-labeled monoclonal antibody OV-TL 3 F(ab')2(111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2) for diagnosis and follow-up of ovarian cancer was prospectively studied in 31 patients. In this prospective study, the safety and diagnostic accuracy of immunoscintigraphy with the indium-111-labeled monoclonal antibody OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 (111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2) for ovarian cancer diagnosis and follow-up was evaluated in 31 patients. The results showed that immunoscintigraphy with 111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 was well-tolerated and there were no significant adverse events reported. The diagnostic accuracy of the technique was assessed by comparing the immunoscintigraphy results with histopathological findings. The sensitivity and specificity of the technique were found to be 87.5% and 92.3%, respectively. Furthermore, immunoscintigraphy was effective in detecting recurrent disease in patients undergoing follow-up. These findings suggest that immunoscintigraphy with 111In-OV-TL 3 F(ab')2 is a safe and accurate diagnostic tool for ovarian cancer, as well as for monitoring disease progression.

Hemodynamic determinants of vascular changes in hypertension and atherosclerosis.  Several new concepts are reviewed concerning structural and functional changes in atherosclerotic and hypertensive blood vessels. This review focuses on the hemodynamic determinants of vascular changes in hypertension and atherosclerosis. It examines several new concepts related to the structural and functional alterations observed in atherosclerotic and hypertensive blood vessels. In hypertension, a decrease in endothelium-dependent vasodilation and an increase in endothelium-derived contracting factors contribute to impaired vascular function. Additionally, increased shear stress and altered wall tension affect vascular remodeling and the development of atherosclerotic plaques. In atherosclerosis, abnormal endothelial function, increased oxidative stress, and inflammation play crucial roles in the initiation and progression of the disease. Understanding the hemodynamic factors underlying these vascular changes is essential for the development of novel therapeutic strategies targeting hypertension and atherosclerosis. Further research is needed to fully elucidate the complex interaction between hemodynamics and vascular alterations in these conditions.

Absent or minimal cerebrospinal fluid abnormalities in Haemophilus influenzae meningitis. The purpose of this study was to investigate the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings in patients with Haemophilus influenzae meningitis. A total of 50 patients were included in the study, and CSF samples were collected from all of them. Contrary to previous reports, our findings revealed that the majority of patients (96%) had either absent or minimal CSF abnormalities. Only 2 patients (4%) showed evidence of increased CSF protein levels, and none had pleocytosis. This finding challenges the traditional belief that Haemophilus influenzae meningitis is associated with significant CSF abnormalities. It suggests that CSF analysis may not be a reliable method for diagnosing this type of meningitis. Further research is needed to better understand the pathophysiology of Haemophilus influenzae meningitis and to identify more accurate diagnostic methods. This knowledge will be crucial in improving the management and outcomes of patients with this condition.

Ventricular arrhythmias in ischemic heart disease. Ventricular arrhythmias are a common and potentially life-threatening complication of ischemic heart disease. This study aimed to characterize the incidence and clinical features of ventricular arrhythmias in patients with ischemic heart disease. A total of 100 patients with confirmed ischemic heart disease and documented ventricular arrhythmias were included in the study. The majority of patients were males (65%) and had a history of myocardial infarction (80%). Ventricular arrhythmias were primarily polymorphic (71%) and frequently associated with angina (68%) and heart failure symptoms (56%). The incidence of ventricular arrhythmias was highest during the first week after myocardial infarction and declined over time. Patients with ventricular arrhythmias had a higher incidence of adverse cardiac events, including sudden cardiac death and recurrent myocardial infarction. The findings of this study highlight the importance of aggressive management strategies, including early revascularization and optimal medical therapy, in patients with ischemic heart disease to prevent ventricular arrhythmias and improve clinical outcomes.

Internal fixation of femoral neck fractures.  Two methods compared. This study compared two methods of internal fixation for femoral neck fractures. A total of [number] patients were included in the study and divided into two groups, each treated with a different fixation method. Clinical and radiographic outcomes were evaluated. The first method [details of the method] showed [specific findings and results], while the second method [details of the method] demonstrated [specific findings and results]. The authors discuss the advantages and disadvantages of each method and provide recommendations for the best approach to internal fixation of femoral neck fractures based on the study findings. Further research and long-term follow-up are needed to validate these results and determine the optimal treatment for this type of fracture.

Narrow QRS ventricular tachycardia.  OBJECTIVE: To determine the frequency and clinical characteristics of narrow QRS ventricular tachycardia (QRS duration less than or equal to 0. 11 seconds). Narrow QRS ventricular tachycardia (VT) is a rare form of VT with a QRS duration of equal to or less than 0.11 seconds. This study aims to determine the frequency and clinical characteristics of this specific type of VT. A retrospective analysis of medical records was conducted on patients with VT admitted to a tertiary care hospital over a 5-year period. Among a total of 500 patients with VT, 22 cases (4.4%) of narrow QRS VT were identified. The mean age of these patients was 51.8 years, and the majority were male (72.7%). The most common underlying cardiac pathology was ischemic heart disease (54.5%), followed by non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (27.3%). Narrow QRS VT was often recurrent (59.1%) and typically presented with symptoms of palpitations (68.2%) and presyncope/syncope (50%). Electrophysiological studies were performed in 18 patients (81.8%), and ventricular programmed stimulation was positive for sustained VT in 16 cases (88.9%). In conclusion, although narrow QRS VT is an uncommon form of VT, it should be considered in patients with recurrent palpitations and presyncope/syncope, particularly those with underlying ischemic heart disease or dilated cardiomyopathy. Further research is needed to better understand the mechanisms and optimal management for this condition.

Incidence of hairy cell leukemia, mycosis fungoides, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia in first known HTLV-II-endemic population.  Unlike human T cell leukemia-lymphoma virus type I (HTLV-I), HTLV-II has not been convincingly linked to a malignancy. In this study, we investigated the incidence of hairy cell leukemia (HCL), mycosis fungoides (MF), and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) in the first known HTLV-II-endemic population. A total of 372 individuals were followed prospectively for a median duration of 10 years. Among them, 11 cases of HCL, 16 cases of MF, and 24 cases of CLL were identified. The incidence rates were 9.3, 13.6, and 20.1 per 100,000 person-years for HCL, MF, and CLL, respectively. Compared to general population rates, the standardized incidence ratios (SIRs) were significantly elevated for all three malignancies (SIR for HCL = 26.7, SIR for MF = 33.7, SIR for CLL = 3.8). Our findings suggest a potential association between HTLV-II infection and the development of HCL and MF, while also highlighting the need for further research to understand the underlying mechanisms.

Postictal psychosis after partial complex seizures: a multiple case study. Postictal psychosis (PIP) is a rare phenomenon characterized by acute psychiatric symptoms following a seizure. This multiple case study aimed to investigate the clinical features and outcomes of PIP in patients with partial complex seizures (PCS). Six patients with PIP after PCS were included in the study. Data on clinical characteristics, seizure semiology, and psychiatric symptoms were collected from medical records. All patients underwent neurologic and psychiatric evaluations, and some received neuroimaging studies. The duration of psychosis ranged from a few hours to several days. Psychiatric symptoms varied among patients and included hallucinations, delusions, and disorganized behavior. Treatment with antipsychotic medications was effective in managing symptoms in all cases. Neuroimaging findings were unremarkable. In conclusion, PIP after PCS is a distinct clinical entity characterized by acute and transient psychiatric symptoms. Timely recognition and appropriate management are crucial for the favorable outcomes of affected patients. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and risk factors associated with PIP in this specific population.

Expandable biliary metal stents for malignancies: endoscopic insertion and diathermic cleaning for tumor ingrowth. Endoscopic placement of expandable biliary metal stents has become a widely accepted treatment option for palliation of malignant biliary obstruction. However, tumor ingrowth is a common complication that can result in stent occlusion and reintervention. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of endoscopic diathermic cleaning in treating tumor ingrowth in expandable biliary metal stents. 

A total of 35 patients with obstructive jaundice due to malignant biliary strictures were included in the study. Expandable biliary metal stents were inserted endoscopically in all patients. Among them, 12 patients developed tumor ingrowth during the follow-up period. They underwent endoscopic diathermic cleaning with a high-frequency electrosurgical unit. 

The diathermic cleaning procedure was successful in all cases, with complete removal of tumor ingrowth and restoration of biliary drainage. No major complications were observed during or after the procedure. In addition, stent patency was maintained in all patients during the follow-up period.

In conclusion, endoscopic diathermic cleaning is a safe and effective technique for the management of tumor ingrowth in expandable biliary metal stents. This approach offers a minimally invasive alternative to conventional reintervention methods, providing successful tumor removal and maintaining biliary patency.

Age-related hypotensive effect of placebo and active treatment in patients older than 60 years.  European Working Party on High Blood Pressure in the Elderly. The European Working Party on High Blood Pressure in the Elderly conducted a study to investigate the age-related hypotensive effects of placebo and active treatment in patients over 60 years old. The study involved assessing the blood pressure response in 382 elderly patients who were randomly assigned either placebo or active treatment. The results showed that both placebo and active treatment led to a significant decrease in blood pressure. However, the hypotensive effect was observed to be more pronounced in the active treatment group when compared to the placebo group. Furthermore, the study found that the hypotensive effect of both placebo and active treatment was more prominent in older patients, suggesting that age plays a role in the blood pressure response to treatment. These findings highlight the importance of considering age-related factors when managing high blood pressure in elderly patients.

Improved silver staining of nucleolar organiser regions in paraffin wax sections using an inverted incubation technique [published erratum appears in J Clin Pathol 1991 Jun;44(6):528] A new simple modification to the silver staining of nucleolar organiser regions (AgNORs) was devised which, by performing the incubation with the slide inverted, results in minimal undesirable background staining, a persistent problem. A modification to silver staining of nucleolar organiser regions (AgNORs) was developed to minimize background staining. By inverting the slide during incubation, undesirable staining is reduced. This modification improves the silver staining technique for the visualization of AgNORs in paraffin wax sections. (Word count: 49)

Endoscopic ethmoidectomy and maxillary antrostomy in immunodeficient patients. Immunodeficient patients often suffer from chronic sinusitis that can lead to significant morbidity.
