The efficacy and safety of endoscopic ethmoidectomy with maxillary antrostomy in immunodeficient patients were evaluated in a retrospective study. A total of 27 patients with varying degrees of immunodeficiency underwent the procedure. At a mean follow-up of 12 months, 81% of patients reported subjective improvement in their sinus symptoms. Objective improvement was seen in 76% of patients, as demonstrated by resolution of sinus opacification on computed tomography scan. Complications were seen in 4 patients, including 2 cases of postoperative bleeding and 2 cases of recurrent sinusitis requiring revision surgery. Overall, the procedure was found to be effective and safe in immunodeficient patients, providing significant improvement in sinus symptoms.

Hypertensive heart disease in African-Americans. Hypertensive heart disease is a common condition in African-Americans, and it is characterized by structural and functional abnormalities in the heart due to long-standing high blood pressure. This review focuses on the prevalence, risk factors, and outcomes of hypertensive heart disease specifically in African-Americans. Multiple factors contribute to the increased susceptibility of this population to develop hypertensive heart disease, including genetic predisposition, higher prevalence of hypertension, and socioeconomic factors. African-Americans with hypertensive heart disease have worse outcomes, including increased rates of heart failure, stroke, and mortality, compared to other racial/ethnic groups. Targeted interventions are needed to address this health disparity and improve outcomes in hypertensive heart disease among African-Americans.

Cerebrospinal fluid endothelin-1 and endothelin-3 levels in normal and neurosurgical patients: a clinical study and literature review. This clinical study aimed to investigate the differences in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) levels of endothelin-1 (ET-1) and endothelin-3 (ET-3) between normal individuals and neurosurgical patients. CSF samples were collected from both groups and ET-1 and ET-3 concentrations were measured using ELISA. Additionally, a literature review was performed to evaluate the existing knowledge on CSF endothelin levels in neurosurgical patients. The results showed significantly higher levels of ET-1 and ET-3 in neurosurgical patients compared to normal individuals. The literature review supported these findings, suggesting that increased CSF endothelin levels might be associated with neurosurgical conditions. Further studies are needed to elucidate the role of endothelins in neurosurgical pathophysiology.

Different tumor-derived p53 mutants exhibit distinct biological activities. Tumor-derived p53 mutants are known to have diverse biological functions. This study aimed to investigate the various activities exhibited by different p53 mutants derived from tumors. The researchers analyzed the effect of these mutants on cell growth and apoptosis in both in vitro and in vivo models. They found that different p53 mutants showed distinct biological activities, with some promoting cell growth and others inducing apoptosis. Moreover, they observed that the ability of these mutants to influence cell behavior varied depending on the tumor type from which they were derived. This study provides valuable insights into the functional diversity of tumor-derived p53 mutants and highlights the importance of understanding their specific activities for targeted therapeutic strategies in cancer treatment. Further investigations should explore the underlying mechanisms behind these distinct biological functions.

Large diameter expanded polytetrafluoroethylene grafts for infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery.  The performance of an expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) graft used for aortic aneurysm replacement was evaluated. The use of expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) grafts for infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery was assessed in this study. The study evaluated the performance of these grafts in aortic aneurysm replacement procedures. A total of [number of cases] cases were included in the analysis. Clinical and surgical data were collected and analyzed to assess the outcomes of using ePTFE grafts. The results showed that the ePTFE grafts were effective in replacing the aneurysmal segments and restoring the integrity of the aorta. The grafts demonstrated good patency rates and durability over the follow-up period. Complications such as graft infection or thrombosis were rare. Overall, the findings suggest that ePTFE grafts are a reliable and safe option for infrarenal aortic aneurysm surgery. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up durations are warranted to confirm these findings.

The electrodiagnostic findings in polyneuropathies associated with IgM monoclonal gammopathies. Polyneuropathy is a common complication of monoclonal gammopathies, but the electrodiagnostic features are not well defined. This study aims to describe the electrodiagnostic findings in patients with polyneuropathy associated with IgM monoclonal gammopathies. We retrospectively reviewed the electrodiagnostic studies of 26 patients who met the criteria for IgM monoclonal gammopathy and polyneuropathy. The majority of patients had a distal symmetric sensory-motor polyneuropathy (65.4%). The most common electrodiagnostic findings were axonal polyneuropathy with reduced compound muscle action potentials and sensory nerve action potentials (96.2%). Motor conduction block (57.7%) and prolonged distal motor latencies (57.7%) were also seen frequently. These findings suggest that patients with IgM monoclonal gammopathy and polyneuropathy have characteristic electrodiagnostic features that may aid in the diagnosis and management of this condition.

Treatment of chronic facial palsy by transplantation of the neurovascularized free rectus abdominis muscle. Facial palsy can significantly impact quality of life, and traditional treatment options have limitations. In this case report, a 56-year-old female with longstanding facial palsy underwent a neurovascularized free rectus abdominis muscle transplant. The muscle flap was harvested with its neurovascular bundle and inserted into the paralyzed side of the face, providing both motor and sensory reinnervation. Postoperatively, the patient demonstrated improved facial symmetry at rest and during voluntary movements, and reported improved facial sensation. Objective assessments revealed improved facial muscle strength and decreased synkinetic movements. This novel surgical approach offers a promising alternative for the treatment of chronic facial palsy, providing both functional and aesthetic improvement. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the long-term outcomes and potential complications associated with this procedure.

Association of immunoglobulin Km and Gm allotypes with specific antinuclear antibodies and disease susceptibility among connective tissue disease patients. This study investigated the association between immunoglobulin Km and Gm allotypes and the presence of specific antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) as well as disease susceptibility in patients with connective tissue disease (CTD). A total of 130 CTD patients were enrolled and tested for the presence of ANAs. Immunoglobulin Km and Gm allotypes were determined using serological techniques. The results showed that there was a significant association between specific Km and Gm allotypes and the presence of ANAs. Furthermore, certain Km and Gm allotypes were found to be associated with increased susceptibility to CTD. These findings suggest that immunoglobulin Km and Gm allotypes may play a role in the development of ANAs and CTD and could potentially serve as biomarkers for disease susceptibility in these patients. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of these associations.

Coronary collateral recruitment: functional significance and relation to rate of vessel closure.  Studies in animals and humans have demonstrated the anatomic presence and functional significance of coronary collaterals. Coronary collateral recruitment refers to the process whereby new blood vessels develop to provide alternative routes of blood flow in the heart in response to ischemic conditions. This process has been found to have functional significance in improving myocardial perfusion and reducing the extent of myocardial infarction. Furthermore, the rate of vessel closure, either through natural progression of atherosclerosis or due to interventions such as percutaneous coronary intervention, has been shown to influence the degree of collateral recruitment. Animal and human studies have demonstrated the presence of anatomically formed coronary collaterals and their ability to enhance myocardial blood flow. Understanding the mechanisms and factors influencing collateral recruitment can offer valuable insights into the development of therapeutic strategies for patients with coronary artery disease.

Emergency center ultrasonography in the evaluation of hemoperitoneum: a prospective study.  The reliability of ultrasonographic detection (US) of hemoperitoneum in blunt abdominal trauma was evaluated in a prospective study of 72 patients. The study aimed to assess the accuracy of emergency center ultrasonography (US) in detecting hemoperitoneum in patients with blunt abdominal trauma. A total of 72 patients were prospectively evaluated. Ultrasonographic findings were compared with those obtained from exploratory laparotomy or computed tomography (CT) scan. The results showed that emergency center US had a sensitivity of 95% and a specificity of 98% in detecting hemoperitoneum. These findings suggest that emergency center US is a reliable tool for the evaluation of hemoperitoneum in patients with blunt abdominal trauma, allowing for prompt and accurate diagnosis, potentially reducing unnecessary surgical interventions.

Ichthyosis, mental retardation, and asymptomatic spasticity. Ichthyosis is a rare genetic disorder characterized by dry and scaly skin. Mental retardation and asymptomatic spasticity are additional features that can be present in individuals with ichthyosis. This case report describes a patient with ichthyosis who also had mental retardation and spasticity, but was otherwise asymptomatic. The patient underwent a thorough clinical evaluation, including physical examination, laboratory tests, and genetic analysis. The results revealed a novel mutation in a specific gene associated with ichthyosis. The patient's symptoms were managed with supportive care, including regular application of moisturizers and emollients to the skin to alleviate dryness and scaling. The patient's mental retardation and spasticity were addressed with appropriate therapies and interventions. This case highlights the importance of comprehensive evaluation and management in individuals with ichthyosis and associated conditions such as mental retardation and spasticity.

Thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax using carbon dioxide laser. Spontaneous pneumothorax is a common condition characterized by the accumulation of air in the pleural cavity. Thoracoscopic treatment has become a preferred option due to its minimally invasive nature. However, the optimal method for achieving efficient and safe ventilation during this procedure remains a challenge. This study aims to evaluate the use of carbon dioxide (CO2) laser for thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax.

A total of 50 patients with spontaneous pneumothorax were included in this study. All patients underwent thoracoscopic surgery using CO2 laser for adhesiolysis, pleural abrasion, and stapler-assisted resection of bullae or blebs. The CO2 laser was used to create a controlled and precise dissection of adhesions and to achieve effective hemostasis.

The results showed that the use of CO2 laser in thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax resulted in successful outcomes with minimal complications. The mean operation time was significantly shorter compared to conventional techniques, and there were no instances of postoperative pneumothorax recurrence. Additionally, the laser-generated smoke was efficiently suctioned, minimizing the risk of airway contamination.

In conclusion, the use of CO2 laser in thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax offers a safe and effective option. It allows for precise dissection, effective hemostasis, and shorter operation times. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and compare the outcomes with other techniques.

Incidence of gallstones in a Danish population.  Five-year incidence of gallstone disease was assessed by ultrasonography in an age- and sex-stratified random population of Danish origin aged 30, 40, 50, and 60 years.  The response rate was 82. 8% (2987/3608). The aim of this study was to determine the five-year incidence of gallstone disease in a Danish population. A random population of Danish individuals aged 30, 40, 50, and 60 years was stratified by age and sex, and underwent ultrasonography to assess the presence of gallstones. The study had a high response rate of 82.8% (2987 out of 3608 participants). The results showed the incidence of gallstone disease in this population over a span of five years. This information is important for understanding the prevalence and risk factors associated with gallstones in the Danish population, and can aid in providing appropriate preventive measures and healthcare interventions.

Computerized neuropsychological assessment of cognitive functioning in children with epilepsy. Children with epilepsy often experience cognitive impairments that can impact their academic performance and overall quality of life. Traditional neuropsychological assessment methods can be time-consuming and expensive, making them less feasible for widespread use in this population. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility and reliability of computerized neuropsychological assessments in children with epilepsy. Forty children aged 8-16 years with epilepsy were administered a battery of computerized cognitive tests. Results were compared to normative data, and the test-retest reliability was assessed. The computerized assessments provided reliable measures of cognitive functioning across a range of domains, including attention, memory, and executive function. Additionally, the assessments demonstrated good construct validity by identifying cognitive impairments in children with epilepsy compared to normative data. Computerized neuropsychological assessment shows promise as a feasible and reliable method for evaluating cognitive functioning in children with epilepsy, with potential applications for treatment planning and monitoring.

Carcinoma of the ductus choledochus. Ductus choledochus carcinoma is a rare malignant tumor originating in the bile duct. We present a case study of a 67-year-old male patient diagnosed with ductus choledochus carcinoma. The patient presented with symptoms of obstructive jaundice, abdominal pain, and weight loss. Imaging studies revealed a mass within the bile duct, and biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of ductus choledochus carcinoma. The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. Despite aggressive treatment, the patient experienced disease recurrence after six months. Palliative care was initiated, focusing on symptom management and quality of life. Ductus choledochus carcinoma carries a poor prognosis, and further research is needed to improve treatment outcomes for this rare malignancy.

Myotonic heart disease: a clinical follow-up. This study presents a clinical follow-up of a case of myotonic heart disease in a 48-year-old man. The patient presented with symptoms of cardiomyopathy, including palpitations and exertional dyspnea. Echocardiography revealed left ventricular hypertrophy and reduced systolic function. Genetic testing confirmed a diagnosis of myotonic dystrophy type 1. The patient was treated with a combination of medications, including beta-blockers and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, and underwent regular cardiac monitoring. The follow-up period demonstrated stable cardiac function with improvement in symptoms and reduction in left ventricular hypertrophy. This case highlights the importance of multidisciplinary management in improving the clinical outcomes of patients with myotonic heart disease.

Clinical significance of white cell antibodies in febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions. Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTRs) are common complications of blood transfusion. Antibodies against white blood cells (WBCs) have been implicated in the pathogenesis of FNHTRs. This study aimed to determine the clinical significance of WBC antibodies in FNHTRs. A retrospective analysis of data from transfusion reactions was conducted, and patients with FNHTRs were included. The presence of WBC antibodies was determined using flow cytometry. Out of the included patients, 42.5% had detectable WBC antibodies. Patients with WBC antibodies had a higher incidence of severe reactions and longer hospital stays compared to those without antibodies. Additionally, the presence of WBC antibodies was associated with a higher risk of developing other transfusion-related complications. Thus, the detection of WBC antibodies in FNHTRs may have clinical implications in identifying patients at risk of more severe reactions and guiding transfusion management strategies.

Evidence of a local immune activation in cystic brain tumors. In this study, we investigated the presence of immune activation in cystic brain tumors. We analyzed samples from 20 patients with cystic brain tumors and 10 control samples from non-tumor brain tissue. Immunohistochemistry staining was performed to evaluate the presence of immune cell markers and cytokines. We found increased infiltration of immune cells, including CD3+ T cells and CD68+ macrophages, in the tumor samples compared to control samples. Furthermore, the expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as interleukin-6 and tumor necrosis factor-alpha, was significantly higher in the tumor samples. These findings suggest that there is a local immune response in cystic brain tumors, indicating a potential role of the immune system in the development and progression of these tumors. Further investigations are needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications of this immune activation.

Vegetables, fruits, and carotenoids and the risk of cancer. Numerous studies have suggested that a diet rich in vegetables and fruits is associated with a reduced risk of cancer. Carotenoids, which are pigments found in various fruits and vegetables, have been specifically implicated in cancer prevention. However, the relationship between carotenoid intake and cancer risk remains unclear. In this study, we conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of existing literature to examine the association between vegetable, fruit, and carotenoid intake and the risk of developing cancer. Our analysis included 25 cohort studies and 10 case-control studies, comprising a total of over 1.5 million participants. Overall, we found that a higher intake of vegetables and fruits was associated with a decreased risk of developing cancer, particularly cancers of the lung, stomach, and colorectum. Additionally, our analysis showed that increased carotenoid intake was also associated with a reduced risk of lung and stomach cancer. These findings further support the importance of a diet rich in vegetables and fruits in cancer prevention.

Laser placement in noncontact Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation.  We treated 40 eyes of 40 patients by using noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation to determine whether treatment 1. 5 or 3. In this study, we investigated the efficacy of noncontact transscleral Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation for the treatment of 40 eyes in 40 patients. The aim was to compare the results and outcomes of treatment using different laser placements: 1.5 mm from the limbus (group A) and 3 mm from the limbus (group B). 

The intraocular pressure (IOP) reduction achieved at 1 month follow-up was similar in both groups (group A: 4.5 +/- 1.2 mmHg, group B: 4.1 +/- 0.9 mmHg). No statistically significant difference was found between the two groups in terms of IOP reduction or occurrence of complications. 

Our findings suggest that both 1.5 mm and 3 mm laser placements in noncontact Nd:YAG cyclophotocoagulation are equally effective in reducing IOP in patients with glaucoma. Therefore, the choice of laser placement can be decided based on surgeon preference and anatomical considerations.

Evaluation of vigabatrin as an add-on drug in the management of severe epilepsy.  The effects of the addition of Vigabatrin, a new anti-epileptic drug, to the therapy of 128 patients with severe medically refractory epilepsy is reported. This study evaluated the efficacy of adding Vigabatrin, a new anti-epileptic drug, to the treatment regimen of 128 patients with severe medically refractory epilepsy. The patients' response to the drug was assessed based on seizure frequency and severity. After a 6-month treatment period, it was found that adding Vigabatrin resulted in a significant reduction in both seizure frequency and severity compared to baseline levels. Approximately 70% of patients experienced a greater than 50% reduction in seizure frequency, and 35% achieved seizure freedom. Adverse effects were reported in 26% of patients, with the most common being visual disturbances. Overall, Vigabatrin demonstrated effectiveness as an add-on therapy for severe epilepsy, providing improved seizure control and potential for seizure freedom in a significant proportion of patients.

Environmental risk factors in siblings with Parkinson's disease. This study aimed to investigate environmental risk factors in siblings with Parkinson's disease (PD). A total of 235 PD patients with at least one affected sibling were recruited, along with 235 age- and sex-matched controls. Environmental risk factors, including smoking, exposure to pesticides and solvents, head trauma, and rural living, were assessed through structured interviews. Logistic regression analysis revealed that PD patients had a higher frequency of ever smoking (odds ratio [OR] = 1.69, 95% confidence interval [CI] = 1.07-2.68), exposure to pesticides (OR = 1.79, 95% CI = 1.13-2.84), and rural living (OR = 1.71, 95% CI = 1.08-2.71) compared to controls. However, there was no significant association between PD and exposure to solvents or head trauma. These findings suggest that smoking, exposure to pesticides, and rural living may be potential environmental risk factors for PD in individuals with affected siblings. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms.

Periurethral colonic-type polyp simulating urethral caruncle. This case report describes a rare presentation of a periurethral colonic-type polyp that mimicked a urethral caruncle in a 36-year-old woman. The patient presented with bleeding and a mass protruding from the urethral meatus. Initially, a diagnosis of urethral caruncle was suspected, but subsequent examination revealed a colonic-type polyp. The polyp was successfully excised and histopathological examination confirmed the presence of colonic mucosa, muscularis mucosa, and submucosa. This case highlights the importance of considering uncommon differential diagnoses for urethral lesions, as periurethral colonic-type polyps can closely resemble urethral caruncles. Awareness of this entity can prevent unnecessary interventions or misdiagnosis. Further studies are needed to determine the etiology and optimal management of periurethral colonic-type polyps.

Oxidation reactions in Parkinson's disease. Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Oxidative stress is known to play a crucial role in the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease. We reviewed the literature to examine the involvement of oxidation reactions in the development and progression of this disease. Various studies have reported increased levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and decreased levels of antioxidants in the brains of Parkinson's patients. Furthermore, markers of oxidative damage, such as lipid peroxidation and protein oxidation, were found to be elevated in these patients. Animal models of Parkinson's disease have also demonstrated increased oxidative stress and neurodegeneration. Additionally, genetic mutations that contribute to familial forms of Parkinson's have been linked to oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction. These findings suggest that oxidation reactions play a critical role in the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease. Targeting oxidative stress pathways may therefore be a promising therapeutic approach for this debilitating disorder.

Cosmetic, functional, independent: self-help aids. Cosmetic and functional impairments can greatly impact the quality of life for individuals with physical disabilities. This review evaluates the effectiveness of self-help aids in addressing these impairments and promoting independence. Various types of self-help aids, including mobility aids, personal care aids, and communication aids, are discussed in terms of their impact on cosmetic appearance, functional ability, and overall independence. The review also examines the factors influencing the selection and utilization of self-help aids, such as personal preferences, individual needs, and available resources. Overall, self-help aids show promising results in improving cosmetic appearance, enhancing functional abilities, and promoting independence in individuals with physical disabilities. However, further research is needed to optimize the design and effectiveness of these aids and to ensure their accessibility to a wider population.

Surgical and prosthesis-related complications using the Groningen button voice prosthesis.  Prosthesis-assisted tracheoesophageal speech has advanced speech rehabilitation appreciably. The use of the Groningen button voice prosthesis has greatly improved speech rehabilitation in patients who have undergone laryngectomy. However, complications related to the surgical procedure and prosthesis use can occur. This study aimed to evaluate the surgical and prosthesis-related complications associated with the Groningen button voice prosthesis. A total of XX patients who underwent laryngectomy and subsequent voice prosthesis insertion were included in the study. Complications such as leakage, premature dislodgement, and material breakdown were assessed. The overall complication rate was XX%, with leakage being the most common complication (XX%). Other complications included premature dislodgement (XX%) and material breakdown (XX%). The study suggests that while the Groningen button voice prosthesis has improved speech rehabilitation, surgical and prosthesis-related complications can arise. Further research is necessary to identify strategies to minimize these complications and improve patient outcomes.

The osteogenetic potential of fracture haematoma. This study aimed to investigate the osteogenetic potential of fracture haematoma. Fracture haematoma, a blood clot formed at the site of a fracture, is known to play a crucial role in the healing process. However, it is unclear whether the haematoma itself has the ability to promote bone formation. In this experimental study, fracture haematomas were collected from patients undergoing surgical treatment for fractures and cultured in vitro. The results showed the presence of osteoprogenitor cells within the haematoma, indicating its potential to generate bone tissue. These findings shed light on the biological mechanisms involved in bone healing and may have implications for developing novel therapeutic strategies to enhance fracture healing.

Anisocoria in unilateral ophthalmic disease.  Pupillary diameters in the affected and unaffected eyes of 327 patients with uniocular red eye were assessed during fixation of a distant target. In 327 patients with unilateral red eye, pupillary diameters were measured in both the affected and unaffected eyes while fixating on a distant target. Anisocoria, or unequal pupil size, was observed in a subset of patients with unilateral ophthalmic disease. This finding suggests a potential correlation between anisocoria and the presence of ocular pathology in the affected eye. Further investigation is needed to determine the specific underlying mechanisms and clinical implications of this relationship. These findings highlight the importance of evaluating pupillary abnormalities as part of the diagnostic workup in patients presenting with unilateral red eye.

Outpatient management of schizophrenia. Outpatient management of schizophrenia is a frequently used approach to provide long-term treatment and support for patients with this chronic mental disorder. This medical abstract examines the effectiveness, safety, and feasibility of outpatient management for schizophrenia. The study included 90 patients with schizophrenia who were treated at an outpatient clinic. The results showed that outpatient management was effective in reducing symptoms and improving overall functioning in the majority of patients. Adherence to medication was also found to be higher in the outpatient setting compared to inpatient care. However, challenges such as poor medication compliance and the need for close monitoring and support were identified. Overall, outpatient management of schizophrenia is a viable and beneficial approach, but it requires a comprehensive and multidisciplinary approach to ensure the best outcomes for patients.

Local failure and related complications after definitive treatment of carcinoma of the prostate by irradiation or surgery. This study aimed to compare the local failure rates and related complications following definitive treatment of carcinoma of the prostate by irradiation or surgery. A total of 200 patients were analyzed, with 100 receiving radiotherapy and 100 undergoing surgery. The local failure rate was found to be significantly lower in the surgery group compared to the radiotherapy group. Moreover, surgical treatment had lower rates of urinary and rectal complications compared to radiotherapy. However, the surgical group had a higher risk of erectile dysfunction. These findings suggest that surgery is more effective in preventing local failure and associated complications, while radiotherapy may result in higher rates of urinary and rectal complications.

A comparative study of terbinafine versus griseofulvin in 'dry-type' dermatophyte infections. Dermatophyte infections, also known as ringworm, are commonly treated with antifungal medications such as terbinafine and griseofulvin. However, there is limited evidence comparing the efficacy of these medications in "dry-type" dermatophyte infections, which present with scaly and red skin lesions. In this comparative study, 100 patients with dry-type dermatophyte infections were randomly assigned to either terbinafine or griseofulvin treatment for 4 weeks. Clinical assessment and mycological evaluations were conducted at baseline and at the end of treatment. Results showed that both terbinafine and griseofulvin were effective in improving clinical symptoms and eradicating the fungal infection. However, terbinafine was significantly more effective, with a higher mycological cure rate compared to griseofulvin. Additionally, terbinafine had a lower relapse rate and shorter treatment duration. These findings suggest that terbinafine is the preferred treatment option for dry-type dermatophyte infections, providing a more rapid and durable response.

Degenerative lesions in the articular cartilage after meniscectomy: preliminary experimental study in dogs. A preliminary experimental study in dogs investigates the degenerative lesions in the articular cartilage following meniscectomy. The study finds that meniscectomy results in progressive degenerative changes in the articular cartilage over time. The lesions are characterized by fibrillation, ulceration, and loss of cartilage thickness. These changes are more pronounced in weight-bearing areas of the joint. The study concludes that meniscectomy may lead to accelerated degenerative joint disease and recommends caution in performing this procedure. The findings highlight the importance of preserving the meniscus whenever possible to minimize the risk of subsequent articular cartilage degeneration and the development of osteoarthritis. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and potential interventions to prevent or mitigate these degenerative changes.

The use of bromodeoxyuridine cytokinetic studies as a prognostic indicator of cancer of the head and neck. Bromodeoxyuridine (BrdU) cytokinetic studies have shown promise in predicting the prognosis of cancer of the head and neck. In a retrospective analysis of 100 patients, BrdU labeling index (LI) was found to be significantly associated with disease recurrence and overall survival. Patients with a high BrdU LI had a higher risk of recurrence and shorter overall survival compared to those with a low BrdU LI. Additionally, BrdU LI correlated with tumor grade and stage, suggesting its potential as a prognostic biomarker. Further studies are warranted to validate the use of BrdU cytokinetic studies as a tool for personalized treatment decisions in head and neck cancer.

Benign parotid tumors: a 24-year experience.  The medical records of 125 patients benign parotid neoplasms surgically treated over a 24-year period were retrospectively reviewed; 128 tumors were excised. This retrospective study aims to review the medical records of 125 patients who underwent surgical treatment for benign parotid tumors over a 24-year period. A total of 128 tumors were excised. The objectives of this study were to analyze the demographic characteristics, histopathological diagnoses, and surgical outcomes of these patients. The mean age at diagnosis was found to be 47 years, with a slight female preponderance. Pleomorphic adenoma was the most common histopathological diagnosis, accounting for 75.8% of cases. Other benign tumors included Warthin tumor, oncocytoma, and lipoma. Complications occurred in 11 cases, with facial nerve palsy being the most common. The long-term follow-up showed a low recurrence rate, suggesting favorable outcomes of surgical treatment for benign parotid tumors.

Serum lipids and lipoproteins are less powerful predictors of extracranial carotid artery atherosclerosis than are cigarette smoking and hypertension The effect of serum lipids and lipoproteins on extracranial carotid artery atherosclerosis (CAS) was studied in patients who underwent carotid arteriography. This study aimed to investigate the association between serum lipids and lipoproteins and extracranial carotid artery atherosclerosis (CAS) compared to other risk factors such as cigarette smoking and hypertension. Carotid arteriography was performed on patients to determine the presence and severity of CAS. Serum lipid and lipoprotein levels were measured in these patients. Statistical analysis revealed that cigarette smoking and hypertension were stronger predictors of CAS compared to serum lipids and lipoproteins. Additionally, when adjusting for other risk factors, serum cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol showed a weak association with CAS, while high-density lipoprotein cholesterol showed a protective effect. These findings suggest that serum lipids and lipoproteins have a limited impact on extracranial CAS development, with cigarette smoking and hypertension playing a more significant role.

Evidence of a local immune activation in cystic brain tumors. A study was conducted to investigate the presence of local immune activation in cystic brain tumors. Tissue samples were obtained from 42 patients with cystic brain tumors and analyzed for the expression of immune markers. The results showed a significant upregulation of immune markers, including CD3, CD4, and CD8 T cells, as well as CD68 macrophages, within the cystic fluid of the tumors compared to normal brain tissue. Additionally, an increased expression of cytokines, such as interleukin-6 and tumor necrosis factor-alpha, was observed. These findings indicate a localized immune response within cystic brain tumors, suggesting the involvement of immune cells in the pathogenesis and progression of these tumors. Further exploration of immune-based therapies may be warranted for the treatment of cystic brain tumors.

Selection of patients with stage B prostate cancer for radical prostatectomy.  There are several areas of concern in dealing with clinical stage B disease. Deciding on the appropriate treatment for patients with clinical stage B prostate cancer remains a challenge. This study aimed to identify factors that could help select patients for radical prostatectomy. A total of 168 patients with clinical stage B disease were included in the analysis. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels, Gleason score, age, and clinical symptoms were evaluated. It was found that PSA levels greater than 20 ng/ml and Gleason scores greater than 7 were significant indicators for selecting patients for radical prostatectomy. Age and clinical symptoms did not contribute significantly to the decision-making process. These findings suggest that PSA levels and Gleason scores can provide valuable information in determining the appropriateness of radical prostatectomy in patients with stage B prostate cancer.

A new syndrome: hearing loss and familial salivary gland insensitivity to aldosterone in two brothers.  Two male siblings presented in infancy with hyponatremia. We present a case study of two male siblings who presented in infancy with hyponatremia. Both siblings were found to have hearing loss and familial salivary gland insensitivity to aldosterone. Genetic testing revealed a novel mutation in the mineralocorticoid receptor gene. Despite treatment with high-dose sodium chloride and fludrocortisone, electrolyte abnormalities persisted in both siblings, indicating resistance to aldosterone. Audiological evaluation confirmed bilateral sensorineural hearing loss in both subjects. Further investigation is required to understand the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms of this novel syndrome. Currently, there is no specific treatment available for the hearing loss associated with this syndrome. This case highlights the need for further research to improve our understanding and management of this rare condition.

Biliary pain in postcholecystectomy patients without biliary obstruction. Biliary pain is a common complication following cholecystectomy, even in the absence of biliary obstruction. This study aimed to assess the clinical characteristics and outcomes of postcholecystectomy patients with biliary pain but no evidence of obstruction on imaging studies. A total of 50 patients were included in the study, with an average age of 52 years and a male predominance. Most patients presented with intermittent colicky pain located in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. Imaging studies showed no evidence of biliary obstruction or residual stones. Conservative management, including dietary modifications and pain control, was the main approach in these patients. Follow-up assessment showed that about 60% of patients experienced complete resolution of their symptoms within six months. In conclusion, biliary pain without obstruction can occur after cholecystectomy and can be managed conservatively with favorable outcomes in the majority of cases.

Neonatal diarrhea at a maternity hospital in Rangoon Between 1981 and 1986, 1,540 infants born at the Central Women's Hospital in Rangoon were transferred to the Sick Baby Unit because of diarrhea (15. Between 1981 and 1986, 1,540 infants from the Central Women's Hospital in Rangoon were admitted to the Sick Baby Unit due to neonatal diarrhea. The incidence was 15 cases per 1,000 live births. The majority of cases occurred within the first week of life. Dehydration and electrolyte abnormalities were common among the affected infants. The high prevalence of breastfeeding and poor maternal hygiene were identified as possible risk factors for the development of neonatal diarrhea. The study highlights the need for improved education and interventions to prevent and manage neonatal diarrhea in this population.

Heterogeneity in spasmodic dysphonia.  Neurologic and voice findings.  Spasmodic dysphonia is a disturbance of phonation with laryngeal spasms. Spasmodic dysphonia is a disorder characterized by laryngeal spasms causing disturbances in phonation. This study aimed to investigate the heterogeneity in spasmodic dysphonia by evaluating neurologic and voice findings. A total of 17 patients with spasmodic dysphonia underwent comprehensive neurological evaluations and voice assessments. Three subtypes of spasmodic dysphonia were identified: adductor (n=9), abductor (n=5), and mixed (n=3). Neurological findings included cervical dystonia, tremor, and parkinsonism in some patients. Voice assessments revealed varying degrees of voice quality impairment, including breathiness, strain, and pitch breaks. Furthermore, acoustic analysis showed significant differences in voice parameters among the subtypes. These findings highlight the heterogeneity of spasmodic dysphonia, suggesting potential underlying neurological and pathophysiological differences. Further understanding of these variations may facilitate improved diagnosis and treatment strategies for individuals with spasmodic dysphonia.

Drug response of head and neck tumors in native-state histoculture.  We describe a chemosensitivity testing of head and neck tumors, in which a native-state histoculture, ie, a three-dimensional culture system that maintains important in vivo properties, including tissue architecture, was used. Chemosensitivity testing of head and neck tumors is crucial for guiding personalized treatment strategies. In this study, we utilized a native-state histoculture system, which preserves the in vivo properties of the tissue, including tissue architecture. Tumor samples from head and neck cancer patients were cultured in this three-dimensional system, and their response to various chemotherapeutic agents was assessed. Our findings demonstrate that the native-state histoculture system accurately reflects drug response in tumors, as compared to conventional two-dimensional cell cultures. This approach provides a valuable tool for predicting individualized drug responses and advancing precision medicine in the treatment of head and neck tumors.

Blood pressure measurements during dental checkups representative of 26-hour registration.  The effect of dental checkups on blood pressure was investigated. This study aimed to investigate the effect of dental checkups on blood pressure measurements over a 26-hour period. Blood pressure measurements were taken from 50 participants before, during, and after dental checkups. The results showed a significant increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure during the dental checkups compared to baseline measurements. This increase was sustained for up to 2 hours post-checkup and gradually returned to baseline levels over the following 24 hours. Interestingly, participants who reported dental anxiety exhibited a greater increase in blood pressure during the checkups compared to those without anxiety. These findings suggest that dental checkups can temporarily elevate blood pressure, particularly in individuals with dental anxiety. Further research is needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential long-term effects of these blood pressure fluctuations in dental settings.

Central airway obstruction due to cytomegalovirus-induced necrotizing tracheitis in a patient with AIDS. This case report describes a patient with AIDS who presented with central airway obstruction caused by cytomegalovirus-induced necrotizing tracheitis. The patient had a history of recurrent respiratory symptoms and was found to have marked tracheal stenosis on bronchoscopy. Histological examination of the tracheal tissue revealed focal ulceration, granulation tissue, and dense infiltration of inflammatory cells, consistent with cytomegalovirus infection. The patient underwent bronchoscopic debridement and received antiviral therapy with ganciclovir. Despite initial improvement, the patient experienced recurrent episodes of airway obstruction requiring multiple interventions, including bronchoscopic stent placement and dilation. The patient ultimately developed respiratory failure and succumbed to the disease. This case highlights the importance of considering cytomegalovirus-induced tracheitis as a potential cause of central airway obstruction in patients with AIDS and emphasizes the challenges in managing this rare complication. Further research is needed to optimize the treatment and outcomes of patients with this condition.

Cerebrospinal fluid fistula and endoscopic sinus surgery.  Seven cases of cerebrospinal fluid fistulae occurring as a result of endoscopic sinus surgery in a total of 800 ethmoidectomies are discussed, along with 1 case referred for consultation. This study presents seven cases of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) fistulae that occurred as a complication of endoscopic sinus surgery, out of a total of 800 ethmoidectomies performed. An additional case referred for consultation is also discussed. The occurrence of CSF fistulae in these cases highlights the potential risk associated with this surgical procedure. These fistulae can lead to various complications, including meningitis and intracranial infections. Prompt recognition and appropriate management are crucial to prevent potentially life-threatening consequences. Identifying risk factors and implementing preventive measures may help minimize the occurrence of CSF fistulae in patients undergoing endoscopic sinus surgery. Further studies are needed to better understand the mechanisms and strategies for prevention of this surgical complication.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease from allogeneic dura: a review of risks and safety. Allogeneic dura mater grafts are frequently used in neurosurgical procedures, but there is potential for the transmission of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a fatal neurodegenerative disorder. This review examines the risks and safety associated with allogeneic dura grafts. Multiple cases of CJD transmission from contaminated dura grafts have been reported, resulting in a high mortality rate. The risk of CJD transmission is influenced by factors such as the donor's age, genotype, and the presence of underlying dural pathologies. Current screening and sterilization techniques may not completely eliminate the risk of CJD transmission. Various safety measures have been proposed, including stricter donor selection criteria and the use of alternative graft materials. Surgeons and neurologists should be aware of the potential risks and consider alternative options to minimize the risk of CJD transmission associated with allogeneic dura grafts.

Nitrite from inflammatory cells--a cancer risk factor in ulcerative colitis? Elevated levels of luminal nitrite and a lowered luminal pH were found in 77 percent of patients with acute ulcerative colitis. Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer. Ulcerative colitis is a form of IBD characterized by inflammation of the colon and rectum. Previous studies have suggested that nitrite, a molecule produced by inflammatory cells, may play a role in the development of cancer. In this study, elevated levels of luminal nitrite and a decreased luminal pH were observed in the majority of patients with acute ulcerative colitis. These findings suggest that nitrite from inflammatory cells may act as a risk factor for cancer development in ulcerative colitis patients. Further research is needed to elucidate the exact mechanisms underlying this association and to develop potential preventive strategies.

Isolated congenital stapes ankylosis: surgical results in 32 ears and a review of the literature.  Isolated congenital stapes ankylosis is described in 32 operated ears from 28 patients. This study presents the surgical results and reviews the literature on isolated congenital stapes ankylosis in 32 ears from 28 patients. The mean age at the time of surgery was 37.6 years, with a range of 14-62 years. The most common presenting symptom was hearing loss, followed by tinnitus and aural fullness. Preoperative audiological evaluation showed a mean air-bone gap of 32.8 dB. All patients underwent stapedectomy with either Teflon or hydroxyapatite piston. Postoperative evaluation revealed a mean air-bone gap closure of 12.4 dB. The overall success rate was 82.1%, with satisfactory hearing improvement achieved in 75% of cases. Complications were observed in 3 ears, including one case of sensorineural hearing loss. In conclusion, surgical intervention for isolated congenital stapes ankylosis can lead to significant improvement in hearing, with a relatively low rate of complications.

Protective and curative effects of rifampicin in Acanthamoeba meningitis of the mouse. Acanthamoeba meningitis is a rare but devastating infection of the central nervous system. Currently, treatment options are limited and often ineffective. This study aimed to evaluate the potential protective and curative effects of rifampicin, a commonly used antibiotic, against Acanthamoeba meningitis in a mouse model. The mice were infected with Acanthamoeba and treated with rifampicin either prophylactically or therapeutically. Results showed that rifampicin significantly reduced the mortality rate and improved overall survival in both treatment groups. Additionally, histopathological analysis revealed reduced inflammation and amoebic burden in the rifampicin-treated mice. These findings suggest that rifampicin may have potential therapeutic benefits in treating Acanthamoeba meningitis.

US-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy of gallbladder masses.  Ultrasonically (US) guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy was performed in 88 patients who had gallbladder masses. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of ultrasonically (US)-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy in diagnosing gallbladder masses. A total of 88 patients with gallbladder masses underwent US-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy. The obtained specimens were analyzed for cytological examination. Among the 88 patients, 78 had malignant gallbladder masses and 10 had benign lesions. The overall diagnostic accuracy of US-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy was 96.6%, with a sensitivity of 98.7% and a specificity of 90.0%. No major complications were observed during or after the procedure. The most common minor complication was mild pain at the biopsy site, which resolved spontaneously. US-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy is a reliable and safe technique for the diagnosis of gallbladder masses, providing high diagnostic accuracy and minimal complications.

Differences in the membrane interaction of scrapie amyloid precursor proteins in normal and scrapie- or Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease-infected brains. This study aimed to investigate the differences in membrane interaction of scrapie amyloid precursor proteins (PrPSc) in normal brains and brains infected with scrapie or Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). Membrane fractions were isolated from normal, scrapie-infected, and CJD-infected brains and subjected to Western blot analysis using antibodies against the C-terminus of PrP. The results showed that PrPSc from scrapie-infected and CJD-infected brains exhibited an increased interaction with membranes compared to PrP from normal brains. Additionally, the membrane-bound PrPSc displayed a higher molecular weight compared to the soluble form. Furthermore, the membrane-bound PrPSc from CJD-infected brains exhibited a distinct electrophoretic pattern compared to scrapie-infected brains. These findings suggest that the membrane interaction of PrPSc is altered in brains infected with scrapie or CJD, possibly contributing to the disease pathogenesis. Further investigation is warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and implications of these differences in membrane interaction.

Role of cell-mediated immunity to staphylococci in blepharitis. This study aimed to investigate the role of cell-mediated immunity in blepharitis caused by staphylococci. A total of 40 patients with chronic blepharitis were enrolled, and their clinical parameters were assessed. T-cell proliferation assays were performed to measure the cell-mediated immune response against staphylococcal antigens. The results showed that patients with blepharitis had significantly reduced T-cell proliferation compared to healthy controls, indicating impaired cell-mediated immunity. Furthermore, the severity of blepharitis was negatively correlated with T-cell proliferation, suggesting that a compromised immune response may contribute to the progression of the disease. These findings highlight the importance of cell-mediated immunity in the pathogenesis of blepharitis and suggest potential avenues for therapeutic interventions targeting immune function in this condition.

Effects of acute ethanol ingestion and burn injury on serum immunoglobulin.  Previous studies have found that acute ethanol ingestion before burn injury caused further impairment of mitogenic response of B lymphocytes compared with burn injury alone. The effects of acute ethanol ingestion and burn injury on serum immunoglobulin levels were examined in this study. Previous research has demonstrated that acute ethanol ingestion exacerbates the weakening of the mitogenic response of B lymphocytes caused by burn injury. To further investigate this phenomenon, a total of 40 adult male rats were divided into four groups: control, ethanol, burn injury, and ethanol plus burn injury. The rats in the ethanol group were given a single dose of ethanol via oral gavage, while the burn injury group received a full-thickness burn injury. The ethanol plus burn injury group experienced both acute ethanol ingestion and burn injury. After 24 hours, blood samples were collected for analysis of serum immunoglobulin levels. The results showed that acute ethanol ingestion alone did not significantly affect serum immunoglobulin levels. However, burn injury alone caused a significant decrease in serum immunoglobulin levels compared to the control group. Interestingly, acute ethanol ingestion combined with burn injury resulted in an even further reduction in serum immunoglobulin levels, indicating a synergistic effect between acute ethanol ingestion and burn injury on immune function. These findings suggest that acute ethanol ingestion can exacerbate the immunosuppressive effects of burn injury, highlighting the importance of avoiding alcohol consumption during the recovery phase of burn injury.

Closure of leaking filtering blebs with cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive. Leaking filtering blebs can lead to complications such as hypotony, which can cause vision loss. This case series evaluates the use of cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive in closing leaking filtering blebs. Four patients with leaking blebs were treated with cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive. Follow-up examinations showed successful closure of the leaking blebs and resolution of symptoms in all patients. No adverse effects were observed. Cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive appears to be a safe and effective alternative for managing leaking filtering blebs. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and explore long-term outcomes.

Proximal posterior cerebral artery occlusion simulating middle cerebral artery occlusion. Proximal posterior cerebral artery (PCA) occlusion is a rare condition that can mimic middle cerebral artery (MCA) occlusion. We present two cases of patients who presented with clinical and radiological findings consistent with MCA occlusion, but subsequent angiogram revealed proximal PCA occlusion. This misdiagnosis can lead to delayed or inappropriate treatment, as the management of MCA and PCA occlusions differs. Recognition of the radiological and clinical features that distinguish these two conditions is essential. Clinicians should be aware of the possibility of proximal PCA occlusion when evaluating patients with suspected MCA occlusion to ensure accurate diagnosis and appropriate management. Further studies are needed to explore the underlying mechanisms and risk factors associated with proximal PCA occlusion.

Spinal cord inhibitory mechanisms in Parkinson's disease. This study aimed to investigate the involvement of spinal cord inhibitory mechanisms in Parkinson's disease. Using animal models, researchers examined the changes in spinal cord inhibitory neurotransmission and its relation to motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease. They found that there was a reduction in the inhibitory neurotransmitter, gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), in the spinal cord of Parkinson's disease animals. This decrease in GABAergic transmission was associated with an increase in motor symptoms and motor cortex hyperexcitability. Additionally, the researchers observed alterations in the expression of GABA receptor subtypes, suggesting a dysregulation of inhibitory signaling in Parkinson's disease. These findings highlight the role of spinal cord inhibitory mechanisms in the pathophysiology of Parkinson's disease and suggest potential therapeutic targets for managing motor symptoms. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop targeted interventions.

Effects of pill-giving on maintenance of placebo response in patients with chronic mild depression Fifty outpatients with mild, chronic, mood-reactive depression whose mood improved markedly after a 10-day single-blind placebo trial were randomly assigned in a double-blind design either to have their placebo medication discontinued or to have it maintained for an additional 6 weeks. This study aimed to investigate the effects of discontinuing placebo medication on the maintenance of placebo response in patients with chronic mild depression. Fifty outpatients who showed marked improvement in mood after a 10-day single-blind placebo trial were randomly assigned to either discontinue placebo medication or continue it for 6 more weeks in a double-blind design. The results suggest that maintaining placebo medication led to better maintenance of the placebo response in patients with chronic mild depression. Further research is needed to validate these findings and determine the underlying mechanisms.

Cardiopulmonary resuscitation and the patient with cancer.  The records of 114 cancer patients suffering cardiopulmonary arrests (CPA) during a 3-year period at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) were retrospectively reviewed to identify variables predicting final outcome in these patients. This retrospective review aimed to identify predictive factors for final outcomes in cancer patients who suffered cardiopulmonary arrests (CPA). The medical records of 114 patients at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center were analyzed over a 3-year period. Among the study population, the majority (62%) had solid tumors. The overall survival rate was found to be 4.4% with a median survival time of 1.4 months. Patients who had a return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) were more likely to survive than those who did not (p < 0.01). Additionally, patients with a ROSC and a non-solid tumor had a higher survival rate than those with a ROSC and a solid tumor (p < 0.001). These findings provide insight into predicting outcomes and guiding resuscitation efforts in cancer patients who suffer CPA.

Ultrasonography in the differentiation of complicated and uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis.  Differentiation of uncomplicated pyelonephritis versus complicated pyelonephritis has always been problematic. Differentiating between complicated and uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis has always posed a challenge. This article examines the role of ultrasonography in distinguishing these two conditions. Several studies were reviewed, and it was found that ultrasonography can be a valuable tool in identifying complications associated with acute pyelonephritis. Findings such as the presence of abscesses, focal renal enlargement, or focal loss of cortical definition on ultrasound were indicative of complicated pyelonephritis. On the other hand, uncomplicated pyelonephritis usually presented with diffuse renal enlargement and increased echogenicity. Despite its usefulness, ultrasonography alone might not be sufficient for an accurate diagnosis, and additional imaging techniques like computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging might be required in certain cases. Overall, ultrasonography shows promise in differentiating complicated and uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis, but further research is needed to fully establish its diagnostic accuracy.

Nondiagnosed left main ostial stenosis partly due to the use of 5 French coronary angiographic catheters. A case of nondiagnosed left main ostial stenosis related to the use of 5 French coronary angiographic catheters is reported. The patient presented with recurrent angina and electrocardiographic changes during cardiac catheterization. Despite the use of a 5 French catheter, the left main ostium stenosis was missed initially due to inadequate engagement of the catheter with the ostium. Subsequent imaging with a larger catheter revealed the presence of significant stenosis. This case highlights the importance of careful catheter engagement and thorough imaging during cardiac catheterization, especially when using smaller caliber catheters. Prompt recognition and treatment of left main ostial stenosis is crucial to prevent potential adverse cardiovascular events and improve patient outcomes.

Moustache appearance in craniopharyngiomas: unique magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomographic findings of perifocal edema. Craniopharyngiomas are rare benign intracranial tumors that commonly present with visual deficits. We report a case of a 38-year-old male with a craniopharyngioma who presented with a unique finding of moustache appearance on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computed tomography (CT). The moustache appearance was characterized by perifocal edema surrounding the tumor in a pattern that resembled a moustache, with bilateral symmetrical involvement of the frontal lobes and lateral ventricles. This finding has not been previously described in the literature. The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor, and postoperative MRI showed resolution of the moustache appearance. This case highlights the importance of recognizing the moustache appearance as a potential imaging finding in craniopharyngiomas, which may aid in the diagnosis and management of these tumors. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and clinical significance of this unique imaging finding.

Germfree animals and technics in surgical research. In surgical research, the use of germfree animals plays a critical role in ensuring the validity and reliability of experimental outcomes. This report aims to review the importance of germfree animals and the techniques involved in maintaining their germfree state. Germfree animals, also known as axenic animals, are free from all types of microorganisms including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites. These animals provide a controlled environment for studying the influence of specific microorganisms on various pathological conditions. The techniques involved in maintaining germfree animals include the use of sterile materials, strict hygiene practices, and specialized isolators or gnotobiotic facilities. Additionally, the report highlights the challenges associated with working with germfree animals, such as susceptibility to infections, the need for specialized diets, and limited availability of germfree strains for specific research purposes. Overall, the use of germfree animals and the techniques employed in surgical research offer valuable insights into the role of microorganisms in disease progression and treatment response.

Results of treatment of displaced patellar fractures by partial patellectomy. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of displaced patellar fractures treated with partial patellectomy. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients who underwent surgery for displaced patellar fractures between 2010 and 2018. The surgical technique involved partial patellectomy, followed by tendon repair or rerouting. Functional outcomes and complications were assessed using the Kujala score and modified Nebraska Knee score. A total of 32 patients were included in the study, with a mean follow-up of 24 months. The results showed satisfactory functional outcomes, with a mean Kujala score of 81 and modified Nebraska Knee score of 71 at final follow-up. Complications were observed in 8 patients, including wound infection and quadriceps weakness. Overall, partial patellectomy provided acceptable functional outcomes in displaced patellar fractures. However, careful patient selection and appropriate surgical technique are crucial to minimize complications and optimize outcomes. Further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up periods are warranted to validate these findings.

Overnight admission of outpatient strabismus patients.  The trend to outpatient strabismus surgery prompted us to determine the frequency of, and the reasons for, postoperative overnight hospital admission following such surgery. This study aimed to investigate the frequency and reasons for postoperative overnight hospital admission in outpatient strabismus surgery. A retrospective analysis of patient records was conducted for all strabismus surgeries performed on an outpatient basis over a one-year period. Out of 250 cases, 35 (14%) required overnight admission. The most common reason for overnight admission was postoperative nausea and vomiting (46%), followed by pain management (26%) and persistent ocular discomfort (20%). Other reasons included surgical complications and patient or parental preference. The study highlights the importance of identifying potential factors that may increase the likelihood of overnight admission in order to improve patient management and reduce healthcare costs in outpatient strabismus surgery. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate and expand upon these findings.

Therapy of persistent human papillomavirus disease with two different interferon species. Persistent human papillomavirus (HPV) infection can lead to serious health consequences, including genital warts and cervical cancer. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of two different interferon species in the treatment of persistent HPV disease. A total of 60 patients with persistent HPV infection were randomly assigned to receive either interferon alpha-2b or interferon beta-1a. The treatment was administered three times a week for a duration of 12 weeks. The response to treatment was evaluated by measuring the clearance of HPV DNA and resolution of clinical lesions. Both interferon alpha-2b and interferon beta-1a were found to be effective in reducing HPV viral load and eliminating clinical lesions. However, interferon beta-1a showed a higher overall response rate compared to interferon alpha-2b. These findings suggest that interferon therapy can be a valuable treatment option for patients with persistent HPV infection, with interferon beta-1a demonstrating a potential advantage over interferon alpha-2b.

Dissociation between pain and autonomic disturbances in cluster headache. Cluster headache is a severe headache disorder characterized by excruciatingly painful episodes that occur in clusters or bouts. This study aimed to investigate the dissociation between pain and autonomic disturbances in cluster headache. A total of 29 patients were included in the study, and their pain intensity and autonomic disturbances were assessed during cluster headache attacks. Surprisingly, 13 out of the 29 patients reported dissociation between pain and autonomic disturbances, where they experienced severe pain without accompanying autonomic symptoms. These patients had shorter attack durations, lower frequency of attacks, and a longer history of cluster headache compared to those without dissociation. Furthermore, they had a higher prevalence of chronic cluster headache. These findings highlight the complex nature of cluster headache and suggest that autonomic disturbances may not be essential for diagnosing and managing the condition. Future research should focus on elucidating the mechanisms underlying dissociation between pain and autonomic disturbances to improve the understanding and treatment of cluster headache.

Reduction of the membrane fluidity of human breast cancer cells by tamoxifen and 17 beta-estradiol. In this study, we investigated the effects of tamoxifen and 17 beta-estradiol on the membrane fluidity of human breast cancer cells. Tamoxifen, a selective estrogen receptor modulator, is commonly used in the treatment of breast cancer, while 17 beta-estradiol is a natural estrogen hormone. Using fluorescence polarization spectroscopy, we found that both tamoxifen and 17 beta-estradiol significantly reduced the membrane fluidity of breast cancer cells compared to control cells. This decrease in membrane fluidity could have important implications for the behavior and function of breast cancer cells, including their ability to metastasize and respond to therapeutic interventions. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential clinical implications of these findings.

Application of coronary angioplasty to the septal perforator arteries. Coronary angioplasty is a common interventional procedure used to treat coronary artery disease. However, its application to the septal perforator arteries, which are small branches of the coronary arteries supplying blood to the septum of the heart, is less explored. We report a case of a 65-year-old man diagnosed with severe angina and ischemia in the septal region. Coronary angiography revealed stenosis in the septal perforator arteries causing myocardial ischemia. Using a specialized microcatheter, successful angioplasty and stenting of the stenotic septal perforator arteries were performed. This resulted in significant improvement of symptoms and resolution of myocardial ischemia. While further studies are needed, our case highlights the potential benefits of applying coronary angioplasty to the septal perforator arteries in selected patients with ischemic heart disease.

Biotype as determinant of natural immunising effect of cholera. This study aimed to investigate the role of biotype in the natural immunising effect of cholera. Stool samples from 100 individuals with cholera were analyzed for their biotype classification. The participants were divided into two groups: those infected with biotype classical and those infected with biotype El Tor cholera strains. The antibody response to cholera toxin was measured in these individuals. The results showed that individuals infected with the classical biotype had a significantly higher antibody response compared to those infected with the El Tor biotype. This suggests that biotype influences the natural immunising effect of cholera, highlighting the importance of considering biotype variation in cholera vaccine development and prevention strategies.

Adventitial red blood cells produce intimal platelet accumulation in cerebral arteries of cats following subarachnoid hemorrhage. Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is a devastating medical condition associated with high mortality and severe morbidity. The pathophysiology of SAH involves the release of various substances that contribute to cerebral artery vasospasm and subsequent ischemic complications. This study aimed to investigate the role of adventitial red blood cells (RBCs) in the development of intimal platelet accumulation in cerebral arteries following SAH in cats. Utilizing a feline SAH model, histological and immunohistochemical analyses were performed to assess the presence of adventitial RBCs and platelet accumulation in cerebral arteries. Results demonstrated a significant increase in the number of RBCs within the adventitial layer of the affected arteries, which correlated with the extent of platelet accumulation in the intima. Furthermore, inhibition of RBC adhesion to the adventitial layer using anti-ICAM-1 antibodies significantly attenuated platelet accumulation. These findings suggest that adventitial RBCs play a crucial role in promoting intimal platelet accumulation following SAH, providing a potential therapeutic target for preventing cerebral artery vasospasm and subsequent ischemic complications in SAH patients.

Treatment of cutaneous T cell lymphoma with a combination of low-dose interferon alfa-2b and retinoids. Cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CTCL) is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that primarily affects the skin. Current treatment options for CTCL are limited and often associated with adverse side effects. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy and safety of a combination therapy consisting of low-dose interferon alfa-2b and retinoids in the treatment of CTCL. A total of 25 patients with CTCL were enrolled in the study and followed for a period of 12 months. The combination therapy resulted in significant improvement in both clinical symptoms and histological findings, with a complete response observed in 40% of the patients. Furthermore, the therapy was well-tolerated, with few adverse side effects reported. These findings suggest that the combination of low-dose interferon alfa-2b and retinoids may be a promising treatment option for CTCL. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these findings.

Cervical spine stabilization.  A three-dimensional, biomechanical evaluation of rotational stability, strength, and failure mechanisms. Cervical spine stabilization is crucial for preventing further injury and promoting recovery in patients with cervical spine instability. This study aimed to evaluate the rotational stability, strength, and failure mechanisms of three-dimensional cervical spine stabilization techniques. Biomechanical testing was conducted using human cadaveric cervical spines subjected to various loading conditions. Results showed that the rotational stability of the cervical spine was significantly improved with the use of stabilization techniques, compared to the unstable condition. Additionally, the strength of the stabilizing constructs was found to be sufficient to withstand physiological loads. Failure mechanisms were primarily observed at the interface between the stabilization device and bone, with screw pullout being the most common mode of failure. These findings provide valuable insights into the biomechanics of cervical spine stabilization, informing the development of more effective treatment strategies for patients with cervical spine instability.

Response of the Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome to treatment of associated small-cell lung carcinoma.  We evaluated the outcome in 16 patients with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) associated with histologically verified small-cell carcinoma (SCC). In this study, we assessed the response of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) to treatment of concomitant small-cell lung carcinoma (SCC) in 16 patients. All patients had histologically confirmed SCC. Treatment involved surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy for SCC, while LEMS was managed with symptomatic and immunomodulatory therapies. Seven patients (43.8%) achieved complete remission, with resolution of LEMS symptoms, while five patients (31.3%) experienced partial remission. Four patients (25.0%) did not respond to treatment. The overall response rate was 75.0%. Adverse events were mild and manageable. Our findings suggest that effective treatment of SCC can lead to significant improvement in LEMS symptoms. Further research is needed to optimize treatment strategies for this challenging coexisting condition.

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease--more than a renal disease.  Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is the most common genetic disease, affecting a half million Americans. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is a prevalent genetic disorder with renal manifestations. However, recent evidence suggests that ADPKD is not solely limited to the kidneys and may have systemic effects. This comprehensive review aims to summarize the extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD, encompassing cardiovascular complications, hepatic involvement, intracranial aneurysms, and gastrointestinal manifestations. Additionally, we discuss the potential mechanisms underlying these extra-renal manifestations, such as altered cilia function and abnormal signaling pathways. Understanding the systemic nature of ADPKD is crucial for early detection, appropriate management, and improved patient outcomes. Further research is needed to elucidate the complex interplay between the primary renal disease and its extrarenal manifestations, leading to the development of targeted therapies and personalized treatment approaches for ADPKD patients.

True hermaphrodite with bilateral ovotestes, bilateral gonadoblastomas and dysgerminomas, 46,XX/46,XY karyotype, and a successful pregnancy. We present a rare case of a true hermaphrodite with bilateral ovotestes, bilateral gonadoblastomas, dysgerminomas, a 46,XX/46,XY karyotype, and a successful pregnancy. A 37-year-old individual presented with primary amenorrhea and a palpable mass in the inguinal region. Imaging revealed bilateral gonadal tumors, confirmed as gonadoblastomas with focal areas of dysgerminoma. Histopathology also revealed bilateral ovotestes. Karyotype analysis revealed a 46,XX/46,XY karyotype. The patient underwent bilateral gonadectomy and adjuvant chemotherapy. Despite the presence of dysgerminomas, the patient attained successful pregnancy through assisted reproductive technology. This case highlights the complexity of true hermaphroditism and the importance of multidisciplinary management in achieving favorable outcomes. Further studies are needed to better understand the reproductive potential and long-term implications of individuals with true hermaphroditism and coexisting gonadal tumors.

What to do when an x-ray film suggests lung cancer. When an x-ray film suggests lung cancer, further investigation is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of the disease. This typically involves additional imaging studies such as a computed tomography (CT) scan or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to provide more detailed images of the lungs and surrounding structures. Additionally, a biopsy may be required to obtain a tissue sample for pathological examination, which can provide definitive evidence of malignancy. Other tests, such as blood tests and pulmonary function tests, may be conducted to assess the patient's overall health and lung function. Prompt diagnosis and staging of lung cancer are essential for guiding appropriate treatment decisions and improving patient outcomes.
