Epstein-Barr virus small nuclear RNAs are not expressed in permissively infected cells in AIDS-associated leukoplakia. We investigated the expression of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs) in permissively infected cells within AIDS-associated leukoplakia, a pre-malignant oral lesion. We used RNA in situ hybridization to detect the presence of EBV-encoded small RNAs (EBERs), which serve as markers for viral infection. Our study included 25 cases of AIDS-associated leukoplakia. We found that none of the permissively infected cells within the lesions expressed the snRNAs, indicating that these viral transcripts are not essential for viral replication in this context. This finding suggests a potential role for other mechanisms in the development and progression of EBV-associated malignancies in the setting of immunosuppression. Further investigations are needed to elucidate the specific mechanisms involved and to develop targeted interventions for this high-risk population.

Attributes and survival patterns of multiple primary cutaneous malignant melanoma.  From a series of 1495 patients with primary cutaneous malignant melanoma (PCMM), 26 patients (1. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 1495 patients with primary cutaneous malignant melanoma (PCMM) to investigate the attributes and survival patterns of multiple primary PCMM. Among the patients, 26 (1.7%) had multiple primary PCMM. The median age at diagnosis for these patients was 55 years, with a female predominance (65.4%). The majority of multiple primary PCMM cases were located on the trunk (46.2%) and extremities (38.5%). The mean thickness of the lesions was 1.9 mm. Five-year survival rates for patients with multiple primary PCMM were 87% for stage I, 61% for stage II, and 25% for stage III. The presence of multiple primary PCMM is associated with younger age, female gender, and worse survival outcomes compared to single primary PCMM cases.

Synchronous positive and negative myoclonus due to pontine hemorrhage. We present a case of synchronous positive and negative myoclonus in a patient with pontine hemorrhage. The patient, a 63-year-old male, developed sudden-onset jerking movements in both upper limbs, followed by simultaneous brief episodes of muscle contractions and relaxation. Brain imaging revealed a hemorrhage in the pons. Electromyography confirmed the presence of myoclonus, with synchronous activation and inhibition of the agonist and antagonist muscles. Treatment with clonazepam resulted in partial improvement of the myoclonus. Synchronous positive and negative myoclonus is a rare presentation, and its occurrence in the setting of pontine hemorrhage suggests a disruption of the inhibitory and excitatory circuits in the brainstem. Further studies are warranted to better understand the pathophysiology and optimal management of this condition.

Elevation of skeletal muscle isoform of serum creatine kinase in heterozygous familial hypercholesterolaemia. Serum creatine kinase (CK) levels were analyzed in patients with heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) to assess the presence of skeletal muscle isoform (CK-MM) elevation as a potential marker for muscle damage. A total of 45 patients with FH and 45 age- and sex-matched control subjects were included in the study. Serum CK-MM levels were significantly higher in the FH group compared to controls (p < 0.001). Furthermore, 18 patients with FH (40%) showed CK-MM levels above the upper limit of normal. There was no correlation between CK-MM levels and lipid profile parameters. These findings suggest that elevated CK-MM levels may indicate skeletal muscle damage in patients with heterozygous FH, potentially contributing to further complications in this population.

Immunohistochemical demonstration of keratin in ameloblastoma as an indication of tumor differentiation. Ameloblastoma is a rare odontogenic tumor of the jaw characterized by local invasiveness and aggressive behavior. The ability to differentiate between ameloblastoma and other odontogenic tumors is crucial for appropriate treatment planning. This study aimed to evaluate the expression of keratin, a marker of epithelial differentiation, in ameloblastoma and its potential diagnostic and prognostic value. Immunohistochemical staining for keratin was performed on tissue sections from 50 cases of ameloblastoma. The results showed strong and diffuse cytoplasmic staining for keratin in all ameloblastoma cases, regardless of histological subtype. In contrast, other odontogenic tumors demonstrated variable keratin expression. These findings suggest that immunohistochemical detection of keratin can be a useful tool in differentiating ameloblastoma from other odontogenic tumors, aiding in accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment selection.

Supported employment: an alternative model for vocational rehabilitation of persons with severe neurologic, psychiatric, or physical disability. Supported employment is an alternative model for vocational rehabilitation of individuals with severe neurologic, psychiatric, or physical disability. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of supported employment for improving employment outcomes compared to traditional vocational rehabilitation methods. Fifty participants with severe disabilities were randomly assigned to either supported employment or traditional vocational rehabilitation. The supported employment group received individualized job placement, ongoing support, and follow-up services, while the traditional vocational rehabilitation group received standard services. Results showed that individuals in the supported employment group were more likely to obtain and maintain competitive employment compared to those in the traditional rehabilitation group. Additionally, participants in the supported employment group reported higher levels of job satisfaction and overall functioning. These findings suggest that supported employment is a promising approach for individuals with severe disabilities seeking employment.

Triiodothyronine and brain excitability.  We investigated mechanisms involved in thyroid hormone action on brain excitability. This study aimed to investigate the mechanisms involved in the effect of triiodothyronine (T3) hormone on brain excitability. Through electrophysiological experiments using rat hippocampal slices, we found that T3 treatment led to increased neuronal excitability, manifested by a reduction in current thresholds for action potential generation. This effect was mediated by enhancement of glutamatergic synaptic transmission, as evidenced by an increase in the amplitude and frequency of spontaneous excitatory synaptic currents. Moreover, T3 treatment resulted in upregulation of glutamate receptors, particularly N-methyl-D-aspartate receptors. These findings suggest that T3 hormone modulates brain excitability through its effects on glutamatergic neurotransmission. Importantly, our results shed light on the potential involvement of thyroid hormone dysregulation in the pathophysiology of neurological disorders characterized by altered brain excitability, highlighting new avenues for therapeutic interventions targeting the thyroid hormone system.

Mucocele of the cystic duct remnant in eight liver transplant recipients: findings at cholangiography, CT, and US.  The case histories and radiologic studies of eight liver transplant recipients who developed a mucocele of the allograft cystic duct remnant were retrospectively evaluated. We retrospectively evaluated the case histories and radiologic studies of eight liver transplant recipients who developed a mucocele of the allograft cystic duct remnant. Cholangiography, CT, and US were used for assessment. The mean age of the recipients was 49 +/- 12.3 years. At the time of diagnosis, the mean post-transplant period was 47 +/- 32.5 months. All patients presented with right upper quadrant pain, and three also had jaundice. Cholangiography demonstrated dilatation of the cystic duct remnant, while CT and US showed a localized cystic lesion. Treatment involved surgical removal of the mucocele in all cases. No complications or recurrences were observed during the follow-up period, which averaged 30.6 +/- 18.4 months. In liver transplant recipients, a mucocele of the allograft cystic duct remnant is a rare but important complication that can be effectively diagnosed and managed using cholangiography, CT, and US.

Ascites revealing peritoneal and hepatic extramedullary hematopoiesis with peliosis in agnogenic myeloid metaplasia: case report and review of the literature. This case report presents a rare finding of ascites revealing peritoneal and hepatic extramedullary hematopoiesis with peliosis in a patient with agnogenic myeloid metaplasia (AMM). A 52-year-old male with AMM presented with abdominal pain and distension. Ascitic fluid analysis showed leukocytosis, erythrocytosis, and megakaryocytosis. Imaging studies revealed multiple complex cystic lesions in the liver. Histological examination of the liver and peritoneal biopsy confirmed the presence of extramedullary hematopoiesis with peliotic changes. This finding suggests that peliosis may represent a possible complication of extramedullary hematopoiesis in patients with AMM. To our knowledge, this is the first case report documenting such an association. Recognition of this rare complication is important for appropriate management of patients with AMM. Further research is warranted to better understand the underlying pathogenesis and clinical implications of this finding.

Closed heart cryoablation of the His bundle using an anterior septal approach.  His bundle cryosurgical ablation using a closed heart anterior septal approach was used in 6 patients. This study describes the use of closed heart cryoablation of the His bundle using an anterior septal approach in 6 patients. Cryosurgical ablation of the His bundle is a technique used to treat certain cardiac arrhythmias. The anterior septal approach involves accessing the His bundle through the septum of the heart. The procedure was performed successfully in all patients, resulting in effective ablation of the His bundle and subsequent improvement in cardiac rhythm. This technique offers a minimally invasive alternative to surgical ablation and may be a viable option for patients with certain arrhythmias. Further research and larger studies are needed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this procedure.

Dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome induced by a cerebellopontine angle meningioma. Cerebellopontine angle meningiomas are known to cause various neurological symptoms due to their proximity to cranial nerves. We present a case of a 45-year-old female who presented with dysgeusia (distorted taste sensation), gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome due to a large cerebellopontine angle meningioma. Dysgeusia, characterized by a metallic or bitter taste in the mouth, was a persistent symptom in our patient. Gustatory sweating, defined as sweating during eating or tasting food, was also observed. Crocodile tears syndrome, characterized by lacrimation during eating, was evident in our patient. Neurological examination and magnetic resonance imaging revealed the presence of a large meningioma compressing the facial and glossopharyngeal nerves. Surgical resection of the tumor led to resolution of the gustatory symptoms, although a persistent metallic taste sensation persisted. This case highlights the rare presentation of dysgeusia, gustatory sweating, and crocodile tears syndrome induced by a cerebellopontine angle meningioma and emphasizes the importance of considering these symptoms in the diagnostic work-up of patients with cranial nerve lesions.

Esophageal involvement in pemphigus vulgaris: a clinical, histologic, and immunopathologic study. This study aimed to investigate the clinical, histologic, and immunopathologic features of esophageal involvement in pemphigus vulgaris (PV). A total of 40 patients diagnosed with PV were included in the study. Esophageal biopsies were taken from all patients, and histologic and immunopathologic analyses were performed. The results showed that esophageal involvement was present in 80% of the patients. Histologic examination revealed acantholysis and intraepithelial vesicles in the esophageal mucosa. Immunofluorescence studies demonstrated deposition of immunoglobulin G and complement C3 in the intercellular spaces of the esophageal epithelium. These findings indicate that esophageal involvement is common in patients with PV and is characterized by similar histologic and immunopathologic features observed in cutaneous lesions. Timely recognition and management of esophageal involvement is crucial in the overall management of PV.

Amyloidosis associated bleeding diatheses in the surgical patient. Amyloidosis is a rare disorder characterized by the deposition of abnormal proteins in tissues and organs, leading to their dysfunction. In surgical patients with amyloidosis, bleeding diatheses can present a significant challenge, as these patients are at increased risk of bleeding complications. This study aimed to evaluate the prevalence and management of bleeding diatheses associated with amyloidosis in surgical patients. A retrospective analysis was conducted on surgical patients with a confirmed diagnosis of amyloidosis and bleeding complications. The results showed that bleeding diatheses were present in a considerable number of surgical patients with amyloidosis, and various bleeding manifestations were observed, including gastrointestinal and intraoperative bleeding. Prophylactic measures, such as the administration of tranexamic acid and the use of mechanical hemostatic devices, were found to be effective in controlling bleeding. Overall, this study highlights the importance of early recognition and appropriate management of bleeding diatheses in surgical patients with amyloidosis.

Portal vein resection with a new antithrombogenic catheter. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a new antithrombogenic catheter during portal vein resection surgery. A total of 100 patients undergoing this procedure were included in the study. The new catheter was compared to a conventional catheter in terms of preventing postoperative complications related to portal vein thrombosis. The results showed that patients who received the new catheter had a significantly lower incidence of postoperative complications compared to those who received the conventional catheter (p<0.05). Furthermore, the new catheter was found to be effective in preventing portal vein thrombosis, with a thrombosis rate of only 5% compared to 15% in the conventional catheter group. These findings suggest that the use of the new antithrombogenic catheter during portal vein resection surgery can improve patient outcomes by reducing postoperative complications related to thrombosis. Further studies with larger sample sizes are warranted to confirm these results.

Refractory hypoglycemia secondary to topical salicylate intoxication.  We describe a case of severe refractory hypoglycemia secondary to topical salicylate intoxication. We present a case of a patient who developed severe refractory hypoglycemia due to topical salicylate intoxication. The patient had applied a large amount of an over-the-counter salicylate-containing cream to his skin for relief of muscle pain. Despite aggressive glucose management, the hypoglycemia persisted and required high doses of dextrose infusion. The patient eventually recovered after discontinuation of the salicylate cream and initiation of supportive care. This case highlights the potential for severe hypoglycemia with topical salicylate use and emphasizes the importance of considering salicylate intoxication in the differential diagnosis of refractory hypoglycemia. Clinicians should be aware of this rare but serious complication, especially in patients using topical salicylate products for extended periods.

Gastrointestinal disease and oral contraception. Gastrointestinal disease is a well-known side effect of oral contraception, but the specific relationship between the two remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate the association between oral contraceptive use and the prevalence of gastrointestinal disease. A cross-sectional study was conducted in a sample of 500 women aged 18-45 who were using oral contraception for at least 6 months. Gastrointestinal symptoms were assessed through a structured questionnaire, and further diagnostic investigations were performed as necessary. The results showed a significantly higher prevalence of gastrointestinal disease in the oral contraceptive group compared to a control group of non-users. Specifically, increased rates of irritable bowel syndrome and gastroesophageal reflux disease were observed. The findings suggest a potential association between oral contraception and gastrointestinal disease, warranting further research to better understand the underlying mechanisms and to inform clinical management.

Desensitization in the management of vancomycin hypersensitivity.  Vancomycin is the preferred antimicrobial agent in the treatment of methicillin-resistant staphylococcal infections. Vancomycin hypersensitivity is a significant concern in the clinical management of methicillin-resistant staphylococcal infections, as vancomycin is the preferred antimicrobial agent for this condition. This paper aims to explore the effectiveness of desensitization as a strategy for managing vancomycin hypersensitivity. A retrospective analysis was conducted to evaluate the outcomes of patients with documented vancomycin hypersensitivity who underwent desensitization at our institution. The desensitization protocol involved a graded intravenous infusion of vancomycin with close monitoring for adverse reactions. A total of 26 patients were included in the analysis, with a median age of 54 years. Results showed that desensitization was successful in 23 out of 26 patients (88%) without major adverse events. Furthermore, the majority of patients (77%) were able to complete their vancomycin treatment course following desensitization. These findings suggest that desensitization can be a safe and effective strategy in managing vancomycin hypersensitivity, enabling patients to receive adequate treatment for methicillin-resistant staphylococcal infections. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these results and establish standardized desensitization protocols.

Admissions to the intensive care unit after complications of anaesthetic techniques over 10 years.  2. Over a 10-year period, admissions to the intensive care unit (ICU) following complications of different anaesthetic techniques were examined. A retrospective analysis was performed on 463 patients who experienced complications related to anaesthesia, resulting in ICU admission. The most common complications leading to ICU admission were respiratory events (51.4%), followed by cardiovascular events (32.8%) and neurological events (15.8%). The most frequent respiratory events were hypoxemia (24.1%) and respiratory failure (21.2%). Cardiovascular events included hypotension (16.7%) and cardiac arrest (9.1%), while neurological events mainly consisted of seizures (10.3%) and stroke (4.1%). The majority of patients required mechanical ventilation (63.1%) and vasopressor support (48.4%) during their ICU stay. This study highlights the importance of recognizing and managing anaesthetic complications promptly to improve patient outcomes and reduce ICU admissions.

The epithelial changes associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva: a review of the clinical, histological and viral findings in 78 women. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common malignancy of the vulva. The aim of this study was to review the clinical, histological, and viral findings associated with SCC of the vulva in a cohort of 78 women. We found that the majority of women presented with pruritus and an ulcerative lesion. Histologically, most cases were well-differentiated SCC. Furthermore, high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) was detected in a significant proportion of cases. These findings highlight the importance of early detection, thorough histological examination, and consideration of HPV as a potential etiological factor in SCC of the vulva.

Total parathyroidectomy and autotransplantation in hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland. Hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland is a common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism. Total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation is an effective treatment option for patients with this condition. A retrospective study was conducted to assess the outcomes of this surgical intervention in 45 patients with hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland. All patients underwent total parathyroidectomy, with four gland autotransplantation. The follow-up period ranged from 6 months to 10 years. Calcium and parathyroid hormone levels were monitored preoperatively and postoperatively. The results showed that total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation effectively normalized calcium and parathyroid hormone levels in the majority of patients. However, a small percentage of patients experienced postoperative complications, including transient hypoparathyroidism and recurrent hyperparathyroidism. In conclusion, total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation is a viable treatment option for hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland, but careful monitoring is necessary to ensure optimal outcomes.

Absence of acetylcholine-induced current in epithelial cells from thymus glands and thymomas of myasthenia gravis patients. Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue. The thymus gland has been implicated in the pathogenesis of MG, specifically in the production of autoantibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR) on muscle cells. This study aimed to investigate the presence of acetylcholine-induced current in epithelial cells from thymus glands and thymomas of MG patients. Epithelial cells were isolated from thymus specimens of MG patients who underwent thymectomy or thymothymectomy and were compared to controls without MG. Patch-clamp recordings were performed to assess the acetylcholine-induced current. The results showed an absence of acetylcholine-induced current in epithelial cells from both thymus glands and thymomas of MG patients, indicating a functional impairment in AChR signaling. These findings suggest that the absence of acetylcholine-induced current in thymic epithelial cells may contribute to the development and perpetuation of MG by disrupting immune regulation and potentially leading to the production of autoantibodies against AChR. Further studies are warranted to explore the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets related to this phenomenon in MG.

The technicon H6000 analyzer discriminates chronic lymphocytic leukemia from other B-cell leukemias through automatic assessment of large unstained cells. The ability to accurately distinguish chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) from other B-cell leukemias is crucial for proper diagnosis and treatment. We evaluated the performance of the technicon H6000 analyzer in discriminating CLL from other B-cell leukemias by automatically assessing large unstained cells (LUCs). A total of 75 patients with confirmed B-cell leukemia were included in the study. The technicon H6000 analyzer accurately identified CLL in 65 out of 75 patients, resulting in a sensitivity of 86.7%. The specificity was 100%, as no false positives were observed. The automated assessment of LUCs by the technicon H6000 analyzer showed promise in differentiating CLL from other B-cell leukemias, providing a rapid and reliable diagnostic tool for clinicians. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and assess the performance in larger patient cohorts.

Attachment of bacteria to tonsillar epithelium during acute tonsillitis. Acute tonsillitis is a common upper respiratory infection that often results in the attachment of bacteria to the tonsillar epithelium. This process is believed to be a crucial step in the pathogenesis of the disease. However, the mechanisms by which bacterial adhesion occurs during acute tonsillitis are not well understood. In this study, we investigated the attachment of bacteria to the tonsillar epithelium in patients with acute tonsillitis. Our results showed that several bacterial species, including Streptococcus pyogenes and Haemophilus influenzae, were able to attach to the tonsillar epithelium. Furthermore, we found that the attachment of bacteria was mediated by specific adhesion molecules present on the surface of the epithelial cells. These findings provide valuable insights into the pathogenesis of acute tonsillitis and may have implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies to prevent and treat this common infection.

Recovery from disturbed colonic transit time after alcohol withdrawal.  The effects of alcohol withdrawal on total and segmental transit time were evaluated in 20 chronic alcoholic subjects.  After withdrawal, colorectal transit time significantly increased from 24. This study aimed to investigate the recovery of colonic transit time after alcohol withdrawal in chronic alcoholic subjects. Twenty individuals who were dependent on alcohol participated in the study. Total and segmental transit time of the colorectal region were assessed before and after alcohol withdrawal. The results showed a significant increase in colorectal transit time following alcohol withdrawal, compared to the initial measurement of 24. Further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms and potential interventions for restoring normal colonic transit time in individuals recovering from alcohol addiction.

Role of tolerance in cloxacillin treatment of experimental Staphylococcus aureus endocarditis. Cloxacillin is a commonly used treatment for Staphylococcus aureus endocarditis; however, its efficacy may be hindered by the development of tolerance. This study aimed to investigate the role of tolerance in cloxacillin treatment. Experimental endocarditis was induced in rabbits, and they were then treated with cloxacillin for 10 days. Tolerance was assessed by comparing the efficacy of cloxacillin against infective endocarditis caused by low-level oxacillin-resistant strains of S. aureus versus susceptible strains. Results showed that rabbits infected with susceptible strains had a significantly lower mortality rate compared to those infected with resistant strains. Additionally, bacterial counts in vegetations were significantly lower in animals infected with susceptible strains. These findings indicate that tolerance to cloxacillin occurs in S. aureus endocarditis and may have significant clinical implications. Further studies are needed to understand the mechanisms underlying this tolerance.

Management of local and regional recurrence after mastectomy or breast-conserving treatment. Management of local and regional recurrence after mastectomy or breast-conserving treatment is a critical aspect of breast cancer care. Local recurrence, defined as the reappearance of cancer in the breast or chest wall after initial treatment, can occur in up to 30% of patients. Regional recurrence, involving the lymph nodes in the axilla or supraclavicular region, further complicates the management strategy. Treatment options vary based on factors such as tumor characteristics, previous treatment modalities, and patient preference. Surgical intervention, including re-excision or lymph node dissection, is often required in combination with adjuvant therapies such as radiation therapy or systemic chemotherapy. Close monitoring and regular follow-up are crucial for early detection and prompt intervention. Multidisciplinary collaboration between surgeons, oncologists, radiation therapists, and pathologists is essential to tailor individualized treatment plans and optimize patient outcomes.

Doppler color-flow images from a stenosed arterial model: interpretation of flow patterns. Doppler color-flow imaging is a noninvasive technique used to assess blood flow patterns in stenosed arteries. In this study, we present and interpret the flow patterns observed in a simulated stenosed arterial model using this technique. The model consisted of a tube with a partial occlusion, mimicking stenosis in the arterial lumen. Doppler color-flow images were acquired at various locations upstream and downstream of the stenosis. Analysis of the images revealed distinct flow patterns, including turbulent flow, jet flow, and recirculation zones. These patterns were dependent on the degree of stenosis and the velocity of blood flow. Understanding these flow patterns is crucial for the accurate diagnosis and management of arterial stenosis. Doppler color-flow imaging provides valuable insights into the hemodynamic changes associated with stenosis, aiding in the assessment of disease severity and guiding treatment decisions. Further research and refinement of this imaging technique are warranted to improve its clinical utility in the diagnosis of arterial stenosis.

Primary solid neoplasms of the greater omentum.  Primary solid tumors of the greater omentum are rare, with only 42 reported cases. This study reports on 42 cases of primary solid tumors located in the greater omentum, a rare occurrence. The majority of these tumors were found incidentally during surgery for unrelated conditions. The most common presenting symptom was abdominal pain, followed by a palpable abdominal mass. The mean age at diagnosis was 58 years, and the female to male ratio was 2:1. Histologically, the tumors were classified as sarcomas in 45% of cases, carcinomas in 24%, and stromal tumors in 12%. The remaining cases were categorized as lymphomas, melanomas, or germ cell tumors. Surgical resection was the primary treatment modality, often combined with adjuvant chemotherapy or radiation therapy. The overall prognosis was poor, with a high incidence of local recurrence and distant metastasis. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management of these rare tumors.

Prediction of cognitive change as a function of preoperative ability status among temporal lobectomy patients seen at 6-month follow-up. The present study aimed to predict cognitive change in temporal lobectomy patients based on their preoperative ability status. Participants who underwent the surgery were assessed at a 6-month follow-up to determine any changes in cognitive functioning. Preoperative ability status was assessed using standardized neuropsychological tests. Multiple regression analysis was conducted to determine whether preoperative ability status could predict cognitive change at the 6-month follow-up. Results showed that preoperative ability status significantly predicted cognitive change, with higher preoperative ability associated with greater cognitive improvement ( = 0.35, p < 0.05). It was observed that patients with higher preoperative ability had better cognitive performance at the follow-up assessment. These findings suggest that preoperative cognitive abilities can serve as a valuable predictor of cognitive outcomes in temporal lobectomy patients. Further research is needed to explore other factors that may influence cognitive change post-surgery.

Long-time survival of a patient with glioblastoma and Turcot's syndrome. We present a case of a 43-year-old male diagnosed with glioblastoma and Turcot's syndrome, a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the presence of multiple colorectal adenomas. Despite the poor prognosis associated with glioblastoma, this patient survived for an unusually long period of 9 years following diagnosis. The survival can be attributed to the patient's young age at diagnosis, aggressive surgical resection, and subsequent adjuvant chemotherapy and radiotherapy. Furthermore, the presence of Turcot's syndrome may have influenced the tumor's response to treatment, as certain genetic mutations associated with the syndrome have been shown to enhance sensitivity to chemotherapy. This exceptional case highlights the importance of individualized treatment approaches and further research into the underlying mechanisms of resistance and response in patients with glioblastoma and genetic syndromes.

Changes in surgical treatments: the example of hysterectomy versus conization for cervical carcinoma in situ.  From 1969 through 1985, 4584 women in the state of New Mexico were diagnosed with carcinoma in situ of the cervix. From 1969 to 1985, a total of 4584 women in New Mexico were diagnosed with cervical carcinoma in situ. This study examines changes in surgical treatments for this condition over that time period. Specifically, the study compares the use of hysterectomy versus conization. Hysterectomy involves the removal of the uterus, while conization involves removing a cone-shaped piece of tissue from the cervix. The study found a significant shift in surgical approach, with hysterectomy becoming the preferred treatment option by the end of the study period. This trend could be attributed to advances in surgical techniques and increasing awareness of the potential for progression to invasive cervical cancer in women with carcinoma in situ.

Gastroduodenal mucosa in uraemia: endoscopic and histological correlation and prevalence of helicobacter-like organisms.  This study aimed to determine the prevalence of endoscopic and histological gastroduodenitis as well as helicobacter-like organisms in patients with end stage renal failure undergoing maintenance dialysis treatment. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence of gastroduodenitis, including endoscopic and histological findings, as well as the presence of helicobacter-like organisms in patients with end stage renal failure undergoing maintenance dialysis treatment. A total of 80 patients were enrolled in the study. Endoscopic examination revealed gastroduodenitis in 56 patients (70%), with antral involvement being the most common finding. Histological analysis confirmed the diagnosis of gastroduodenitis in 46 patients (57.5%), with chronic inflammation being the predominant finding. Helicobacter-like organisms were detected in 38 patients (47.5%). There was a significant correlation between endoscopic and histological findings (p<0.001) as well as between the presence of helicobacter-like organisms and histological diagnosis of gastritis (p=0.012). These findings highlight the high prevalence of gastroduodenitis and the potential role of helicobacter-like organisms in patients with end stage renal failure undergoing maintenance dialysis treatment.

Arterial oxygen desaturation during gastrointestinal endoscopy This prospective study evaluated the incidence and severity of arterial oxygen desaturation during gastrointestinal endoscopy. This prospective study aimed to assess the occurrence and seriousness of arterial oxygen desaturation during gastrointestinal endoscopy. A total of [number] patients undergoing endoscopy were included in the study. Results revealed that [percentage] of patients experienced arterial oxygen desaturation during the procedure, with [percentage] of those presenting with severe desaturation levels. Factors associated with increased risk of desaturation included older age, presence of comorbidities, and longer procedure duration. Furthermore, patients who experienced desaturation were more likely to exhibit symptoms such as dizziness, shortness of breath, and fatigue during and after the procedure. Prompt management of desaturation events, including supplemental oxygen administration, was effective in resolving symptoms and preventing adverse outcomes. These findings highlight the importance of close monitoring and adequate oxygenation during gastrointestinal endoscopy to ensure patient safety. Further research is required to identify additional risk factors and optimize preventive strategies for minimizing arterial oxygen desaturation in this setting.

The development of infratentorial atrophy in patients with idiopathic cerebellar ataxia of late onset: a CT study. This study aimed to investigate the development of infratentorial atrophy in patients with idiopathic cerebellar ataxia of late onset (ILOCA) using CT imaging. CT scans of the brain were obtained from 30 patients with ILOCA and 30 age- and sex-matched healthy controls. The degree of infratentorial atrophy was quantitatively assessed using a validated rating scale. The results showed a significant increase in infratentorial atrophy scores in patients with ILOCA compared to controls (mean score 2.7 vs. 0.6, p < 0.001). Furthermore, the severity of atrophy correlated with the duration and progression of ataxia symptoms in the patient group (p < 0.05). These findings suggest that infratentorial atrophy is a common feature in patients with ILOCA and may be related to disease progression. CT imaging could be a valuable tool for monitoring disease progression and assessing treatment efficacy in this patient population.

Imaging the gallbladder: a historical perspective.  After Wilhelm Conrad Roentgen's discovery of the X-ray in 1895, it was initially thought that gallstones could not be visualized. This historical perspective review examines the imaging of the gallbladder following Wilhelm Conrad Roentgen's discovery of the X-ray in 1895. Initially, it was believed that gallstones could not be visualized using this new technology. However, subsequent advancements in radiography, including the introduction of contrast agents and cholecystography, allowed for the visualization of gallstones and the identification of gallbladder pathology. Advancements in ultrasound technology further improved the imaging of the gallbladder, allowing for non-invasive and real-time visualization. The development of endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) has further enhanced the ability to diagnose and stage gallbladder carcinoma. This historical perspective highlights the progression of imaging techniques for the gallbladder and their impact on diagnosis and treatment.

Nosocomial infections due to Xanthomonas maltophilia (Pseudomonas maltophilia) in patients with cancer.  From December 1985 to May 1986, Xanthomonas maltophilia (formerly known as Pseudomonas maltophilia) was isolated at an increased rate at our institution; 52 isolates of X. Nosocomial infections due to Xanthomonas maltophilia, also known as Pseudomonas maltophilia, pose a significant concern in cancer patients. This study investigates the occurrence of X. maltophilia infections in cancer patients at our institution from December 1985 to May 1986. A total of 52 isolates of X. maltophilia were identified during this period, representing an increased rate of isolation. These infections were likely acquired within the healthcare setting, as X. maltophilia is known to be a common hospital-acquired pathogen. Cancer patients are particularly vulnerable to these infections due to their compromised immune systems. Therefore, strict infection control measures should be implemented to prevent and manage nosocomial infections caused by X. maltophilia in cancer patients. Further research is warranted to explore effective treatment strategies for these infections.

Hypertension during pregnancy in insulin-dependent diabetic women. Pregnant women with insulin-dependent diabetes are at higher risk for hypertension during pregnancy. In a retrospective study of 256 diabetic women, the incidence of hypertension was examined. The study showed that 38% of women developed hypertension during pregnancy, with the majority experiencing gestational hypertension rather than chronic hypertension. Additionally, women who had preexisting hypertension were more likely to have poor glucose control during pregnancy. Furthermore, women with preexisting hypertension had a higher incidence of preterm delivery and intrauterine growth restriction compared to those without hypertension. These findings indicate that hypertension is a common complication in insulin-dependent diabetic women during pregnancy and is associated with poor glucose control and adverse pregnancy outcomes. Therefore, close monitoring and management of blood pressure and glucose control are essential in this population to optimize maternal and fetal outcomes.

Optimal escort for interhospital transport of pediatric emergencies. Interhospital transport of pediatric emergencies requires optimal escort to ensure patient safety and to provide appropriate medical care during the transfer. This study aimed to evaluate the impact of different escort models on the outcomes of interhospital transport in pediatric emergencies. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 250 pediatric patients who were transferred between hospitals for emergency care. Four escort models were compared: physician-led, nurse-led, paramedic-led, and non-medical personnel-led. The primary outcomes measured were transport time, adverse events during transport, and patient outcomes. The results showed that the physician-led escort model had the shortest transport time and the lowest rate of adverse events during transport. Furthermore, patients escorted by physicians had significantly better outcomes compared to other escort models. These findings suggest that a physician-led escort model is the optimal approach for interhospital transport of pediatric emergencies, as it can ensure timely and safe transfer while providing appropriate medical care. Further research is needed to validate these results and explore other factors influencing escort models for pediatric interhospital transport.

Relative effects of brain and non-brain injuries on neuropsychological and psychosocial outcome. This study aimed to investigate the relative effects of brain and non-brain injuries on neuropsychological and psychosocial outcomes in individuals with traumatic injuries. A total of 100 participants were included in the study, with 50 having brain injuries and 50 having non-brain injuries. Neuropsychological and psychosocial assessments were conducted at multiple time points up to five years post-injury. Results showed that individuals with brain injuries exhibited significantly lower cognitive functioning and poorer psychosocial outcomes compared to those with non-brain injuries. Additionally, the severity of brain injury was found to be directly related to the extent of impairment in both neuropsychological and psychosocial domains. These findings suggest that brain injuries have a more detrimental impact on cognitive functioning and psychosocial well-being compared to non-brain injuries. Early and targeted interventions should be implemented to optimize outcomes in individuals with brain injuries.

Intraoperative ultrasonography and the detection of liver metastases in patients with colorectal cancer. This study aimed to evaluate the usefulness of intraoperative ultrasonography (IOUS) in detecting liver metastases in patients with colorectal cancer. A total of 128 patients undergoing colorectal cancer surgery were included in the study. IOUS was performed during surgery to assess the presence of liver metastases. The results of IOUS were compared to preoperative imaging and postoperative histopathological examination. IOUS had a sensitivity of 87% and specificity of 98% in detecting liver metastases. In addition, IOUS was able to identify additional liver lesions missed by preoperative imaging. The use of IOUS during surgery can therefore aid in the accurate detection of liver metastases and improve surgical outcomes in patients with colorectal cancer.

Subscapular elastofibroma in a young pitcher.  A case report. Elastofibroma is a rare, benign soft tissue tumor typically found in the subscapular region of elderly individuals. We present a case report of a 26-year-old pitcher who developed a subscapular elastofibroma. The patient presented with a painless, firm mass in the left scapular region that had been gradually increasing in size for several years. Imaging studies confirmed the presence of a well-defined, heavily calcified subscapular mass. Surgical excision of the tumor was performed, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of elastofibroma. Postoperatively, the patient experienced complete resolution of symptoms and returned to full participation in sports within six months. This case highlights the importance of considering elastofibroma as a differential diagnosis in young individuals presenting with a mass in the subscapular region.

Photodynamic therapy with chloroaluminum-sulfonated phthalocyanine. Photodynamic therapy (PDT) using chloroaluminum-sulfonated phthalocyanine (CASPc) has emerged as a potential treatment modality for various malignancies. This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of CASPc PDT in the management of superficial and nodular skin cancers. A total of 75 patients with biopsy-proven basal cell carcinoma (BCC) or squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) were included. CASPc was topically applied to the tumor, followed by activation with red light. Clinical response, adverse events, and recurrence rates were assessed. After a median follow-up of 12 months, the overall response rate was 90.7%, with complete response observed in 80% of patients. Adverse events were mostly mild and transient. Recurrence occurred in 11 patients (14.7%). CASPc PDT appears to be a safe and effective treatment option for superficial and nodular skin cancers, offering high response rates and low recurrence rates. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings and optimize treatment protocols.

Laparoscopic guided cholecystectomy. Laparoscopic guided cholecystectomy has become the standard surgical approach for the treatment of symptomatic gallstones. This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of laparoscopic guided cholecystectomy in a cohort of patients. A total of 100 patients with symptomatic gallstones underwent laparoscopic guided cholecystectomy. The mean age of the patients was 52 years, with a female predominance (78%). The surgery was successfully completed in all cases, with an average operating time of 90 minutes. Postoperative complications occurred in 8% of patients, including wound infection and bile leakage. None of the patients required conversion to open surgery. The mean length of hospital stay was 2 days. Symptoms significantly improved after surgery, with a decrease in pain and resolution of biliary colic. Patient satisfaction was high, with 95% reporting improvement in their quality of life. In conclusion, laparoscopic guided cholecystectomy is a safe and effective procedure for the treatment of symptomatic gallstones, providing symptom relief and improved quality of life for patients. Further studies are needed to evaluate long-term outcomes and compare different surgical techniques.

Sudden death caused by coronary artery aneurysms: a late complication of Kawasaki disease. Sudden death resulting from coronary artery aneurysms is a rare but serious complication of Kawasaki disease. Although this condition primarily affects children, it can also occur in adults. The pathogenesis of coronary artery aneurysms in Kawasaki disease is not fully understood, but it is thought to involve immune-mediated inflammation. Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment with intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin can reduce the risk of developing coronary artery aneurysms. However, in some cases, these aneurysms may progress and lead to sudden death due to myocardial infarction or rupture. Close monitoring and timely intervention are crucial in managing patients with Kawasaki disease to prevent these devastating complications.

Differentiation of ventricular tachyarrhythmias. Differentiating between different types of ventricular tachyarrhythmias is crucial for appropriate management and treatment. This study aimed to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of several electrocardiographic parameters in distinguishing between monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT), polymorphic VT, and ventricular fibrillation (VF).

A total of 220 patients with documented ventricular tachyarrhythmias were included in the study. Various electrocardiographic parameters, including QRS duration, QT interval, T wave amplitude, and presence of fusion beats, were analyzed. 

The results showed that QRS duration was the most useful parameter in differentiating between monomorphic VT and polymorphic VT/VF. A cut-off value of 140 ms had a sensitivity of 78% and a specificity of 90% in distinguishing between these two arrhythmias. 

Additionally, the presence of fusion beats was highly specific for monomorphic VT, with a specificity of 95%. T wave amplitude and QT interval did not significantly contribute to the differentiation of ventricular tachyarrhythmias.

In conclusion, QRS duration and the presence of fusion beats are valuable parameters in differentiating between monomorphic VT, polymorphic VT, and VF. These findings can aid clinicians in making accurate diagnoses and implementing appropriate treatment strategies.

Antenatal spontaneous perforation of the extrahepatic biliary tree. Antenatal spontaneous perforation of the extrahepatic biliary tree is a rare condition characterized by the rupture of the biliary system before birth. This case report describes a newborn female who presented with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. Imaging studies revealed large peritoneal fluid collections, and subsequent exploration identified a perforation in the extrahepatic bile duct. The perforation was repaired, and the patient recovered well postoperatively. This case emphasizes the importance of considering antenatal spontaneous biliary perforation as a differential diagnosis in cases of neonatal abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. Early diagnosis and surgical intervention can lead to favorable outcomes for these patients. Further research is needed to better understand the etiology and optimal management of this condition.

Dystrophin analysis in Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy carriers: correlation with intracellular calcium and albumin. This study investigated the correlation between dystrophin analysis and intracellular calcium and albumin levels in carriers of Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy. Nine carriers (age range, 22-52 years) were included in the study. Muscle biopsies were analyzed for dystrophin expression using immunohistochemistry, and intracellular calcium levels were measured using a fluorescent calcium indicator. Serum albumin levels were also determined. Results showed a significant correlation between dystrophin expression and intracellular calcium levels (p<0.05). Additionally, a positive correlation was observed between dystrophin expression and serum albumin levels (p<0.01). These findings suggest that intracellular calcium and serum albumin may be useful markers for evaluating disease progression and therapeutic interventions in carriers of Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy. Further studies are needed to explore this relationship in larger cohorts.

Lateral deviation of the eyes on forced lid closure in patients with cerebral lesions. Forced lid closure and subsequent lateral deviation of the eyes has been observed in patients with cerebral lesions. This phenomenon has not been well documented or understood. We conducted a study to investigate this clinical sign and its association with cerebral lesions. We analyzed the medical records of 100 patients with cerebral lesions who exhibited forced lid closure during physical examination. We found that 78% of these patients also showed lateral deviation of the eyes towards the side of the cerebral lesion. This abnormal eye movement was more frequently observed in patients with lesions involving the frontal and parietal lobes. Our findings suggest that lateral deviation of the eyes on forced lid closure may serve as a potential diagnostic and prognostic indicator for cerebral lesions. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and clinical implications of this phenomenon.

Small bile duct abnormalities in sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, including the liver. In this study, the authors examined the presence of small bile duct abnormalities in patients with sarcoidosis. Liver biopsies were performed on 62 patients with sarcoidosis, and bile duct abnormalities were observed in 10 patients (16.1%). These abnormalities included bile duct wall thickening, periductal fibrosis, and bile ductular proliferation. Interestingly, none of the patients had clinical symptoms or laboratory evidence of liver dysfunction. The authors conclude that small bile duct abnormalities are a common finding in sarcoidosis, even in the absence of liver dysfunction, suggesting that these abnormalities may be a manifestation of the systemic inflammatory process. Further studies are needed to better understand the clinical significance of these findings.

Extramammary Paget's disease of the bronchial epithelium. Extramammary Paget's disease (EMPD) is a rare neoplastic disorder that typically affects the skin and mucous membranes. Here we report a case of EMPD involving the bronchial epithelium, which is an extremely rare manifestation of this disease. The patient presented with symptoms of chronic bronchitis and was found to have abnormal bronchoscopic findings, leading to the diagnosis of EMPD. Histological examination confirmed the presence of Paget cells, characterized by large, round cells with abundant clear cytoplasm and centrally located nuclei. Immunohistochemical staining for cytokeratin stains provided further confirmation of the diagnosis. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported case of EMPD involving the bronchial epithelium.

Wilson's disease: 35 years' experience.  Thirty-seven Chinese patients fulfilling the criteria for Wilson's disease seen during a 35-year period were reviewed. We conducted a retrospective review of 37 Chinese patients with Wilson's disease over a 35-year period to evaluate their clinical characteristics and outcomes. The mean age at diagnosis was 18.4 years, with a slight male predominance. The majority of patients presented with hepatocellular dysfunction, neurological symptoms, or a combination of both. Kayser-Fleischer rings were observed in 78.4% of cases. Liver biopsy showed hepatic copper accumulation in all patients. Treatment with D-penicillamine resulted in clinical improvement in most cases. However, 2 patients progressed to liver failure and underwent liver transplantation. Our study highlights the importance of early diagnosis and appropriate treatment in improving outcomes for patients with Wilson's disease.

Treatment of manifest and impending pathologic fractures of the femoral neck by cemented hemiarthroplasty.  Thirty-four patients with manifest or impending pathologic fractures of the femoral neck were treated between 1971 and 1987. Between 1971 and 1987, thirty-four patients with manifest or impending pathologic fractures of the femoral neck were treated using cemented hemiarthroplasty. All fractures were related to primary or metastatic tumors, and the patients' mean age was 46 years. The majority of fractures were impending fractures with evidence of cortical thinning or a radiolucent line on X-ray. Immediate pain relief was achieved in all patients after surgery, and no intraoperative or immediate postoperative complications were noted. One patient required a revision arthroplasty due to premature loosening of the cement. There were no cases of intraoperative or postoperative fractures. Overall, cemented hemiarthroplasty provided effective pain relief and stability in the treatment of manifest or impending pathologic fractures of the femoral neck caused by primary or metastatic tumors.

Implementation of cancer prevention guidelines in clinical practice.  Data from several sources, including consumer surveys, physician surveys, and medical record audits, indicate that consumers do not receive cancer screening tests as recommended by the National Cancer Institute, the American Cancer Society, and the U. Various sources of data, such as consumer surveys, physician surveys, and medical record audits, suggest that there is a lack of adherence to cancer prevention guidelines in clinical practice. Despite recommendations from reputable organizations like the National Cancer Institute and the American Cancer Society, studies show that consumers are not receiving cancer screening tests as recommended. This suggests a gap between guideline recommendations and their implementation in clinical settings. Efforts should be made to bridge this gap to ensure that patients receive appropriate cancer screening and preventive care. Further research is needed to identify barriers and develop effective strategies to improve the implementation of cancer prevention guidelines in clinical practice.

Longitudinal study of diagnoses in children of women with unipolar and bipolar affective disorder. This longitudinal study aimed to investigate the diagnoses observed in children of women with unipolar and bipolar affective disorder. A total of 321 children born to women with a history of affective disorders were followed up for an average of 9.2 years. The children were evaluated for psychiatric diagnoses using standardized assessments. The results showed that 50.5% of children had at least one psychiatric diagnosis, with the most common being attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and major depressive disorder. Children of women with bipolar affective disorder had a higher risk of developing bipolar disorder themselves compared to those born to women with unipolar disorder. The findings suggest the importance of early identification and intervention for children at risk.

Contracturing granulomatous myositis: a separate entity. Contracturing granulomatous myositis (CGM) is a rare inflammatory myopathy characterized by gradually progressive muscle weakness and contractures. We present a case series of five patients with CGM and provide a comprehensive analysis of their clinical, histopathological, and radiological features. All patients had symmetric proximal muscle weakness, joint contractures, and elevated muscle enzymes. Biopsies revealed granulomatous inflammation, fibrosis, and muscle fiber necrosis. Magnetic resonance imaging showed muscle atrophy and fatty infiltration. CGM was found to be distinct from other forms of inflammatory myopathies based on its unique clinical presentation and histopathological features. Treatment with immunosuppressants and physical therapy resulted in variable improvement in muscle strength and contractures. This case series highlights the importance of recognizing CGM as a separate entity in the spectrum of inflammatory myopathies, which can aid in timely diagnosis and appropriate management. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying pathogenesis and identify more effective treatment strategies for CGM.

Malignant glandular triton tumor. Malignant glandular triton tumor (MGTT) is a rare and aggressive subtype of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST) that exhibits divergent differentiation, including rhabdomyoblastic elements. This study presents a case report of a 52-year-old male patient who presented with a large retroperitoneal mass. Histological examination revealed a high-grade sarcomatous neoplasm with glandular and rhabdomyoblastic differentiation. Immunohistochemical studies confirmed positive staining for epithelial and muscle markers, supporting the diagnosis of MGTT. Further molecular analysis identified loss of heterozygosity in multiple loci, consistent with the tumor's malignant behavior. The patient underwent surgical resection followed by adjuvant chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Despite aggressive treatment, the patient experienced local recurrence and distant metastasis, ultimately succumbing to the disease. MGTT is a rare and challenging tumor with a poor prognosis, emphasizing the need for further understanding of its pathogenesis and development of effective treatment strategies.

Clinicopathologic and flow cytometric DNA study of medullary thyroid carcinoma.  Sixty-one patients with medullary thyroid carcinoma were investigated to establish relationships between the neoplasm's DNA content, other clinicopathologic factors, and patient survival (at least 5 years' follow-up). We conducted a clinicopathologic and flow cytometric DNA study on 61 patients with medullary thyroid carcinoma. Our aim was to determine the relationship between DNA content, clinicopathologic factors, and patient survival. Patients were followed up for at least 5 years. We found that DNA content did not correlate with age, sex, tumor size, or lymph node metastasis. However, a significant association was observed between DNA content and patient survival. Patients with higher DNA content had poorer survival outcomes compared to those with lower DNA content. These findings suggest that DNA content may serve as a prognostic marker for medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Complications of general anesthesia for Nd:YAG laser resection of endobronchial tumors.  We studied the incidence and mechanisms of cardiovascular complications and postoperative respiratory insufficiency associated with GA and Nd:YAG laser endobronchial tumor resection. This study aimed to investigate the occurrence and mechanisms of cardiovascular complications and postoperative respiratory insufficiency in patients undergoing general anesthesia (GA) for Nd:YAG laser resection of endobronchial tumors. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a group of patients who underwent this procedure. The results showed that cardiovascular complications occurred in 10% of the patients, with the majority being hypotension and arrhythmias. Respiratory insufficiency occurred in 15% of the patients, mainly due to bronchospasm and airway obstruction. The mechanisms underlying these complications were thought to be related to the effects of GA on cardiovascular and respiratory functions. The study highlights the importance of proper monitoring and management of cardiovascular stability and respiratory function during GA for Nd:YAG laser resection of endobronchial tumors to minimize the occurrence of complications.

Demonstration of the genuine iso-12p character of the standard marker chromosome of testicular germ cell tumors and identification of further chromosome 12 aberrations by competitive in situ hybridization. In this study, we investigated the nature of the standard marker chromosome in testicular germ cell tumors (TGCT) and identified additional chromosome 12 aberrations using competitive in situ hybridization (CISH). We confirmed that the standard marker chromosome in TGCT is a genuine iso-12p chromosome. By analyzing tumor samples from 54 patients, we detected various chromosome 12 aberrations, including losses, gains, and structural rearrangements. Our findings provide valuable insights into the genetic alterations associated with TGCT and highlight the potential of CISH as a useful tool for the identification of chromosomal abnormalities in this disease.

The failure of serial pneumatic cuff venous occlusion plethysmography to predict patients at risk for pulmonary emboli after trauma. Serial pneumatic cuff venous occlusion plethysmography is commonly used to predict patients at risk for pulmonary emboli after trauma. However, this study aimed to determine if this method had any limitations in accurately identifying patients at risk. The results of the study showed that there was no significant correlation between the measurements obtained through pneumatic cuff venous occlusion plethysmography and the presence of pulmonary emboli in trauma patients. This suggests that this method may not be reliable in predicting the risk of pulmonary emboli in this patient population. Further research is necessary to identify more accurate methods for assessing the risk of pulmonary emboli after trauma.

Pathological changes in levator palpebrae superioris muscle treated with botulinum toxin in a case of carotico-cavernous fistula. We report a case of carotico-cavernous fistula presenting with pathological changes in the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) muscle. A 48-year-old male patient presented with proptosis, periorbital edema, and diplopia following a traumatic car accident. Imaging studies confirmed the diagnosis of carotico-cavernous fistula. Botulinum toxin injections were administered to temporarily weaken the hyperactive LPS muscle, alleviating the patient's symptoms. Repeat imaging studies showed significant improvement in the fistula and resolution of the LPS muscle pathology. This case highlights the potential benefit of botulinum toxin in the management of carotico-cavernous fistula-associated LPS muscle pathology, offering a less invasive and reversible treatment option before considering surgical intervention. Further research is warranted to validate these findings.

Surgical complications of continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis.  Surgical experience with 260 consecutive patients with chronic renal failure receiving continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) at one medical center from 1980 to 1989 is reviewed. This study reviewed the surgical complications experienced by 260 consecutive patients with chronic renal failure who underwent continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) at a single medical center from 1980 to 1989. The incidence and types of complications were analyzed, including catheter-related problems, hernias, leaks, and infections. The overall complication rate was found to be 39% for catheter-related problems, 12% for hernias, and 5% for leaks. Infections occurred in 27% of patients, with peritonitis being the most common. Surgical intervention was required in 16% of cases. The study highlights the importance of recognizing and managing surgical complications associated with CAPD to optimize patient outcomes.

Botulinum A toxin for the treatment of adult-onset spasmodic torticollis. Adult-onset spasmodic torticollis is a debilitating condition characterized by abnormal head posture and muscle contractions in the neck muscles. The efficacy of botulinum A toxin in the treatment of this condition was evaluated in a prospective study involving 70 patients. Patients received botulinum A toxin injections into the affected muscles and were followed for a mean period of 2 years. Significant improvement in head posture and reduction in muscle spasms were observed in the majority of patients. The overall success rate was 80%, with a higher success rate seen in patients with shorter disease duration. Common adverse effects included temporary neck weakness and dysphagia. Botulinum A toxin appears to be a safe and effective treatment option for adult-onset spasmodic torticollis.

Carcinoma of the cervix: value of MR imaging in detecting parametrial involvement.  In patients with cervical carcinoma, precise knowledge of parametrial tumor extension affects the therapeutic decision between surgery and radiation therapy. MR imaging is a valuable tool in detecting parametrial involvement in patients with cervical carcinoma, as it provides precise knowledge of tumor extension. This knowledge is crucial in making the therapeutic decision between surgery and radiation therapy. A study was conducted to assess the value of MR imaging in detecting parametrial involvement in cervical carcinoma patients. The study included patients who underwent both MR imaging and surgery, and the results were compared. The findings showed a high sensitivity and specificity of MR imaging in detecting parametrial involvement, with an accuracy rate of 93%. These results indicate that MR imaging can be a reliable method for assessing parametrial involvement in cervical carcinoma patients, allowing for more accurate therapeutic decisions and improved patient outcomes. Further research is warranted to validate these findings and explore the potential of MR imaging in other aspects of cervical carcinoma management.

Noninvasive assessment of cardiac output in children using impedance cardiography.  This study evaluated the effect of intracardiac shunting on the accuracy of thoracic bioimpedance-derived cardiac output determinations. Intracardiac shunting can affect the accuracy of noninvasive cardiac output measurements obtained through thoracic bioimpedance. We conducted a study to evaluate this effect in children. Cardiac output was measured using thoracic bioimpedance in 54 children with varying degrees of intracardiac shunting, including 26 patients with right-to-left shunt and 28 patients with left-to-right shunt. The measurements were compared to cardiac output values obtained using a reference method. Our results showed that the presence of right-to-left shunting significantly underestimated cardiac output, while left-to-right shunting did not have a significant effect. The underestimation was more pronounced in patients with larger shunt fractions and in those with lower systemic vascular resistance. In conclusion, intracardiac shunting affects the accuracy of thoracic bioimpedance-derived cardiac output measurements in children. Clinicians should consider these factors when interpreting noninvasive cardiac output data in this population.

Spinal cord compression from a thoracic paraganglioma: case report. Spinal cord compression resulting from a thoracic paraganglioma is a rare occurrence. We report a case of a 45-year-old male who presented with progressive lower extremity weakness and urinary incontinence. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed an intradural tumor at the T9 level causing severe spinal cord compression. Surgical resection of the tumor was performed, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of a paraganglioma. Postoperatively, the patient's neurological deficits improved significantly. Paragangliomas are neuroendocrine tumors arising from paraganglia, which are primarily located in the carotid body and adrenal medulla. However, they can also occur in other locations, such as the spine. Spinal paragangliomas are extremely rare and tend to present with symptoms of spinal cord compression. Early recognition and prompt surgical intervention are crucial to prevent permanent neurological damage. Therefore, clinicians should consider spinal paraganglioma as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with progressive neurological deficits and perform appropriate imaging studies for early detection and management.

Is emotional disturbance a precipitator or a consequence of chronic pain? The present study examined the relationship between psychological factors and pain in order to assess the contribution of emotional disturbance to the perpetuation of pain. This study aimed to investigate the relationship between psychological factors and chronic pain to determine whether emotional disturbance is a cause or a consequence of pain persistence. The study included a sample of individuals with chronic pain and assessed various psychological factors such as anxiety, depression, and stress levels. Results showed a significant association between emotional disturbance and pain severity, with higher levels of emotional disturbance being correlated with increased pain intensity and disability. Furthermore, longitudinal analysis revealed that emotional disturbance predicted increased pain severity over time, suggesting that it may play a role in the perpetuation of chronic pain. These findings emphasize the importance of addressing emotional factors in the management and treatment of chronic pain.

Use of the Collings knife electrode for percutaneous access in difficult endourology cases. Access to the urinary tract during endourological procedures can be challenging in certain cases. The Collings knife electrode has been proposed as a useful tool for percutaneous access in these difficult cases. In this study, we present our experience with the Collings knife electrode in 20 endourology cases where traditional access methods were deemed difficult or impossible. The Collings knife electrode allowed for successful percutaneous access in all cases, with minimal complications and no major injuries. The procedure was relatively quick and provided excellent visualization of the targeted area. The Collings knife electrode proved to be a safe and effective alternative for percutaneous access in difficult endourology cases. Its utilization should be considered for patients who require endourological procedures but present challenging anatomical or technical obstacles. Further studies are warranted to establish its efficacy and safety in a larger patient population.

Optimum results of the surgical treatment of carotid territory ischemia. Surgical treatment plays a crucial role in managing carotid territory ischemia. Achieving optimum results requires meticulous planning and execution. The main goal of surgery is to restore blood flow to the affected area and prevent future ischemic events. Various techniques such as carotid endarterectomy and carotid artery stenting can be employed depending on the patient's specific condition. Careful patient selection, preoperative evaluation, and intraoperative monitoring are essential to ensure successful outcomes. Furthermore, postoperative care including close surveillance, medication management, and cardiovascular risk factor control are crucial for long-term success. Complications such as stroke, bleeding, and infection should be promptly recognized and managed to minimize morbidity and mortality. In conclusion, a comprehensive and multidisciplinary approach is necessary to achieve optimal results in the surgical treatment of carotid territory ischemia.

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty of crural arteries.  The authors dilated 103 stenosed crural arteries in 71 patients. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) in dilating stenosed crural arteries. A total of 103 crural arteries in 71 patients were subjected to PTA. The procedure involved the use of a balloon catheter to mechanically widen the narrowed arteries. The success of the procedure was assessed using angiographic criteria, which included a reduction in stenosis and improved blood flow. The mean follow-up period was 12 months. The results showed a significant improvement in the patency of the dilated crural arteries, with a success rate of 85.4%. Complications such as dissection and perforation were rare, occurring in only 3.9% of cases. This study demonstrates that PTA is a safe and effective method for treating stenosed crural arteries, providing improved blood flow and increased limb salvage rates in patients with peripheral arterial disease.

Aneurysmal dilatation in saphenous vein bypass grafts. Aneurysmal dilatation is a known complication of saphenous vein bypass grafts. This case report highlights a 68-year-old male patient who presented with symptoms of acute limb ischemia seven years after undergoing a saphenous vein bypass graft for peripheral arterial disease. Imaging studies revealed a large aneurysmal dilatation at the site of the graft. The patient underwent surgical repair of the aneurysm, which involved graft replacement and removal of the aneurysmal segment. Pathological examination confirmed the presence of a true aneurysm with degenerative changes in the graft wall. The patient experienced a satisfactory outcome postoperatively, with restoration of limb perfusion. This case emphasizes the importance of surveillance and early detection of aneurysmal dilatation in saphenous vein bypass grafts to prevent complications such as acute limb ischemia. Further research is warranted to better understand the risk factors and optimal management strategies for this condition.

Calcium and calcium binding in human gallstone disease. The role of calcium and calcium-binding proteins in the development of human gallstone disease has been investigated. Gallstone disease is a common disorder characterized by the formation of solid masses in the gallbladder or bile ducts. Previous studies have suggested a potential association between calcium and gallstone formation, but the precise mechanisms underlying this relationship remain unclear. In this study, we examined the levels of calcium and calcium-binding proteins in gallstone patients compared to control subjects. Our results revealed significantly higher levels of calcium in gallstone patients, indicating a potential role for calcium in gallstone formation. Additionally, we found alterations in the expression of calcium-binding proteins, including calmodulin and S100A proteins, in gallstone patients. These findings suggest that dysregulation of calcium homeostasis and calcium-binding proteins may contribute to the pathogenesis of gallstone disease. Further research is needed to elucidate the exact mechanisms by which calcium and calcium-binding proteins are involved in gallstone formation, which could potentially lead to the development of new therapeutic interventions for this condition.

Porokeratoses: immunohistochemical, light and electron microscopic evaluation. Porokeratosis is a group of skin disorders characterized by the presence of cornoid lamella. In this study, we conducted an immunohistochemical, light, and electron microscopic evaluation of porokeratoses to gain a better understanding of their pathogenesis. We examined skin sections from 20 patients with various types of porokeratosis. Immunohistochemical staining showed a marked increase in cytokeratin expression, particularly in the cornoid lamella, indicating abnormal keratinocyte differentiation. Additionally, electron microscopy revealed abnormal keratinization with disorganized lamellar structures and increased melanin granules in the lesional epidermis. These findings suggest that the abnormal differentiation and keratinization of keratinocytes contribute to the formation of cornoid lamella in porokeratosis. Moreover, the increased presence of melanin granules may suggest a role for melanocytes in the pathogenesis of porokeratosis. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets for these disorders.

Effect of electrocautery on wound healing in midline laparotomy incisions. The effect of electrocautery on wound healing in midline laparotomy incisions was evaluated in a study involving 80 patients. Half of the patients received electrocautery during their surgeries, while the other half did not. Wound healing was assessed by measuring the incidence of wound infections, wound dehiscence, and the time required for complete wound closure. The results revealed a significantly higher incidence of wound infections and wound dehiscence in the electrocautery group compared to the control group. Additionally, the time required for complete wound closure was significantly longer in the electrocautery group. These findings indicate that the use of electrocautery in midline laparotomy incisions may negatively impact wound healing.

Percutaneous transperineal prostate cryosurgery using transrectal ultrasound guidance: animal model. This study aimed to develop an animal model for percutaneous transperineal prostate cryosurgery using transrectal ultrasound guidance. Six male pigs weighing 20-25kg were used for the procedure.
