After anesthesia and transrectal ultrasound imaging, a percutaneous access needle was inserted through the perineum, followed by insertion of cryoprobes into the prostate gland under ultrasound guidance. Cryoablation was performed with multiple freeze-thaw cycles. Post-procedure imaging showed successful targeting of the prostate gland and formation of ice balls within the gland. Histopathological examination confirmed necrosis of prostatic tissue. This animal model demonstrates the feasibility of percutaneous transperineal prostate cryosurgery using transrectal ultrasound guidance and may contribute to further advancements in this technique.

Metastatic small cell tumor of bone with 'true' rosettes and glial fibrillary acidic protein positivity. Metastatic small cell tumor of bone is a rare malignant neoplasm with limited case reports. We present a case of a 56-year-old male who presented with a painful lump on his right thigh. Histopathological examination of the excised tumor revealed small round blue cells with 'true' rosette formation and positive staining for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), which is typically seen in astrocytic tumors. Immunohistochemistry further confirmed the diagnosis of metastatic small cell tumor of bone. The patient underwent systemic chemotherapy, but unfortunately, experienced disease progression and succumbed to the disease within a year. This case highlights the importance of considering metastatic small cell tumor of bone in the differential diagnosis of bone tumors and emphasizes the role of immunohistochemistry in confirming the diagnosis. Further studies are needed to better understand the etiology and optimal management of this rare malignancy.

The butterfly rash and the malar flush. The butterfly rash and the malar flush are dermatological manifestations commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This study aimed to evaluate the clinical characteristics and disease associations of patients presenting with these cutaneous findings. A retrospective analysis was conducted on medical records of 100 SLE patients with butterfly rash and/or malar flush seen at a tertiary care center between January 2010 and December 2015. The mean age at diagnosis was 34 years, with a female predominance (84%). The majority of patients (78%) had positive antinuclear antibodies, and 56% had positive anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies. Renal involvement was found in 42% of patients, while serositis was present in 24%. Neurological manifestations and hematologic abnormalities were observed in 15% and 14% of patients, respectively. Overall, the butterfly rash and malar flush are important clinical markers in the diagnosis of SLE and are associated with a wide range of systemic manifestations. Prompt recognition and appropriate management are crucial for optimizing patient outcomes.

Toxic epidermal necrolysis after bone marrow transplantation: study of nine cases. Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) is a severe cutaneous adverse reaction that can occur after bone marrow transplantation (BMT). This study aims to analyze the clinical characteristics and outcomes of nine patients who developed TEN following BMT. Among the nine cases, seven were allogeneic BMT and two were autologous BMT. The median onset of TEN after BMT was 25 days. Severe symptoms such as fever, mucositis, and ocular involvement were observed in all patients. Skin biopsies confirmed the diagnosis of TEN in all cases. Despite aggressive management with supportive care and immunosuppressive therapy, the mortality rate was high, with six of the nine patients (67%) succumbing to their condition. The three survivors had significant long-term complications, including chronic graft-versus-host disease and skin contractures. This study highlights the importance of recognizing and promptly treating TEN in patients undergoing BMT, as it is associated with high morbidity and mortality. Further research is needed to identify risk factors and develop effective preventive strategies for this devastating reaction.

Radical prostatectomy for clinical stage T1-2N0M0 prostatic adenocarcinoma: long-term results. This study evaluated the long-term outcomes of radical prostatectomy in patients with clinical stage T1-2N0M0 prostatic adenocarcinoma. A total of 250 patients underwent radical prostatectomy and were followed up for a median of 10.5 years. The overall survival rate at 10 years was 85%, while the cancer-specific survival rate was 92%. The biochemical recurrence-free survival rate was 76% at 10 years. On multivariate analysis, preoperative prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level and pathological stage were significant predictors of biochemical recurrence. Positive surgical margins were found in 29% of cases, which was associated with a higher risk of biochemical recurrence. The most common adverse events were urinary incontinence and erectile dysfunction, with rates of 24% and 51%, respectively. In conclusion, radical prostatectomy for clinical stage T1-2N0M0 prostatic adenocarcinoma provides favorable long-term outcomes in terms of overall and cancer-specific survival. Preoperative PSA level, pathological stage, and surgical margin status are important prognostic factors for biochemical recurrence.

Bacterial meningitis: an update. Bacterial meningitis is a serious and life-threatening infection of the meninges, the protective membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord. This abstract provides an update on bacterial meningitis, summarizing key information about its epidemiology, pathogenesis, clinical presentation, diagnosis, and treatment. The abstract also highlights recent advancements in the understanding of this disease, including the identification of genetic recombination as a mechanism for gene deletion in factor IX Seattle 1, a variant associated with hemophilia B. In this particular case, recombination between two 14-bp homologous sequences located in different regions of the normal factor IX gene resulted in a 10-kb intragenic deletion. These findings contribute to our understanding of the genetic basis of hemophilia B and provide insights into potential therapeutic strategies for this inherited bleeding disorder.

X-linked spinal muscular atrophy (Kennedy's syndrome). X-linked spinal muscular atrophy (Kennedy's syndrome) is a rare neurodegenerative disorder primarily affecting males. This abstract reviews the clinical presentation, genetic basis, and management of this condition. X-linked spinal muscular atrophy is caused by mutations in the androgen receptor gene, resulting in progressive muscle weakness and atrophy. Symptoms typically manifest in adulthood and involve proximal limb weakness, bulbar dysfunction, and gynecomastia. Diagnosis is confirmed through genetic testing. Treatment options focus on alleviating symptoms and improving quality of life, including physical therapy, assistive devices, and speech therapy. Ongoing research aims to identify potential targeted therapies. Clinicians should consider X-linked spinal muscular atrophy in the differential diagnosis for males presenting with progressive muscle weakness, and provide appropriate multidisciplinary care and genetic counseling for affected individuals and their families.

Molecular analysis of acute promyelocytic leukemia breakpoint cluster region on chromosome 17. Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is characterized by a specific chromosomal translocation involving the breakpoint cluster region (BCR) on chromosome 17. The molecular analysis of this region provides valuable information for diagnosis and monitoring of APL. In this study, we analyzed the BCR region in a cohort of APL patients and identified various breakpoints. We found that the majority of breakpoints occurred in intron 3 of the BCR gene. Furthermore, we observed a correlation between specific breakpoints and patient outcomes. Our findings highlight the importance of molecular analysis of the BCR region in APL, as it can aid in diagnosis, risk stratification, and treatment selection for patients with this disease.

Incidence of cutaneous T cell lymphoma and other rare skin cancers in a defined population.  Between 1970 and 1984 in Rochester, Minnesota, rare skin cancers developed in 15 local residents: cutaneous T cell lymphoma (six subjects), dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (four), adenocarcinoma of sweat glands (two), Merkel cell carcinoma (one), liposarcoma (one), and extramammary Paget's disease (one). This study aimed to determine the incidence of rare skin cancers in a defined population. A total of 15 cases of rare skin cancers were identified in Rochester, Minnesota between 1970 and 1984. The specific types of rare skin cancers included cutaneous T cell lymphoma, dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans, adenocarcinoma of sweat glands, Merkel cell carcinoma, liposarcoma, and extramammary Paget's disease. This study provides important information about the occurrence of these rare skin cancers in a specific population. Further research is needed to investigate potential risk factors and improve early detection and management of these rare skin cancers.

The Marinesco-Sjogren syndrome examined by computed tomography, magnetic resonance, and 18F-2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose and positron emission tomography. Marinesco-Sjogren syndrome is a rare neurodegenerative disorder characterized by cerebellar ataxia, cataracts, muscle weakness, and intellectual disability. This case series describes the neuroimaging findings in three patients with Marinesco-Sjogren syndrome using computed tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), 18F-2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG) positron emission tomography (PET). CT and MRI revealed cerebellar atrophy and white matter abnormalities in all patients, while MRI additionally showed signal abnormalities in the globus pallidus. FDG PET demonstrated hypometabolism in the cerebellum, frontal cortex, and basal ganglia. These findings provide further evidence of the involvement of the cerebellum and basal ganglia in Marinesco-Sjogren syndrome. The combination of CT, MRI, and FDG PET can aid in the diagnosis and evaluation of disease progression in patients with Marinesco-Sjogren syndrome. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying pathophysiology and develop targeted therapeutic strategies for this debilitating disorder.

Neuroexcitatory plasma amino acids are elevated in migraine. The objective of this study was to determine if there is an association between neuroexcitatory plasma amino acids and migraine. Plasma samples from 42 migraine patients and 42 healthy controls were analyzed for the levels of glutamate, aspartate, glycine, and taurine using high-performance liquid chromatography. The results showed that the levels of glutamate and aspartate were significantly elevated in migraine patients compared to controls (p < 0.001). There was no significant difference in the levels of glycine and taurine between the two groups. Furthermore, the levels of glutamate and aspartate were positively correlated with the frequency and severity of migraine attacks (p < 0.05). These findings suggest that elevated levels of neuroexcitatory amino acids, specifically glutamate and aspartate, may play a role in the pathogenesis of migraine. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore potential therapeutic targets.

Medical treatment and prevention of peptic ulcer disease.  Many agents seem to be equally effective for the treatment of peptic ulcer disease. Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a common condition that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. Medical treatment is important for both acute management and long-term prevention. Various agents are available for PUD treatment, including proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), H2 receptor antagonists (H2RAs), and antacids. This study aimed to compare the efficacy of different agents in the treatment and prevention of PUD. A systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials were conducted. The results showed similar effectiveness among PPIs, H2RAs, and antacids in the treatment of PUD, with comparable rates of healing and symptom relief. However, PPIs were found to be superior in preventing recurrent ulceration and achieving long-term remission. Therefore, PPIs should be considered the first-line therapy for PUD, both for acute treatment and maintenance therapy. Further studies are needed to optimize treatment regimens and determine individual patient factors that may influence treatment outcomes.

Cause of death in an emergency department A retrospective review was done of 601 consecutive emergency department deaths.  Nontrauma causes accounted for 77% of the deaths and this group had an average age of 64 years and a male to female ratio of 1. A retrospective review of 601 emergency department deaths revealed that nontrauma causes accounted for 77% of the cases. The average age of patients in this group was 64 years, with a male to female ratio of 1. Identifying the cause of death in these cases is crucial for improving patient care and resource allocation. Many of these deaths occurred in older adults, highlighting the need for comprehensive geriatric assessment and specialized care in emergency departments. Further research should focus on developing strategies to prevent and manage nontraumatic conditions that contribute to mortality in this population.

Carboplatin in childhood brain tumors. Carboplatin, a platinum-based chemotherapeutic agent, has shown promising efficacy in the treatment of childhood brain tumors. This study aimed to evaluate the clinical outcomes and side effects of carboplatin in pediatric patients with brain tumors. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of 50 children diagnosed with various types of brain tumors and treated with carboplatin as part of their chemotherapy regimen. The overall response rate was 60%, with 40% of patients achieving a complete response and 20% achieving a partial response. The median progression-free survival was 10 months, and the median overall survival was 24 months. Common side effects included myelosuppression, gastrointestinal disturbances, and renal toxicity. However, these toxicities were generally manageable and reversible. In conclusion, carboplatin appears to be an effective and tolerable treatment option for childhood brain tumors, providing encouraging clinical responses with an acceptable safety profile. Further prospective studies are warranted to confirm these findings and optimize treatment strategies.

The operative management of coexisting thyroid and parathyroid disease.  Three hundred eight patients who underwent operation for hyperparathyroidism were studied. In this study, the authors evaluated the operative management of coexisting thyroid and parathyroid disease in 308 patients with hyperparathyroidism. Surgical procedures were performed to treat the patients. Among the patients, 193 had parathyroid adenoma, 56 had multiglandular disease, and 59 had thyroid disease. Of these, 32 patients had thyroid cancer. The surgical approach varied depending on the type of disease and the patient's individual needs. The majority of patients underwent a combination of parathyroidectomy and thyroid lobectomy or total thyroidectomy. The authors observed that the surgical treatment resulted in successful management of both parathyroid and thyroid diseases in most patients. However, they noted that careful evaluation and individualized surgical planning are required to ensure optimal outcomes in patients with coexisting thyroid and parathyroid disease.

Surgical aspects of sclerosing encapsulating peritonitis. Sclerosing encapsulating peritonitis (SEP) is a rare but serious complication of peritoneal dialysis. This study aims to highlight the surgical aspects of SEP in 20 patients. The surgical treatment involved extensive adhesiolysis, excision of the encapsulating membrane, and peritoneal reconstruction using various techniques including omentoplasty and mesh repair. Intraoperative findings showed thickened and fibrotic peritoneal membranes encasing the small bowel and other organs. Adhesions were present between the encapsulating membrane and adjacent structures. Postoperative outcomes were generally satisfactory, with relief of symptoms and improvement in organ function. However, complications such as wound infection and small bowel obstruction were observed in a few cases. The study emphasizes the importance of early recognition and prompt surgical intervention in SEP management. Surgical techniques that aim to relieve adhesions, excise the encapsulating membrane, and reconstruct the peritoneal cavity are effective in relieving symptoms and improving outcomes in patients with SEP.

Immunohistologic localization of alpha, mu, and pi class glutathione S-transferases in human tissues. Glutathione S-transferases (GSTs) are enzymes involved in detoxification processes and are expressed in various human tissues. In this study, we aimed to localize alpha, mu, and pi class GSTs immunohistologically in different human tissues. Tissue samples were obtained from various organs including liver, kidney, lung, colon, and brain. Immunohistochemistry was performed using specific antibodies against alpha, mu, and pi class GSTs. The results showed differential expression patterns of these GST classes in different tissues. The alpha class GSTs were mainly localized in the liver and kidney, with minimal presence in other tissues. The mu class GSTs were abundant in the liver, lung, and colon, while the pi class GSTs were predominantly found in the liver and brain. These findings provide insights into the tissue-specific distribution of GSTs, which may have implications for understanding their role in drug metabolism and detoxification processes in different organs.

Comparison of shunt fraction estimation using transcolonic iodine-123-iodoamphetamine and technetium-99m-pertechnetate in a group of dogs with experimentally-induced chronic biliary cirrhosis. Chronic biliary cirrhosis is a progressive liver disease characterized by impaired hepatic circulation. Shunt fraction estimation, a method to quantify the blood flow bypassing the liver, is crucial for assessing disease severity and guiding treatment decisions. In this study, we compared the accuracy of transcolonic iodine-123-iodoamphetamine (IMP) and technetium-99m-pertechnetate (Tc-99m) for shunt fraction estimation in dogs with experimentally-induced chronic biliary cirrhosis. Dogs were divided into two groups: control and cirrhotic. Both IMP and Tc-99m were administered intravenously, followed by scintigraphy to visualize the shunt fraction. We found a significant correlation between the shunt fraction measured by IMP and Tc-99m in both control and cirrhotic groups. However, the shunt fraction estimates were higher with IMP compared to Tc-99m in the cirrhotic group. Our findings suggest that while both tracers can accurately estimate shunt fraction, IMP may overestimate the shunt fraction in dogs with chronic biliary cirrhosis. Further studies are warranted to validate these findings in a larger patient population and explore alternative methods for shunt fraction estimation in this clinical setting.

Decreased local toxicity with subcutaneous diamorphine (heroin): a preliminary report. This study aimed to evaluate the local toxicity of subcutaneous diamorphine administration in patients with chronic pain. A total of 30 patients were included in this preliminary report. Local toxicity was assessed using a visual analog scale (VAS) for pain, redness, swelling, and pruritus at the injection site. Results showed that subcutaneous diamorphine administration was associated with a significant decrease in pain compared to baseline VAS scores. Furthermore, no significant redness, swelling, or pruritus was reported at the injection site. Overall, these preliminary findings suggest that subcutaneous diamorphine may be a safe and effective option for chronic pain management, with no significant local toxicity observed. However, further research with a larger sample size is warranted to confirm these findings.

Progression of stage T1 bladder tumors after intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin [published erratum appears in J Urol 1991 Apr;145(4):840] Of 221 patients with superficial bladder tumors (stages Ta, Tis and T1) treated by transurethral resection and an initial 6-week course of intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) 195 were evaluated after 3 months for local response. This study examined the progression of stage T1 bladder tumors after treatment with intravesical bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG). A total of 221 patients with superficial bladder tumors (stages Ta, Tis and T1) underwent transurethral resection and received an initial 6-week course of intravesical BCG. After 3 months, 195 patients were evaluated for local response. The results showed that BCG treatment was effective in preventing tumor progression in the majority of patients. Specifically, only a small percentage of patients experienced disease progression to a higher stage. These findings suggest that intravesical BCG is a valuable treatment option for stage T1 bladder tumors, as it can effectively reduce the risk of disease progression.

Indwelling epidural catheters for pain control in gynecologic cancer patients. Indwelling epidural catheters are commonly used for pain control in gynecologic cancer patients. This study aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of indwelling epidural catheters in this population. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 100 gynecologic cancer patients who received indwelling epidural catheters for pain management. The majority of patients (82%) reported significant pain relief, with a mean pain score reduction of 6.4 on a numerical rating scale. The incidence of complications was low, with only 5% of patients experiencing catheter-related infections or dislodgement. No serious adverse events were reported. The mean duration of catheter use was 7.2 days, with 70% of patients requiring catheter removal due to improvement in pain. These findings suggest that indwelling epidural catheters are a safe and effective option for pain control in gynecologic cancer patients, providing significant pain relief with minimal complications. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these results.

Outpatient laparoscopic laser cholecystectomy. Outpatient laparoscopic laser cholecystectomy is a minimally invasive surgical technique for the removal of the gallbladder. This retrospective study evaluates the safety, effectiveness, and feasibility of this procedure in an outpatient setting. A total of 150 patients underwent laparoscopic laser cholecystectomy and were discharged on the same day. The average operative time was 60 minutes, and there were no major intraoperative or postoperative complications. The patients reported minimal pain, early return to normal activities, and high satisfaction with the procedure. Outpatient laparoscopic laser cholecystectomy is a viable option for the management of gallbladder pathologies, providing a safe and efficient approach with excellent patient outcomes.

Marijuana smoking as a possible cause of tongue carcinoma in young patients. This study aimed to determine if marijuana smoking is a possible cause of tongue carcinoma in young patients. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 40 patients diagnosed with tongue carcinoma under the age of 40, and 40 age-matched controls without tongue carcinoma. The use of marijuana was self-reported by the patients. Results showed that 65% of the tongue carcinoma patients were marijuana smokers, compared to only 10% in the control group. The odds ratio for developing tongue carcinoma in marijuana smokers was found to be 12.5. Furthermore, the duration and intensity of marijuana smoking were positively correlated with the risk of developing tongue carcinoma. These findings suggest that marijuana smoking may be a significant risk factor for tongue carcinoma in young patients and emphasize the need for further studies to confirm these findings.

Use of activated charcoal to reduce elevated serum phenobarbital concentration in a neonate.  The course of a neonate administered activated charcoal orally for elevated phenobarbital concentration is described. This case report describes the successful reduction of elevated serum phenobarbital concentration in a neonate through the administration of activated charcoal orally. The neonate presented with a dangerously high phenobarbital concentration due to a medication error. Activated charcoal was chosen as a treatment option to enhance drug elimination by adsorption in the gastrointestinal tract. After obtaining parental consent, the neonate received a single dose of activated charcoal. Serial blood samples were collected to monitor the serum phenobarbital levels. Within hours of the activated charcoal administration, a significant decrease in the serum phenobarbital concentration was observed. The neonate's clinical condition remained stable throughout the treatment. Activated charcoal appears to be a safe and effective treatment option for reducing elevated serum phenobarbital levels in neonates. Further studies are warranted to evaluate the optimal dosing and administration schedule of activated charcoal in this patient population.

Infrarenal abdominal aortic disease: a review of the retroperitoneal approach. Infrarenal abdominal aortic disease is a common condition that often requires surgical intervention. The retroperitoneal approach is an alternative technique for accessing and treating this disease, offering advantages such as reduced morbidity and shorter hospital stay compared to the traditional transperitoneal approach. This article provides a comprehensive review of the retroperitoneal approach for infrarenal abdominal aortic disease, including its indications, surgical technique, and outcomes. Key aspects discussed include patient selection, benefits of retroperitoneal exposure, avoidance of bowel complications, and potential complications specific to this approach. The review highlights the importance of proper patient selection and surgical expertise to achieve optimal outcomes when utilizing the retroperitoneal approach for infrarenal abdominal aortic disease.

Prognosticating study for cervical myelopathy using evoked spinal cord potentials. This study aimed to evaluate the prognostic value of evoked spinal cord potentials (ESCPs) in patients with cervical myelopathy. A total of 78 patients diagnosed with cervical myelopathy underwent preoperative ESCP testing. The ESCPs included somatosensory evoked potentials and motor evoked potentials. The patients were followed up for a median period of 36 months. The primary outcome measure was the improvement in neurological function based on the modified Japanese Orthopedic Association (mJOA) score. The results showed that patients with positive ESCPs had a significantly higher rate of neurological improvement compared to those with negative ESCPs (p < 0.05). Additionally, the absence of ESCPs was associated with a higher risk of postoperative deterioration (p < 0.05). In conclusion, ESCPs can be a valuable prognostic tool for assessing the outcome of surgical intervention in patients with cervical myelopathy.

Mammographic follow-up of low-suspicion lesions: compliance rate and diagnostic yield. This study aims to assess the compliance rate and diagnostic yield of mammographic follow-up for low-suspicion lesions. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 500 patients who had undergone mammographic imaging for low-suspicion lesions. The compliance rate was determined by examining the number of patients who returned for scheduled follow-up appointments. The diagnostic yield was assessed by determining the number of patients who were subsequently diagnosed with breast cancer. The results showed a compliance rate of 75% and a diagnostic yield of 2.5%. These findings suggest that mammographic follow-up for low-suspicion lesions has a relatively low compliance rate and a low diagnostic yield. Further research is needed to identify strategies to improve patient compliance and increase the diagnostic yield in this population.

An analysis of abnormalities of the retinoblastoma gene in human ovarian and endometrial carcinoma. This study aimed to investigate abnormalities of the retinoblastoma (RB) gene in ovarian and endometrial carcinoma. Tumor samples from 50 patients with ovarian carcinoma and 50 patients with endometrial carcinoma were analyzed. Abnormalities of the RB gene were detected using polymerase chain reaction and direct DNA sequencing. Results showed that 20% of patients with ovarian carcinoma and 18% of patients with endometrial carcinoma had RB gene abnormalities. Among these abnormalities, gene mutations were the most common, followed by loss of heterozygosity and promoter hypermethylation. Furthermore, RB gene abnormalities were associated with advanced tumor stage and lymph node involvement in both types of carcinoma. These findings suggest that abnormalities of the RB gene may contribute to the development and progression of ovarian and endometrial carcinoma. Targeting the RB pathway could be a potential therapeutic strategy for these cancers. Further investigation is warranted to elucidate the precise mechanisms and clinical implications of RB gene abnormalities in these types of carcinoma.

Adenocarcinoma arising in Barrett's esophagus after total gastrectomy A 64-yr-old Japanese male who underwent a partial gastrectomy for a duodenal ulcer at the age of 21, a total resection of the remnant stomach for a stomal ulcer at age 25, and in whom Barrett's esophagus was diagnosed at age 47, was found to have a tumor at the distal esophagus and was operated on by thoracic esophagectomy. A 64-yr-old Japanese male with a history of partial gastrectomy and total resection of the remnant stomach developed a tumor in the distal esophagus. The patient underwent thoracic esophagectomy due to the presence of Barrett's esophagus.

Chronic diarrhea in essential mixed cryoglobulinemia: a manifestation of visceral vasculitis? Gastrointestinal involvement occurs frequently in essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, and most often involves the liver and spleen. This case report discusses a patient with chronic diarrhea associated with essential mixed cryoglobulinemia. Gastrointestinal involvement is common in essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, with the liver and spleen being the most affected organs. The patient presented with chronic diarrhea, and further investigations revealed cryoglobulinemia and signs of visceral vasculitis. This suggests that the chronic diarrhea experienced by the patient may be a result of visceral vasculitis. Gastrointestinal symptoms should be carefully evaluated in patients with essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, as they may be indicative of underlying vasculitis. Early recognition and management of visceral vasculitis are crucial in improving patient outcomes.

Fatigue failure of noncemented porous-coated implants. This article focuses on the issue of fatigue failure in noncemented porous-coated implants. It is part of a larger study on the complications associated with joint replacement surgery. The article provides an overview of the biomechanics and causes of fatigue failure in these implants. It discusses the importance of proper implant design and surgical technique in preventing this complication. The article also highlights the role of patient factors, such as age and activity level, in increasing the risk of fatigue failure. Understanding the factors contributing to fatigue failure in noncemented porous-coated implants is crucial for surgeons to make informed decisions and improve patient outcomes in joint replacement surgery. Further research and advancements in implant materials and designs are needed to address this issue.

Microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism causing subacute cor pulmonale: a difficult antemortem diagnosis [published erratum appears in Mayo Clin Proc 1991 Apr;66(4):439] Microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism is difficult to diagnose. Pulmonary tumor embolism is a rare but potentially fatal complication of malignancy. It occurs when tumor cells or tumor emboli migrate to the pulmonary vasculature and cause obstruction, leading to pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale. The diagnosis of this condition is challenging due to its nonspecific clinical presentation and lack of specific imaging findings. We present a case of a patient with subacute cor pulmonale who was ultimately diagnosed with microscopic pulmonary tumor embolism. The patient had a history of lung carcinoma, and autopsy confirmed the presence of tumor emboli in the pulmonary vasculature. This case highlights the importance of considering pulmonary tumor embolism in the differential diagnosis of unexplained cor pulmonale, particularly in patients with known malignancy. Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial for improving patient outcomes. Further research is needed to improve the diagnostic accuracy and management strategies for this rare condition.

Heart weights of white men 20 to 39 years of age.  An analysis of 218 autopsy cases. This study analyzed the heart weights of 218 white men aged 20 to 39 years based on autopsy cases. The mean heart weight was found to be 334 grams, with a standard deviation of 47 grams. Further analysis using regression equations indicated that age was positively correlated with heart weight, with an estimated increase of 1.6 grams per year. Additionally, height and body weight were also found to be positively correlated with heart weight. No significant differences in heart weight were observed based on cause of death or presence of cardiovascular disease. These findings contribute to our understanding of heart weights in young adult white men and may have implications for clinical practice and research.

Air in the fissure for the ligamentum teres: new sign of intraperitoneal air on plain radiographs. Intraperitoneal air on plain radiographs is typically recognized by the presence of pneumoperitoneum or specific signs such as Rigler's sign or the football sign. We report a novel sign of intraperitoneal air, the air in the fissure for the ligamentum teres, in two patients with acute abdominal pain. Both patients had prior abdominal surgery and developed symptoms consistent with bowel obstruction. On plain radiographs, air was visualized within the fissure for the ligamentum teres, a radiolucent area that represents a remnant of the fetal umbilical vein. This sign correlated with the presence of pneumoperitoneum confirmed on subsequent computed tomography scans. Awareness of this sign may aid in the early recognition and diagnosis of intraperitoneal air on plain radiographs.

99mTc HM-PAO SPECT in pediatric migraine. Pediatric migraine is a common neurological disorder characterized by recurrent headaches. To investigate the cerebral blood flow changes during migraine attacks in children, we performed 99mTc hexamethylpropyleneamine oxime single-photon emission computed tomography (99mTc HM-PAO SPECT) in a group of pediatric patients. A total of 30 patients (mean age 10.1 years) with a history of migraine were included in this study. SPECT imaging was performed during a migraine attack and compared to the results obtained during headache-free intervals. The analysis revealed significant hypoperfusion in various cerebral regions, including the frontal, parietal, and occipital lobes, as well as the basal ganglia and cerebellum, during the migraine attack. These findings suggest that altered cerebral blood flow underlies the pathophysiology of pediatric migraine and may contribute to the development of headache symptoms. 99mTc HM-PAO SPECT can serve as a valuable tool for the diagnosis and monitoring of pediatric migraine. Further studies are warranted to explore the clinical implications of these findings and possible therapeutic targets.

A T-cell neoplasia showing clinicopathologic features of malignant histiocytosis with novel chromosomal abnormalities and N-ras mutation.  Malignant histiocytosis (MH) is a distinct disease entity defined clinically and morphologically. We report a case of T-cell neoplasia displaying clinicopathologic features of malignant histiocytosis (MH) with novel chromosomal abnormalities and N-ras mutation. MH is a well-defined disease entity characterized by aggressive proliferation of histiocytes in multiple organs, but T-cell involvement is rare. A 52-year-old male presented with generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Histopathological examination revealed infiltration of histiocytes exhibiting pleomorphic nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positive staining for CD4, CD3, CD68, and S100. Fluorescence in situ hybridization demonstrated novel chromosomal abnormalities involving chromosomes 11 and 16. Additionally, molecular analysis revealed an N-ras mutation. Our case expands the spectrum of MH to include T-cell neoplasia and highlights the importance of molecular characterization in the diagnosis and classification of this rare disease. Further studies are warranted to investigate the clinical implications of these genetic alterations in MH.

The effect of metoclopramide on ovarian responsiveness to gonadotropin administration in patients with severe polycystic ovarian syndrome. Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is a common cause of infertility in women and is characterized by hyperandrogenism and anovulation. This study investigates the effect of metoclopramide on ovarian responsiveness to gonadotropin administration in patients with severe PCOS. A total of 50 patients with severe PCOS were randomly assigned to receive either metoclopramide or placebo in addition to gonadotropin treatment. Ovarian responsiveness was evaluated through the number of follicles developed and serum estradiol levels. Results showed that patients treated with metoclopramide had a significantly higher number of follicles developed and higher estradiol levels compared to the placebo group. Additionally, metoclopramide treatment was associated with a higher ovulation rate and lower cancellation rate for in vitro fertilization procedures. These findings suggest that metoclopramide may improve ovarian responsiveness and enhance outcomes in patients with severe PCOS undergoing assisted reproductive techniques. Further studies are warranted to confirm these results.

Treating systemic fungal infections in AIDS patients. Systemic fungal infections pose a significant threat to the health of AIDS patients. This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of different treatment options for these infections. The medical records of 250 AIDS patients diagnosed with systemic fungal infections were retrospectively reviewed. Patients were classified into three groups based on the treatment received: antifungal monotherapy, combination therapy, or no treatment. The outcomes assessed included the resolution of infection, mortality rates, and adverse events. Results showed that combination therapy was associated with the highest rates of resolution (82%), compared to antifungal monotherapy (65%) and no treatment (48%). Additionally, combination therapy had lower mortality rates (12%) compared to antifungal monotherapy (18%) and no treatment (26%). Adverse events were reported in 25% of patients receiving combination therapy, 18% in the antifungal monotherapy group, and none in the no treatment group. In conclusion, combination therapy appears to be the most effective and safe approach for treating systemic fungal infections in AIDS patients.

Is emotional disturbance a precipitator or a consequence of chronic pain? The present study examined the relationship between psychological factors and pain in order to assess the contribution of emotional disturbance to the perpetuation of pain. This study aimed to determine whether emotional disturbance is a precipitator or a consequence of chronic pain by assessing the relationship between psychological factors and pain. Participants with chronic pain were evaluated for the presence of emotional disturbance and its impact on pain perpetuation. The results revealed a significant association between emotional disturbance and the intensity and duration of pain. Higher levels of emotional disturbance were found to be linked to increased pain severity and duration. These findings suggest that emotional disturbance may act as a precipitator of chronic pain, exacerbating its intensity and prolonging its duration. Appropriate interventions targeting emotional disturbance may be beneficial in managing chronic pain. Further research is needed to explore the causal relationship between emotional disturbance and chronic pain.

Decision criteria for pure-tone detection used by two age groups of normal-hearing and hearing-impaired listeners. This study investigated the decision criteria for pure-tone detection in two age groups of normal-hearing and hearing-impaired listeners. The results showed that both groups relied on different decision criteria, with the normal-hearing group using a more liberal criterion compared to the hearing-impaired group. Additionally, older participants in both groups had more stringent decision criteria compared to younger participants. These findings suggest that age and hearing status play a significant role in determining the decision criteria for pure-tone detection. Understanding these differences may help improve the development of interventions and treatments for individuals with hearing impairments.

Analysis of alterations in the retinoblastoma gene and tumor grade in bone and soft-tissue sarcomas. In this study, we aimed to investigate the relationship between alterations in the retinoblastoma (RB) gene and tumor grade in bone and soft-tissue sarcomas. We analyzed 45 tumor samples from patients diagnosed with bone and soft-tissue sarcomas using immunohistochemistry, fluorescence in situ hybridization, and genetic sequencing techniques. We found that alterations in the RB gene were present in 28 out of the 45 samples (62.2%). Interestingly, higher tumor grade was significantly associated with the presence of RB gene alterations (p < 0.05). Furthermore, we observed that patients with RB gene alterations had a worse overall survival compared to those without alterations (p < 0.05). Our findings suggest that alterations in the RB gene may play a crucial role in the development and progression of bone and soft-tissue sarcomas, particularly in higher-grade tumors. Further studies are needed to validate these results and explore the potential of RB gene alterations as prognostic markers and therapeutic targets in sarcoma patients.

Pineal hyperactivity in spontaneously hypertensive rats: muscarinic regulation of indole metabolism.  1. In this study, we investigated the role of muscarinic regulation in the pineal gland of spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR) and its effect on indole metabolism. Pineal glands from SHR and control rats were analyzed for muscarinic receptor expression using immunohistochemistry and Western blotting. We found significantly higher levels of muscarinic receptor expression in the SHR pineal gland compared to controls. Indole metabolism was assessed by measuring the levels of pineal indoleamines using high-performance liquid chromatography. We observed increased levels of melatonin and serotonin in the SHR pineal gland, suggesting enhanced indole metabolism. Furthermore, muscarinic receptor blockade significantly reduced the levels of melatonin and serotonin in SHR pineal glands, indicating that muscarinic regulation plays a crucial role in indole metabolism. These findings suggest that pineal hyperactivity, mediated by muscarinic regulation, is involved in the pathophysiology of hypertension in SHR through modulation of indole metabolism.

Anton's syndrome in a patient with posttraumatic optic neuropathy and bifrontal contusions. Anton's syndrome, characterized by denial of visual loss despite objective evidence, is a rare condition typically associated with bilateral occipital lobe lesions. We present a case of Anton's syndrome in a patient with posttraumatic optic neuropathy and bifrontal contusions. The patient, a 45-year-old male, presented with blunt head trauma and subsequently developed visual impairment. Brain imaging revealed bilateral contusions in the frontal lobes and optic nerve atrophy. Interestingly, despite objective evidence of visual loss, the patient consistently denied any visual deficits. This case highlights the possibility of Anton's syndrome occurring in the setting of posttraumatic optic neuropathy and frontal lobe contusions. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and optimal management strategies for patients with this unique presentation. Clinicians should be aware of this potential manifestation to facilitate early recognition and appropriate intervention for these patients.

Oral squamous cell carcinoma arising in a patient with long-standing lichen planus. Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory mucocutaneous disease with a reported association with oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC). We present a case of OSCC arising in a patient with lichen planus. The patient had a long history of lichen planus lesions on the buccal mucosa, which eventually progressed to a suspicious ulcerated lesion that was diagnosed as OSCC. The risk of developing OSCC in patients with oral lichen planus is estimated to be around 0.5-6%. Lichen planus may serve as a potential precursor or predisposing factor for the development of OSCC. Clinicians should be aware of this association and carefully monitor patients with lichen planus for signs of malignant transformation.

Pneumococcal anticapsular antibodies in patients with chronic cardiovascular and obstructive lung disease in The Netherlands. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with chronic cardiovascular and obstructive lung diseases. This study aimed to investigate the levels of pneumococcal anticapsular antibodies in these patient populations in The Netherlands. 135 patients with chronic cardiovascular disease, 221 patients with obstructive lung disease, and 114 healthy controls were included in the study. Serum samples were collected and tested for anticapsular antibodies against 23 pneumococcal serotypes using a multiplex immunoassay. The results showed that patients with chronic cardiovascular disease had significantly lower levels of anticapsular antibodies compared to healthy controls, particularly for serotypes 6B, 9V, and 23F. In contrast, patients with obstructive lung disease had higher antibody levels than controls. These findings suggest that patients with chronic cardiovascular disease may have impaired immune responses to pneumococcal infection, highlighting the importance of vaccination in this population.

Awareness during caesarean section.  Between 1982 and 1989 over 3000 patients were questioned about recall and dreaming after general anaesthesia for Caesarean section. Awareness during caesarean section, where patients have conscious awareness during surgery, is a concerning phenomenon. In a study conducted between 1982 and 1989, over 3000 patients who underwent general anesthesia for Caesarean section were interviewed about their experience of recall and dreaming. The results showed that 1 in 670 patients reported some level of awareness during the procedure, with 70% experiencing auditory and 40% experiencing visual awareness. However, only 8% of these patients had distressing experiences. Factors such as rapid sequence induction, lower doses of anesthesia, and higher levels of anxiety were associated with a higher incidence of awareness. The study highlights the importance of monitoring and optimizing anesthesia techniques to minimize the risk of awareness during Caesarean section.

Pancreatic ascites: treatment by continuous somatostatin infusion. Pancreatic ascites is a rare complication of acute or chronic pancreatitis. We report four cases of pancreatic ascites that were successfully treated with continuous somatostatin infusion. All patients presented with abdominal distension, pain, and imaging exams confirmed the presence of ascites. Initial conservative management with fasting, bowel rest, and total parenteral nutrition was unsuccessful in resolving the condition in all cases. Continuous somatostatin infusion was initiated and maintained for a median duration of 10 days. In all cases, resolution of ascites occurred within 7 to 14 days of starting somatostatin infusion. No adverse events were observed during treatment. Continuous somatostatin infusion appears to be an effective and safe treatment option for pancreatic ascites. Further studies are warranted to determine the optimal dosage and duration of somatostatin therapy.

Colorectal adenocarcinoma in patients less than 40 years of age.  From 1973 to 1985, 105 patients under 40 years of age were treated for colorectal adenocarcinoma at Roswell Park Cancer Institute. Colorectal adenocarcinoma is typically seen in older adults, and its occurrence in patients under 40 years of age is rare. In this retrospective study, we analyzed the medical records of 105 patients who were diagnosed with colorectal adenocarcinoma at Roswell Park Cancer Institute between 1973 and 1985. Our findings revealed that the majority of these patients presented with advanced stage disease, which may have contributed to poor outcomes. Surgery, both radical and palliative, was the main treatment modality, while adjuvant chemotherapy was also utilized in some cases. The overall survival rate at five years was significantly lower in this younger age group compared to older patients, emphasizing the need for increased awareness and early detection strategies for colorectal adenocarcinoma in younger individuals.

Periventricular hyperintensity detected by magnetic resonance imaging in infancy.  Twenty-one infants younger than 12 months of age were diagnosed as having periventricular hyperintensity (PVH) on T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging. A study was conducted to evaluate periventricular hyperintensity (PVH) detected by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in infants aged younger than 12 months. Twenty-one infants were diagnosed with PVH based on T2-weighted MRI findings. The location and extent of PVH were assessed, and its association with clinical features was analyzed. Results showed that PVH was most commonly observed in the periventricular white matter. It was found to be associated with various clinical features, including abnormal neurodevelopmental outcomes. This study highlights the significance of MRI in detecting PVH and its potential implications for the prognosis and management of infants with this condition. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying pathophysiology and long-term outcomes associated with PVH.

Malignant melanoma of the biliary tract: a case report.  A 58-year-old man was seen with obstructive jaundice and discomfort in the upper abdomen. We report a case of malignant melanoma of the biliary tract in a 58-year-old man who presented with obstructive jaundice and upper abdominal discomfort. Radiographic imaging revealed a mass in the common bile duct, which was confirmed on biopsy. Melanoma cells were identified on histopathological and immunohistochemical analysis. No primary site of melanoma was found, suggesting a primary biliary tract origin. The patient underwent surgical resection followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. However, he developed metastatic disease and succumbed to his illness a few months later. Malignant melanoma of the biliary tract is an extremely rare entity with a poor prognosis. It should be considered in the differential diagnosis of biliary tract tumors, especially in the absence of a primary cutaneous or ocular melanoma.

Extensive peripheral retinectomy combined with posterior 360 degrees retinotomy for retinal reattachment in advanced proliferative vitreoretinopathy cases. In cases of advanced proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR) where conventional techniques for retinal reattachment may be inadequate, extensive peripheral retinectomy combined with posterior 360 degrees retinotomy can be an effective surgical approach. This novel technique allows for the release of tractional forces exerted by epiretinal membranes and enables successful retinal reattachment. The surgical procedure involves the removal of peripheral retinal tissues and creation of a complete posterior retinotomy. By providing complete access to the vitreous cavity, this technique improves visualization and enables successful removal of membranes and retinal reattachment. This approach can be considered in cases where standard techniques have failed, ensuring optimal outcomes for patients with advanced PVR.

Post-traumatic bile fistulae.  Bile leakage after liver injury has been reported to be a complication associated with significant mortality. Post-traumatic bile fistulae, or bile leakage after liver injury, is a serious complication with high mortality rates. In this study, we aimed to assess the clinical characteristics and outcomes of patients with post-traumatic bile fistulae. A total of 78 patients with post-traumatic bile fistulae were included in this retrospective analysis. The mean age was 42.6 years, and the majority of patients were male (76.9%). The most common cause of liver injury was blunt trauma (81.1%). The mean time from injury to diagnosis was 4.9 days. The majority of patients (84.6%) underwent surgical intervention, including hepaticojejunostomy and percutaneous drainage. The overall mortality rate was 25.6%. Risk factors associated with mortality included advanced age, delayed diagnosis, severe liver injury, and the need for surgical intervention. In conclusion, post-traumatic bile fistulae are associated with high mortality rates, emphasizing the need for early diagnosis and appropriate surgical management.

Absence of acetylcholine-induced current in epithelial cells from thymus glands and thymomas of myasthenia gravis patients. Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue. The thymus gland has been implicated in the pathogenesis of MG, but the exact mechanisms underlying the disease remain unknown. In this study, we investigated the presence of acetylcholine-induced currents in epithelial cells from thymus glands and thymomas of MG patients. Patch-clamp recordings were performed on freshly isolated thymic epithelial cells. Our results showed a complete absence of acetylcholine-induced currents in both thymus glands and thymomas from MG patients, compared to controls. This suggests a functional impairment of the acetylcholine receptor in thymic epithelial cells of MG patients. Further analysis revealed a significant reduction in the expression of nicotinic acetylcholine receptor subunits in MG thymus glands and thymomas. These findings provide new insights into the role of thymic epithelial cells in the pathogenesis of MG and suggest that dysfunction of the acetylcholine receptor in these cells may contribute to the development of autoimmunity in MG.

Feasibility of reversing benzodiazepine tolerance with flumazenil To examine whether the benzodiazepine antagonist flumazenil can reverse tolerance to benzodiazepines but without precipitating withdrawal seizures, the antiepileptic effect of flumazenil itself and its ability to reverse tolerance at a dose that would leave sufficient receptors free for the binding of benzodiazepines were investigated. In this study, the potential of flumazenil to reverse benzodiazepine tolerance without causing withdrawal seizures was examined. The antiepileptic effect of flumazenil and its ability to reverse tolerance at a dose that would allow benzodiazepine binding were investigated. It was found that flumazenil does possess antiepileptic properties, however, its ability to reverse tolerance without precipitating withdrawal seizures was inconclusive. Further research is needed to fully understand the feasibility of using flumazenil to reverse benzodiazepine tolerance safely and effectively.

Unusual presentation of recurrent Wegener's granulomatosis. Wegener's granulomatosis (WG) is a rare systemic vasculitis characterized by granulomatous inflammation predominantly affecting the upper and lower respiratory tracts and kidneys. We report a case of recurrent WG presenting with an unusual manifestation in a 55-year-old male. The patient initially presented with classic symptoms of WG, including sinusitis, pulmonary nodules, and renal impairment. He responded well to immunosuppressive therapy and achieved remission. However, two years later, he presented with bilateral orbital masses and panuveitis, which was found to be a recurrence of WG. Treatment with high-dose corticosteroids and rituximab led to a gradual improvement in symptoms. This case highlights the importance of recognizing atypical manifestations of WG, as prompt diagnosis and treatment are crucial for optimal outcomes.

Upper tract tumours following cystectomy for bladder cancer. Upper tract tumors (UTTs) are a known complication following cystectomy for bladder cancer. This retrospective study aimed to assess the incidence and risk factors associated with UTT development after cystectomy. A total of 385 patients who underwent cystectomy for bladder cancer were included in the study, with a mean follow-up of 52 months. Twelve patients (3.1%) developed UTTs during the follow-up period. The median time to UTT diagnosis was 21 months after cystectomy. Multivariate analysis identified male gender and smoking history as independent risk factors for UTT development. Furthermore, patients with concurrent carcinoma in situ (CIS) had a significantly higher risk of UTTs. Although rare, UTTs can occur following cystectomy for bladder cancer, particularly in male patients with a history of smoking and concurrent CIS. Regular surveillance and close monitoring of these high-risk patients are recommended to detect and manage UTTs at an early stage.

Detection by CT during arterial portography of colorectal cancer metastases to liver.  A prospective evaluation of the accuracy of real-time ultrasonography (US), computed tomography (CT), infusion hepatic angiography (IHA), and computed tomography during arterial portography (CT-AP) was performed on 65 resected liver metastases of colorectal cancers. This study prospectively evaluated the accuracy of real-time ultrasonography (US), computed tomography (CT), infusion hepatic angiography (IHA), and computed tomography during arterial portography (CT-AP) in detecting liver metastases from colorectal cancer. 65 resected liver metastases were included in the analysis. CT-AP demonstrated the highest sensitivity (92.3%), followed by CT (86.2%), IHA (79.2%), and US (72.3%). The overall accuracy rates were 83.1%, 76.9%, 75.4%, and 70.8% for CT-AP, CT, IHA, and US, respectively. The study concludes that CT-AP is the most accurate imaging modality for detecting liver metastases from colorectal cancer, making it a valuable tool in the management of these patients.

A case of cecocolic intussusception with complete invagination and intussusception of the appendix with villous adenoma. We report a rare case of a cecocolic intussusception with complete invagination and intussusception of the appendix accompanied by a villous adenoma. A 52-year-old male presented with acute abdominal pain, and imaging revealed intussusception involving the cecum and ascending colon. During surgery, complete invagination of the cecum was observed, with the appendix also involved in the intussusception. Histopathological examination of the resected specimen showed a villous adenoma in the appendix. This case highlights the importance of considering unusual causes of intussusception, such as concurrent invagination of the appendix, and suggests that epithelial tumors of the appendix may be complicating factors. Surgical resection remains the mainstay of treatment for such cases.

Solitary, isolated metastasis from Ewing's sarcoma to the brain: case report. We present a case report of a solitary, isolated metastasis from Ewing's sarcoma to the brain. The patient, a 17-year-old male, was initially diagnosed with Ewing's sarcoma in the pelvis and underwent chemotherapy and surgical resection. However, 8 months later, he developed neurological symptoms and imaging studies showed a single brain lesion. He underwent a craniotomy and resection of the metastatic lesion, followed by whole-brain radiation therapy. The patient had a favorable response to treatment, with no evidence of recurrent disease at the 2-year follow-up. This case highlights the possibility of brain metastasis in patients with Ewing's sarcoma and underscores the importance of early detection and multidisciplinary management. Further studies are needed to better understand the risk factors and treatment options for brain metastasis in Ewing's sarcoma.

Neonatal small bowel atresia, stenosis and segmental dilatation. Neonatal small bowel atresia, stenosis, and segmental dilatation are serious congenital anomalies that can result in significant morbidity and mortality. In this study, we present a case series of neonates diagnosed with small bowel atresia, stenosis, and segmental dilatation. The patients presented with symptoms of intestinal obstruction, including bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. Diagnostic imaging, including abdominal X-rays and ultrasound, confirmed the presence of bowel obstruction. Surgical intervention was performed in all cases, which included resection of the dilated segment and primary anastomosis. Postoperative care involved close monitoring for complications such as anastomotic leak and sepsis. The outcomes varied among the patients, with some experiencing prolonged hospital stays and require subsequent surgeries, while others had a favorable recovery. This case series highlights the importance of early diagnosis and prompt surgical intervention in neonates with small bowel atresia, stenosis, and segmental dilatation to improve outcomes and prevent complications. Further research is needed to better understand the etiology and optimal management of these conditions in neonates.

Anterior decompression and stabilization of thoracolumbar burst fractures by the use of the Slot-Zielke device.  Between July 1983 and November 1986, 29 patients with thoracolumbar burst fractures underwent a one-stage operation consisting of anterior decompression by subtotal vertebrectomy, reduction, and stabilization with the Slot-Zielke device. This study evaluated the efficacy of the Slot-Zielke device in treating thoracolumbar burst fractures. A total of 29 patients underwent a one-stage operation involving anterior decompression, subtotal vertebrectomy, reduction, and stabilization with the Slot-Zielke device between July 1983 and November 1986. The clinical outcomes and radiographic parameters were assessed. The results showed satisfactory neurological improvement in all patients, with no complications directly related to the device. Radiographic evaluation revealed excellent reduction and maintenance of the vertebral height. This one-stage operation using the Slot-Zielke device can effectively achieve anterior decompression, stabilization, and restoration of vertebral height in patients with thoracolumbar burst fractures. Further studies with larger sample sizes and long-term follow-up are required to fully evaluate the effectiveness and stability of this technique.

Catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy in multiple endocrine neoplasia. Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the development of tumors in multiple endocrine organs. Catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy (CIC) is a known complication of MEN, but its prevalence and clinical features remain unclear. In this study, we conducted a retrospective analysis of patients with MEN who developed CIC. A total of 56 patients were included, and the median age at diagnosis was 45 years. The most common presenting symptom was dyspnea, followed by chest pain and fatigue. Echocardiography revealed reduced ejection fraction in all patients. Treatment with beta-blockers and calcium channel blockers led to improvement in cardiac function in most cases. These findings highlight the importance of recognizing CIC as a potential complication of MEN and emphasize the need for early detection and management to prevent adverse outcomes.

Spindle cell carcinoma of the lung. Spindle cell carcinoma (SpCC) is a rare and aggressive subtype of lung cancer. This study aims to provide a comprehensive analysis of the clinical features, treatment modalities, and outcomes of patients with SpCC of the lung. 

A retrospective analysis was conducted on 85 patients diagnosed with SpCC between 2005 and 2015. The median age at diagnosis was 62 years, with a slight male predominance. The most common symptom at presentation was cough (63%), followed by dyspnea (41%) and chest pain (27%). Histologically, the majority of cases demonstrated sarcomatoid features (79%). 

Treatment modalities varied, with surgery being the most common approach (58% of cases), followed by chemotherapy (34%) and radiotherapy (25%). The median overall survival was 9.5 months, with a 1-year survival rate of 36%. Adverse prognostic factors included advanced stage, presence of distant metastases, and poor performance status. 

In conclusion, SpCC of the lung is a highly aggressive malignancy with limited treatment options. Further research is needed to identify effective therapeutic strategies for improving patient outcomes in this challenging disease.

All-trans retinoic acid in acute promyelocytic leukemias.  II. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemias (APL) and to determine the factors that influence its effectiveness. A total of 50 patients with APL were included in the study. Patients were treated with ATRA at a dose of 45 mg/m2/day until complete remission was achieved. The results showed that ATRA was highly effective in inducing remission, with 80% of patients achieving complete remission within 30 days of treatment initiation. The response to ATRA was not influenced by age, sex, or initial white blood cell count. However, patients with a higher percentage of bone marrow blasts had a lower response rate to ATRA. The most common side effects of ATRA were differentiating syndrome and hyperleukocytosis. These findings suggest that ATRA is a highly effective treatment for APL, regardless of age or sex. However, patients with a higher percentage of bone marrow blasts may have a lower response rate and require alternative treatment strategies.

Subtle cerebellar phenotype in mice homozygous for a targeted deletion of the En-2 homeobox. Mice with a targeted deletion of the En-2 homeobox gene exhibited a subtle cerebellar phenotype. The En-2 gene is essential for normal cerebellar development in mice. In this study, homozygous mice lacking the En-2 gene were found to have smaller cerebellar lobules and a reduction in the number of granule cells. However, there were no gross cerebellar abnormalities or motor deficits observed in these mice. These findings suggest that the En-2 homeobox gene plays a role in fine-tuning cerebellar development, but its absence does not result in severe cerebellar dysfunction or motor impairment in mice. Further research is needed to understand the precise mechanisms underlying this subtle cerebellar phenotype.

Mechanical sutures in perforation of the thoracic esophagus as a safe procedure in patients seen late.  Between 1976 and 1988, we treated 13 perforations of the thoracic esophagus, excluding ruptured carcinoma and intraoperative wounds, by mechanical sutures without exclusion. Thirteen cases of thoracic esophageal perforations were treated between 1976 and 1988 using mechanical sutures. Excluding cases of ruptured carcinoma and intraoperative wounds, the procedure was deemed safe for patients who presented late. The mechanical sutures were used without exclusion, and the outcomes were evaluated. The study found that this approach was effective in treating esophageal perforations, and the patients experienced positive outcomes. This suggests that mechanical sutures can be a safe procedure in cases of thoracic esophageal perforation, even when patients present late. Further research may be needed to validate these findings and determine the long-term effects.

Survey of Alabama physicians' use of mammography, 1989. This study aimed to assess the utilization of mammography among physicians in Alabama in 1989. A survey was conducted among a random sample of 500 physicians, including family practitioners, general internists, and obstetricians/gynecologists. The response rate was 74%. Results showed that the overall use of mammography was low among Alabama physicians, with only 59% of respondents ordering more than 25 mammograms that year. The use of mammography varied significantly by specialty, with obstetricians/gynecologists having the highest utilization rate. Factors associated with higher utilization included age, medical school location, and having received continuing medical education in mammography. These findings highlight the need for targeted interventions to improve mammography utilization among Alabama physicians.

Basic studies on a new material for inducing antitumor immune cells. This study investigates the potential of a new material for inducing antitumor immune cells. The material, which is based on nanofibers, has been designed to enhance the activation and expansion of immune cells known as dendritic cells (DCs). In a series of in vitro experiments, the material was shown to effectively stimulate the maturation and cytokine production of DCs. Furthermore, when DCs were co-cultured with tumor cells in the presence of the material, there was a significant increase in the production of cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs), which are known to target and kill tumor cells. These findings suggest that the new material has the potential to enhance the antitumor immune response. Future studies are needed to evaluate the efficacy of this material in vivo and determine its potential as a therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment.

Neoadjuvant chemotherapy in invasive bladder cancer: the evolving role of surgery. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) has become an integral part of the treatment approach for invasive bladder cancer. It has shown to improve overall survival and increase the likelihood of achieving a complete pathological response. However, the optimal timing and extent of subsequent surgery remain controversial. Radical cystectomy is the standard surgical treatment for muscle-invasive bladder cancer. Recent evidence suggests that performing surgery after NAC may confer additional survival benefits compared to upfront surgery alone. Furthermore, the potential for organ preservation strategies, such as partial cystectomy or trimodality therapy, is being explored. The evolving role of surgery in the context of NAC is a dynamic field that requires further research and consensus.

The management of atypical non-cardiac chest pain. The management of atypical non-cardiac chest pain poses a challenge for clinicians. A retrospective study was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of different treatment approaches in 50 patients presenting with atypical chest pain. Patients were categorized into two groups: those with gastrointestinal symptoms and those without gastrointestinal symptoms. The treatment modalities included proton pump inhibitors, antacids, H2 receptor antagonists, and psychological interventions such as cognitive-behavioral therapy. The results showed that patients with gastrointestinal symptoms had a higher response rate to proton pump inhibitors and antacids compared to those without gastrointestinal symptoms. Psychological interventions were found to be effective in both patient groups. These findings suggest that a tailored approach that targets the specific underlying cause of the chest pain is crucial in effectively managing atypical non-cardiac chest pain.

Management of Peyronie disease by implantation of inflatable penile prosthesis. Peyronie's disease is a condition characterized by penile curvature and deformity, often accompanied by pain and erectile dysfunction. Conservative treatments have limited success, prompting the exploration of surgical interventions such as penile prosthesis implantation. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of inflatable penile prosthesis (IPP) in managing Peyronie's disease. A retrospective analysis was conducted on a cohort of patients who underwent IPP implantation for Peyronie's disease from 2010 to 2020. Patient demographics, preoperative characteristics, and postoperative outcomes were analyzed. Results showed a significant improvement in penile curvature, pain, and erectile function following IPP implantation. Complication rates were low, with device infection being the most common. Overall patient satisfaction was high. The findings suggest that IPP implantation is a viable and effective treatment option for Peyronie's disease, providing improved penile function and patient quality of life. Further prospective studies are warranted to validate these results and optimize patient selection.

Estrogen and coronary heart disease in women. The relationship between estrogen and coronary heart disease (CHD) in women has been the subject of extensive research. This review article aims to summarize the current evidence regarding the association between estrogen levels and CHD risk in women. Numerous observational studies have consistently shown that premenopausal women have a lower risk of developing CHD compared to men of the same age. This difference diminishes after menopause, suggesting a protective effect of estrogen. However, randomized controlled trials investigating the use of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) in postmenopausal women have yielded conflicting results. While some studies have reported a reduction in CHD risk with HRT, others have shown an increased risk, particularly in older women. The timing of HRT initiation and duration of use may also influence the risk-benefit profile. Further research is needed to better understand the complex association between estrogen and CHD in women and to identify optimal strategies for prevention and treatment.

Long term effects of gastrocystoplasty in rats.  Twenty prepubescent rats underwent microsurgical gastrocystoplasty by a technique which is described. The long-term effects of gastrocystoplasty were investigated in a study involving twenty prepubescent rats. Microsurgical gastrocystoplasty was performed using a specific technique. Following the procedure, the rats were observed for an extended period to assess the effects of gastrocystoplasty. The results showed favorable outcomes without any immediate complications. However, the long-term effects of gastrocystoplasty were not fully explored in this study. Further research is warranted to evaluate the potential complications and benefits associated with this surgical technique. A long-term follow-up study involving a larger sample size and assessment of various parameters is recommended to obtain a comprehensive understanding of the effects of gastrocystoplasty in rats.

Implementation of preventive services in an HMO practice. This study focuses on the implementation of preventive services in a health maintenance organization (HMO) practice. The objective is to evaluate the effectiveness of various strategies and interventions aimed at promoting preventive care within the HMO setting. The study includes a review of the literature on successful implementation strategies, barriers encountered, and potential solutions. Key preventive services such as vaccinations, screenings, and counseling are emphasized. The study also examines the role of healthcare providers, patients, and electronic health records in facilitating the delivery of preventive services. Findings suggest that a multifaceted approach involving provider education, patient engagement, and systematic reminders can effectively increase the utilization of preventive services in HMO practices. Further research is needed to assess the long-term impact and sustainability of these interventions.

Social networks, health, and emotional well-being among the oldest old in London. This study examined the relationship between social networks, health, and emotional well-being among the oldest old population in London. A total of 250 individuals aged 85 and older were surveyed, and their social network size, social participation, and perceived emotional well-being were assessed. The results showed that a larger social network size was significantly associated with better self-reported health and emotional well-being. Additionally, higher levels of social participation were also associated with better self-reported health and emotional well-being. These associations remained significant after controlling for demographic factors. Furthermore, the results indicated that social networks and social participation were more strongly related to emotional well-being than to physical health. This study highlights the importance of social networks and social participation in promoting emotional well-being among the oldest old population in London and suggests that interventions targeting social engagement may be beneficial in improving their overall well-being.

Magnetic resonance imaging in the preoperative evaluation of cervical radiculopathy. We evaluated the effectiveness of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in detecting cervical radiculopathy preoperatively. A total of 57 patients with suspected cervical radiculopathy underwent MRI imaging. The patients were then divided into two groups: those with confirmed radiculopathy (n=38) and those without (n=19). MRI scans revealed abnormalities consistent with radiculopathy in 36 out of the 38 confirmed cases, resulting in a sensitivity of 94.7%. In the control group, MRI scans showed no abnormalities in 18 of the 19 patients, giving a specificity of 94.7%. The positive predictive value was 97.4% and the negative predictive value was 94.7%. Overall, MRI imaging demonstrated high accuracy in diagnosing cervical radiculopathy, making it a valuable tool in the preoperative evaluation of patients with suspected radiculopathy.

Severe hypertension after liver transplantation in alpha 1 antitrypsin deficiency. Alpha 1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD) is a genetic disorder associated with liver and lung disease. Severe hypertension (HTN) following liver transplantation (LT) in AATD is a rare but serious complication. We present a case of a 45-year-old male with AATD who developed severe HTN shortly after LT. The patient had no history of HTN prior to surgery and was not on antihypertensive medications. Evaluation revealed no other identifiable cause of HTN. The patient was started on multiple antihypertensive medications, resulting in blood pressure control. This case highlights the importance of considering AATD as a potential etiology for severe post-LT HTN and the need for early recognition and management to prevent complications.
