Quality of life in elderly, chronically ill outpatients.  Quality of life (QL) in elderly outpatients is poorly characterized. The quality of life (QL) in elderly outpatients with chronic illness is relatively unknown and poorly characterized. This study aims to evaluate the QL of elderly outpatients with chronic illness and identify factors that may influence QL in this population. Data was collected from a sample of elderly outpatients with various chronic illnesses, including cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and chronic respiratory disease. QL was assessed using validated self-report questionnaires, including the Medical Outcomes Study Short Form-36 (SF-36). Social, demographic, and clinical factors were also assessed to determine their association with QL. Preliminary analysis revealed that elderly outpatients with chronic illness generally have poorer QL compared to the general population. Additionally, factors such as age, comorbidity burden, and levels of social support were found to significantly impact QL in this population. This study provides important insights into the QL of elderly outpatients and highlights the need for targeted interventions to improve their QL.

Comparison of structure, mechanical properties, and functions of lumbar spinal ligaments. The lumbar spinal ligaments play a critical role in stabilizing the spine and allowing for proper movement. This study aimed to compare the structure, mechanical properties, and functions of various lumbar spinal ligaments.  Biomechanical testing was conducted on ligament specimens obtained from cadavers. The ligaments examined included the anterior longitudinal ligament (ALL), posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL), ligamentum flavum (LF), interspinous ligament (ISL), supraspinous ligament (SSL), and facet capsules (FC). It was found that the ALL and PLL were composed of dense collagen fibers, providing strong structural support. The LF exhibited a unique elastic behavior, allowing it to effectively absorb and distribute loads. The ISL and SSL played a crucial role in limiting flexion and extension of the spine. The FC provided guidance and stability to the facet joints. This comprehensive understanding of the structural and functional characteristics of lumbar spinal ligaments is essential for developing effective treatment strategies for spinal pathologies and improving surgical interventions. Further research exploring the interplay between ligaments and spinal biomechanics is warranted.

Management of penile gunshot wounds. Penile gunshot wounds are a rare but potentially devastating injury. The management of these wounds requires prompt evaluation and intervention to minimize morbidity and preserve penile function. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the management strategies and outcomes of patients with penile gunshot wounds. A total of 62 patients were included, with a median age of 32 years. The majority of injuries were due to intentional self-harm or assault. The most common initial management approach was primary repair (61.3%), followed by conservative wound care (30.6%) and surgical exploration (8.1%). Complications were observed in 37.1% of cases, with infection being the most frequent. Overall, the majority of patients (91.9%) achieved successful penile preservation and functional outcomes. The study highlights the importance of early intervention and appropriate management techniques in the successful treatment of penile gunshot wounds.

Ocular complications of rheumatic diseases of childhood. Rheumatic diseases in childhood can lead to various ocular complications. We present a retrospective analysis of ocular complications in pediatric patients with rheumatic diseases. Among a total of 98 patients, ocular complications were observed in 35 (35.7%) cases. Uveitis was the most common ocular complication, affecting 68.6% of the patients with ocular involvement. Other notable complications included episcleritis, keratoconjunctivitis sicca, and scleritis. Systemic lupus erythematosus was associated with the highest proportion of ocular complications (22.9%), followed by juvenile idiopathic arthritis (14.3%) and Kawasaki disease (11.4%). Regular ophthalmologic screening and prompt intervention are crucial in preserving visual function and preventing long-term ocular damage in children with rheumatic diseases. Further studies are needed to explore the potential risk factors and optimal management strategies for ocular complications in this population.

The Maylard incision in gynecologic surgery The transverse muscle-splitting Maylard incision was used in 175 gynecologic patients who required pelvic-abdominal surgery. This study reports the use of the transverse muscle-splitting Maylard incision in 175 gynecologic patients undergoing pelvic-abdominal surgery. The Maylard incision is known for providing excellent exposure to the pelvic organs and minimizing postoperative pain. In this cohort, the incision was performed without any major complications or conversion to alternative incisions. The average length of hospital stay was within the expected range, and there were no instances of wound infection or dehiscence. Overall, the Maylard incision proved to be a safe and effective approach for gynecologic procedures, allowing for optimal surgical outcomes and patient satisfaction. Further studies could compare this approach to other incision techniques to determine its superiority in specific clinical scenarios.

Effect of motilin on gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis. Gastroparesis is a common complication of diabetes, characterized by delayed gastric emptying. Motilin, a gastrointestinal hormone, plays a vital role in promoting gastric motility. However, its effect on gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis remains unclear. In this study, we aimed to investigate the effect of motilin on gastric emptying in these patients. 
Twenty patients with diabetic gastroparesis were enrolled and randomly assigned to receive either motilin or placebo for four weeks. Gastric emptying scintigraphy was performed before and after the treatment period to assess the rate of gastric emptying. Our results showed that patients receiving motilin had a significantly faster gastric emptying rate compared to those receiving placebo. Additionally, motilin treatment was well-tolerated and did not cause any severe adverse effects. These findings suggest that motilin can improve gastric emptying in patients with diabetic gastroparesis, highlighting its potential as a therapeutic option for this condition. Further studies are warranted to explore the optimal dosage and long-term effects of motilin in this patient population.

Isolated erythroid hypoplasia and renal insufficiency induced by long-term griseofulvin therapy. We present a case of a 45-year-old male with isolated erythroid hypoplasia and renal insufficiency induced by long-term griseofulvin therapy. The patient was diagnosed with tinea capitis and was treated with griseofulvin for 5 months. Three months into therapy, he developed fatigue, dyspnea, and pallor. Laboratory tests revealed severe normocytic anemia with reticulocytopenia and reduced erythropoietin levels. Bone marrow biopsy showed marked erythroid hypoplasia with normal myeloid and megakaryocytic cell lines. Renal function tests revealed elevated serum creatinine levels and decreased glomerular filtration rate. A renal biopsy demonstrated interstitial nephritis and tubular degenerative changes. The patient's clinical symptoms and laboratory abnormalities improved after discontinuation of griseofulvin therapy and initiation of supportive care. This case highlights a rare complication of griseofulvin therapy and emphasizes the importance of monitoring renal function and hematologic parameters during long-term use of this antifungal medication. Physicians should be aware of this potential adverse effect and consider alternative treatments in patients at risk for renal impairment.

Doppler diagnostics, indications, and control of surgical treatment in patients with carotid pathology. Carotid pathology is a common condition that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality if left untreated. Doppler diagnostics has emerged as a valuable tool in the evaluation of carotid disease, providing information on plaque characteristics, stenosis severity, and hemodynamic effects on cerebral circulation. This abstract aims to review the indications for surgical treatment in patients with carotid pathology and highlight the role of Doppler imaging in guiding management decisions. By accurately assessing the degree of stenosis and identifying high-risk features, Doppler diagnostics can help identify patients who would benefit from carotid endarterectomy or stenting. Additionally, postoperative Doppler surveillance allows for monitoring of graft patency and detection of restenosis. Understanding the role of Doppler in the management of carotid pathology can lead to improved outcomes and patient selection for surgical intervention.

The neuromuscular pathology of the Eosinophilia-Myalgia syndrome.  The Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome (EMS) is a recently reorganized disorder in patients ingesting pharmacologic doses of L-tryptophan. Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome (EMS) is a disorder that has been associated with the ingestion of high doses of L-tryptophan. The syndrome is characterized by eosinophilia and myalgia, with patients experiencing muscle pain, weakness, and fatigue. The exact mechanism underlying the neuromuscular pathology of EMS remains unclear. However, a number of studies have suggested possible immune-mediated and toxic mechanisms. Histopathological examination of affected muscles has revealed perifascicular atrophy, endomysial fibrosis, and infiltration of eosinophils and lymphocytes. Additionally, electron microscopy has shown abnormalities in muscle mitochondria and glycogen deposition. The presence of autoantibodies and elevated levels of cytokines in EMS patients suggest an immune system involvement. Further research is needed to fully understand the pathogenesis of EMS and develop effective treatment strategies for this debilitating condition.

Atonic pupil: an unusual complication of cataract surgery. Atonic pupil, characterized by a dilated and non-reactive pupil, is a rare complication of cataract surgery. We report the case of a 62-year-old male who presented with unilateral atonic pupil three weeks after uneventful cataract surgery. Ophthalmologic examination revealed a dilated pupil that did not constrict with light or accommodation. Adie's tonic pupil was suspected based on clinical findings and confirmed with pharmacological testing. The patient was managed conservatively with close monitoring for any associated symptoms. Atonic pupil following cataract surgery is extremely rare but should be considered in patients presenting with persistent pupil dilation. Prompt recognition and appropriate management are essential to prevent unnecessary investigations and potential complications.

Lumbar spinal nerves in the neural foramen: MR appearance. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the magnetic resonance (MR) appearance of lumbar spinal nerves within the neural foramen. MR images of 50 patients were retrospectively reviewed. The images were assessed for the presence or absence of lumbar spinal nerves within the neural foramen and the degree of nerve compression. The majority of nerves (82%) were visualized within the foramen, with the L5 nerve being the most commonly seen. The degree of compression varied among the nerves, with the L2 nerve being most frequently compressed. The MR imaging findings were compared with surgical findings in 16 patients who underwent surgery. The results showed a strong correlation between the MR appearance and surgical findings of nerve compression. This study provides valuable information regarding the MR appearance of lumbar spinal nerves within the neural foramen, which can aid in the diagnosis and management of nerve compression in patients with low back pain.

Synergistic effects of INTERCEED(TC7) and heparin in reducing adhesion formation in the rabbit uterine horn model. This study aimed to evaluate the synergistic effects of INTERCEED(TC7) and heparin in reducing adhesion formation in a rabbit uterine horn model. Eighteen rabbits underwent bilateral uterine horn injury, and were divided into three groups: INTERCEED(TC7) group, heparin group, and combined INTERCEED(TC7) and heparin group. Adhesion scores were assessed at 2 and 4 weeks post-injury. Histological examination and immunohistochemical analysis of angiogenesis markers were also performed. The combined INTERCEED(TC7) and heparin group showed significantly lower adhesion scores compared to the other two groups at both time points. Histological examination revealed decreased fibrosis and inflammation in the combined group. Immunohistochemical analysis showed reduced angiogenesis in the combined group compared to the other groups. These findings suggest that the combination of INTERCEED(TC7) and heparin has synergistic effects in reducing adhesion formation in the rabbit uterine horn model, possibly through inhibition of angiogenesis. This combination may have potential clinical applications in preventing postoperative adhesions following uterine surgeries.

Intra-abdominal "angiosarcomatosis" report of two cases after pelvic irradiation. We report two cases of intra-abdominal "angiosarcomatosis" occurring after pelvic irradiation. Angiosarcomatosis is a rare malignancy characterized by the presence of multiple angiosarcomatous lesions involving multiple organ systems. In both cases, the patients had a history of pelvic irradiation for gynecological malignancies several years prior to the diagnosis. Radiological imaging revealed multiple nodular lesions scattered throughout the liver, spleen, and abdominal wall. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of angiosarcoma, with vascular infiltrates displaying endothelial proliferation and atypical mitoses. Both patients underwent surgical resection of the angiosarcomatous lesions, followed by adjuvant chemotherapy and radiation therapy. However, the prognosis remains poor, with both patients experiencing disease progression despite aggressive management. These cases highlight the potential long-term complications of pelvic irradiation and the need for close surveillance in patients with a history of such treatment. Further studies are required to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of radiation-induced angiosarcomatosis and explore potential preventive strategies.

The risk for systemic vascular diseases and mortality in patients with central retinal vein occlusion.  In this cross-sectional study, the authors evaluated 197 patients diagnosed with central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) at the Wilmer Ophthalmological Institute between 1980 and 1985 to determine the risk of systemic disease and mortality. In this retrospective cross-sectional study, the authors investigated the risk of systemic vascular diseases and mortality in 197 patients diagnosed with central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) at the Wilmer Ophthalmological Institute between 1980 and 1985. They found a significant association between CRVO and systemic vascular diseases, including hypertension (44.7%), diabetes mellitus (25.9%), and hyperlipidemia (19.8%). The patients with CRVO also had a higher mortality rate compared to the general population. Additionally, older age, male gender, and presence of systemic vascular diseases were identified as independent risk factors for mortality in this patient population. These findings highlight the importance of close monitoring and management of systemic vascular diseases in patients with CRVO to mitigate the risk of adverse outcomes.

Mucocele of the cystic duct remnant in eight liver transplant recipients: findings at cholangiography, CT, and US.  The case histories and radiologic studies of eight liver transplant recipients who developed a mucocele of the allograft cystic duct remnant were retrospectively evaluated. We present a retrospective evaluation of eight liver transplant recipients who developed a mucocele of the allograft cystic duct remnant. Cholangiography, CT, and US findings were analyzed along with patient case histories. Mucoceles were detected at a median of 11 months post-transplantation. Imaging studies revealed dilated cystic ducts with filling defects, consistent with mucous accumulation. In one case, a mucoid mass was identified proximal to a completely obstructed cystic duct. In five cases, periductal fluid collections were observed. Two patients had associated choledocholithiasis. All patients underwent surgical intervention, and mucocele contents were consistent with mucin-filled cysts. No complications or recurrence were reported during follow-up. Awareness of this potential complication is crucial for early detection and appropriate management. Radiologic imaging plays a vital role in diagnosing and determining the extent of mucoceles in liver transplant recipients.

'Cystic papilloma' in humans? Demonstration of human papillomavirus in plantar epidermoid cysts. Plantar epidermoid cysts, also known as cutaneous cysts, are typically benign lesions that occur on the soles of the feet. However, a few reports have suggested a possible association between these cysts and human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. This study aimed to investigate the presence of HPV in plantar epidermoid cysts in humans. 
A total of 30 samples from plantar epidermoid cysts were collected and tested for HPV DNA using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis. HPV DNA was detected in 23 of the 30 samples (76.7%), with HPV types 6, 11, and 16 being the most common. Immunohistochemical staining confirmed the presence of HPV antigens in the cyst epithelium. In addition, p16INK4a overexpression, a surrogate marker for high-risk HPV infection, was observed in 6 of the HPV-positive samples (26.1%). 
These findings provide evidence of HPV infection in plantar epidermoid cysts and suggest a possible role of HPV in the pathogenesis of these lesions. Further research is needed to understand the clinical implications of this association and explore potential therapeutic approaches targeting HPV in plantar epidermoid cysts.

Flow cytometric DNA content of adenoid cystic carcinoma of submandibular gland.  Correlation of histologic features and prognosis. Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) of the submandibular gland is a rare tumor characterized by aggressive behavior and a wide range of histologic features. This study aimed to assess the prognostic value of flow cytometric DNA analysis in ACC and correlate it with histologic features. Tumor DNA content was measured using flow cytometry in 45 patients with ACC. Statistical analysis revealed a significant correlation between aneuploidy and adverse histologic features such as perineural invasion, lymphovascular invasion, and high-grade tumors. Patients with aneuploid tumors had significantly worse prognosis compared to those with diploid tumors. This study highlights the importance of flow cytometric DNA analysis in predicting the biologic behavior and prognosis of ACC, aiding in treatment decisions and patient management.

Decalcification of a choroidal osteoma. Choroidal osteoma is a rare benign intraocular tumor characterized by ossification of the choroid. In this case report, the authors describe a novel approach for treating a symptomatic choroidal osteoma by performing decalcification. The patient, a 32-year-old female, presented with decreased vision in her left eye and was diagnosed with a choroidal osteoma based on clinical and imaging findings. Due to the location and size of the tumor, traditional treatment options such as laser photocoagulation or surgical excision were deemed inappropriate. Instead, a decalcification procedure was performed using ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA). Follow-up examinations revealed improved visual acuity and regression of the lesion. Decalcification with EDTA may be a viable treatment option for selected cases of choroidal osteoma, providing an alternative to more invasive interventions.

Pelvic pain: lessons from anatomy and physiology. This paper discusses the lessons learned from the anatomy and physiology of pelvic pain. Pelvic pain is a common symptom that can arise from various sources in the pelvic region, including reproductive, urinary, gastrointestinal, and musculoskeletal systems. Understanding the complex anatomy and physiology of the pelvis is crucial in diagnosing and managing pelvic pain. The paper highlights the importance of a comprehensive history and physical examination, including assessment of pelvic floor muscle function, to identify the underlying cause of pelvic pain. Additionally, the integration of multidisciplinary approaches, such as physical therapy and psychological interventions, can provide effective treatment options for patients with chronic pelvic pain.

Expression and characterization of TCA3: a murine inflammatory protein.  TCA3 is a cDNA originally isolated from activated T cells. TCA3 is a murine inflammatory protein that was initially discovered in activated T cells. In this study, we aimed to further investigate the expression and characterization of TCA3. By utilizing various techniques such as immunoblotting, immunohistochemistry, and ELISA, we demonstrated that TCA3 is predominantly expressed in inflamed tissues. Specifically, TCA3 expression was found to be upregulated in response to inflammatory stimuli such as lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and pro-inflammatory cytokines. Furthermore, we also observed that TCA3 is secreted by activated T cells and acts as a chemoattractant for immune cells, including neutrophils and monocytes. These findings suggest that TCA3 may play a key role in the regulation of inflammation and immune responses. Future studies investigating the specific mechanisms of TCA3 function and its potential as a therapeutic target for inflammatory diseases are warranted.

Risk ratios and risk differences in estimating the effect of risk factors for cardiovascular disease in the elderly. This study aimed to evaluate the effect of different risk factors on cardiovascular disease (CVD) in the elderly population. A retrospective cohort of elderly individuals with and without CVD was analyzed. Risk ratios (RR) and risk differences (RD) were calculated for each identified risk factor. The results demonstrated that hypertension had the highest RR (2.5) and RD (0.15), indicating a significant association with CVD. Other significant risk factors included diabetes (RR: 1.8, RD: 0.10) and smoking (RR: 1.6, RD: 0.08). Obesity showed a moderate association with CVD (RR: 1.3, RD: 0.05), while physical inactivity had a weak association (RR: 1.1, RD: 0.02). Interestingly, gender did not significantly affect CVD risk. These findings highlight the importance of controlling hypertension, diabetes, and smoking in the elderly population to prevent CVD. Further research is needed to explore additional risk factors and their impact on CVD in this demographic.

Cyclosporine-induced thrombotic microangiopathy resulting in renal allograft loss and its successful reuse: a report of two cases. We present two cases of cyclosporine-induced thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) leading to renal allograft loss. Both patients experienced rapid deterioration of renal function, with histological findings consistent with TMA. Cyclosporine was discontinued, and plasmapheresis and supportive therapy were initiated. Serial renal biopsies showed resolution of TMA in both cases. Subsequently, the renal allografts were successfully retransplanted, and both patients experienced stable renal function without recurrence of TMA. These cases highlight the importance of early recognition and prompt management of cyclosporine-induced TMA in order to preserve renal allograft function.

Laparoscopic management of ovarian cysts. Ovarian cysts are common and can cause pain, infertility, and other complications. Laparoscopic management has become the preferred surgical approach due to its advantages over open surgery, including shorter hospital stays, less postoperative pain, and faster recovery time. In this abstract, we present a retrospective analysis of laparoscopic management of ovarian cysts in a cohort of 100 patients. The surgical technique involved cystectomy or oophorectomy depending on the size, location, and nature of the cyst. Our results show a high success rate with minimal intraoperative and postoperative complications. Laparoscopic management of ovarian cysts is a safe and effective approach that offers numerous benefits for patients.

Facial muscle reanimation using the trigeminal motor nerve: an experimental study in the rabbit. This study aimed to investigate the potential of trigeminal motor nerve stimulation in reanimating facial muscles in a rabbit model. Facial nerve palsy, resulting from various causes, can greatly impact a patient's quality of life. In this experimental study, we utilized the trigeminal motor nerve as an alternative route for facial muscle reanimation. Through surgical procedures and electrical stimulation, we successfully induced contractions in the facial muscles of rabbits. Histological analysis revealed axonal regeneration and functional recovery of the paralyzed muscles. These findings suggest the potential of trigeminal motor nerve stimulation as a viable approach for facial muscle reanimation, offering a promising alternative for patients with facial nerve palsy.

Radical resection for carcinoma of the ampulla of Vater.  One hundred four consecutive patients who underwent radical resection for ampullary cancer between 1965 and 1989 were retrospectively reviewed. This retrospective study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of radical resection in patients with ampullary cancer. A total of 104 consecutive patients who underwent radical resection between 1965 and 1989 were included in the analysis. The surgical management involved a comprehensive removal of the tumor along with adjacent lymph nodes and organs if necessary. The overall survival rate at 5 years was 49%, with a median survival of 24 months. The presence of lymph node metastasis and advanced tumor stage were associated with poorer outcomes. Complications were seen in 33% of patients, with the most common being wound infection and bile leak. Radical resection offers a potential curative option for patients with ampullary cancer, although the procedure is associated with risks and complications. Further studies are needed to assess the long-term outcomes and refine the surgical approach.

Lateral medullary infarction: prognosis in an unselected series.  We describe the acute and long-term prognosis in 43 patients with lateral medullary infarction (LMI) collected from a population-based stroke registry from 1982 to July 1988. This study aims to investigate the prognosis of lateral medullary infarction (LMI) in an unselected series of 43 patients from a population-based stroke registry. The patients were collected from 1982 to July 1988. The acute and long-term prognosis were analyzed. The study found that at presentation, common symptoms included vertigo, limb ataxia, dysarthria, and Horner syndrome. In 25 patients, angiography was performed, with 11 showing vertebral artery stenosis or occlusion. Follow-up assessments were done at a mean of 4.7 years after the initial event. The long-term prognosis was favorable, with 38 patients showing complete recovery or minor disability. Only two patients had severe disability and three patients died during the follow-up period. This study demonstrates a generally positive prognosis for patients with LMI, indicating the importance of early recognition and appropriate management of the condition.

Carcinoma of female urethra.  Manitoba experience: 1958-1987. This retrospective study aims to analyze the experience of female urethral carcinoma in Manitoba from 1958 to 1987. A total of 33 cases were identified from the Manitoba Cancer Treatment and Research Foundation's database. The clinical and pathological data were reviewed to determine key factors related to the disease. The average age at diagnosis was 62 years, with the majority of patients presenting with advanced disease (85%). Squamous cell carcinoma was the most common histological subtype (76%), followed by transitional cell carcinoma (15%). The main presenting symptom was hematuria (79%), followed by dysuria (61%). The overall survival rate at 5 years was 24%, with a median survival of 16 months. Poorer prognosis was associated with advanced tumor stage, lymph node involvement, and distant metastasis. This study provides valuable insights into the epidemiology, clinical presentation, and prognosis of female urethral carcinoma in Manitoba.

Rehabilitation in brain disorders.  4. Rehabilitation is a crucial component in the management of brain disorders. This review article aims to provide an overview of current evidence and advancements in rehabilitation strategies for various brain disorders. It highlights the importance of multidisciplinary approaches and individualized treatment plans in improving functional outcomes and quality of life for patients.

Specific focus is given to stroke rehabilitation, traumatic brain injury rehabilitation, and neurodegenerative disorders rehabilitation such as Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's disease. Various rehabilitation interventions including physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, and cognitive rehabilitation are discussed.

The review also emphasizes the integration of technology and innovation in rehabilitation, such as virtual reality and robotics, which have shown promising results in enhancing motor and cognitive recovery. Additionally, the role of neuroplasticity and neurorehabilitation in promoting brain recovery and reorganization is explored.

While significant progress has been made in the field of brain disorder rehabilitation, further research is needed to optimize and tailor rehabilitation interventions to individual patients. The ultimate goal is to maximize functional independence and improve overall quality of life for individuals with brain disorders.

DNA ploidy pattern in rectal carcinoid tumors. The DNA ploidy pattern in rectal carcinoid tumors was analyzed in a study of 30 patients using flow cytometry. The majority of tumors (87%) showed a diploid DNA content, indicating a benign or low malignant potential. Only four tumors (13%) displayed an aneuploid DNA content, suggesting a higher malignant potential. The aneuploid tumors were associated with larger tumor size and lymph node metastasis, suggesting an advanced stage of disease. No significant correlation was found between DNA ploidy pattern and age, gender, or production of hormones. The findings indicate that the DNA ploidy pattern may serve as a useful prognostic indicator for rectal carcinoid tumors, with aneuploid tumors associated with a more aggressive clinical course. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and explore potential therapeutic implications.

Sensitivity and specificity of various morphological features of cervical condylomas. Cervical condylomas are a common sexually transmitted infection caused by human papillomavirus. Morphological features of cervical condylomas are often used for diagnosis and management decisions, but their sensitivity and specificity are not well-defined. In this study, we aimed to determine the sensitivity and specificity of various morphological features of cervical condylomas. A total of 100 patients with histologically confirmed cervical condylomas were included. The sensitivity of classic cauliflower-like papillary architecture, acanthosis, koilocytosis, and hyperkeratosis were found to be 92%, 82%, 76%, and 68%, respectively. The specificity ranged from 84% to 94% for these features. These findings highlight the importance of considering various morphological features in the diagnosis and management of cervical condylomas.

Nursing home patients transferred by ambulance to a VA emergency department.  Nursing home residents are frequently transferred to hospital emergency departments. Transferring nursing home patients to hospital emergency departments is a common occurrence. These transfers often involve older adults who may have complex medical conditions and require specialized care. Understanding the reasons for these transfers is vital to optimize patient outcomes and resource allocation. This retrospective study aimed to analyze the reasons for ambulance transfers of nursing home residents to a Veterans Affairs (VA) emergency department. Data was collected from ambulatory transport records and electronic medical records of 250 patients. The most common reasons for transfer included altered mental status, respiratory distress, falls, and chest pain. The majority of patients were transferred during weekdays and during regular business hours. This study provides valuable insights into the patterns and reasons for ambulance transfers of nursing home residents to a VA emergency department. Further research is necessary to develop strategies for optimizing healthcare delivery to this vulnerable population and potentially reducing the need for transfers.

Association of disease-free survival and percent of ideal dose in adjuvant breast chemotherapy. This study aimed to determine the association between disease-free survival (DFS) and the percent of the ideal dose received during adjuvant breast chemotherapy. Data from 300 breast cancer patients who received adjuvant chemotherapy were analyzed. The percent of the ideal dose received was calculated for each patient, with 100% representing the full prescribed dose. Kaplan-Meier analysis and Cox proportional hazards modeling were used to assess DFS. The median percent of the ideal dose received was 90%. Patients who received a higher percent of the ideal dose had significantly better DFS compared to those who received a lower percent (p<0.001). Cox regression analysis confirmed that a higher percent of the ideal dose was independently associated with improved DFS (HR 0.72, 95% CI 0.60-0.87, p=0.001). These findings suggest that receiving a higher percent of the ideal dose during adjuvant breast chemotherapy may improve DFS and should be considered in treatment planning.

Coronary collateral recruitment: functional significance and relation to rate of vessel closure.  Studies in animals and humans have demonstrated the anatomic presence and functional significance of coronary collaterals. Coronary collateral recruitment is a well-documented phenomenon in both animals and humans. This abstract reviews the existing studies that have demonstrated the presence and functional significance of coronary collaterals. These collaterals serve as alternative pathways for blood flow when there is a blockage in the main coronary artery. The rate of vessel closure, i.e., the speed at which the main artery becomes completely occluded, has been found to be inversely related to the extent of collateral recruitment. Studies have shown that a higher collateral recruitment can significantly delay the onset of myocardial ischemia and limit the size of the resulting infarction. Therefore, understanding the factors that influence collateral recruitment and finding ways to enhance it could potentially have important implications for the management and treatment of coronary artery disease.

Metastatic small cell tumor of bone with 'true' rosettes and glial fibrillary acidic protein positivity. Metastatic small cell tumor of bone is a rare entity with only a few reported cases. We present a case of a 55-year-old male who presented with pain and swelling in the right thigh. Radiographic imaging showed a lytic lesion in the proximal femur, which was biopsied. Histopathological examination revealed small round blue cells forming 'true' rosettes and positive immunohistochemical staining for synaptophysin and chromogranin. Interestingly, the tumor cells also showed positive staining for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), which is typically seen in glial tumors. Further investigations ruled out primary central nervous system neoplasms, confirming the diagnosis of metastatic small cell tumor of bone. This case highlights the importance of recognizing the rare occurrence of metastatic small cell tumor of bone and the utility of GFAP staining in the diagnosis. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathogenesis and optimal management of this rare tumor.

Extrahepatic portal vein aneurysm associated with a tortuous portal vein. We report a case of an extrahepatic portal vein aneurysm associated with a tortuous portal vein in a patient with no underlying liver disease or portal hypertension. A 52-year-old male presented with mild intermittent abdominal pain and was found to have an incidental discovery of a portal vein aneurysm on abdominal imaging. Further evaluation with computed tomography angiography revealed a tortuous portal vein leading to the aneurysm. The patient underwent surgical resection of the aneurysm, which was confirmed histologically. Extrahepatic portal vein aneurysms are extremely rare, and their association with a tortuous portal vein is even more uncommon. The etiology of these findings remains unclear, and further research is necessary to better understand the pathophysiology and optimal management of this condition. Clinicians should be aware of this rare presentation and consider it in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with abdominal pain or other portal vein-related symptoms.

Pancreaticobiliary ductal union. The pancreaticobiliary ductal union refers to the anatomical connection between the pancreatic duct and the common bile duct. A study was conducted to evaluate the prevalence and clinical significance of different types of pancreaticobiliary ductal union. A total of 256 patients undergoing endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) were included in the study. The types of pancreaticobiliary ductal union were classified into four categories: normal, incomplete, accessory, and anomalous. The results showed that the most common type of pancreaticobiliary ductal union was normal (67.2%), followed by incomplete (24.2%), accessory (7.8%), and anomalous (0.8%). Patients with anomalous pancreaticobiliary ductal union had a higher incidence of biliary stones and pancreatitis. In conclusion, the pancreaticobiliary ductal union has clinical implications and should be carefully evaluated during ERCP to guide appropriate management.

Benign missense variations in the cystic fibrosis gene. This review focuses on benign missense variations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene. Numerous missense variations have been identified in CFTR, ranging from common polymorphisms to rare mutations. While some missense variations are known to cause cystic fibrosis (CF), others have been classified as benign due to their lack of disease-causing effects. However, recent evidence suggests that these variants may still have functional consequences and contribute to disease susceptibility or phenotypic variability. This review discusses the classification and functional characterization of benign missense variations in CFTR, emphasizing their potential effects on protein structure, function, and cellular regulation. Understanding the impact of these variants is vital for accurate genetic counseling, risk prediction, and future therapeutic interventions in CF patients. Further research is needed to elucidate the functional significance and clinical implications of these benign missense variations in CFTR.

Polyglucosan body disease.  Adult polyglucosan disease has been described in 15 cases. Polyglucosan body disease is a rare disorder characterized by the accumulation of abnormal glycogen deposits, known as polyglucosan bodies. This condition primarily affects the central nervous system and can present with various neurological symptoms. In this study, 15 cases of adult polyglucosan disease were analyzed. Clinical and pathological findings were evaluated, and common features were identified. The most frequent clinical manifestations included weakness, sensory disturbances, and difficulty in walking. Pathological examinations revealed the presence of polyglucosan bodies in various tissues, including the brain, spinal cord, and peripheral nerves. Although the disease remains poorly understood, early recognition and diagnosis are crucial for appropriate management and treatment. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and develop effective therapeutic strategies.

Susceptibility to invasive Haemophilus influenzae type b disease and the immunoglobulin G2m(n) allotype. Invasive Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) disease is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality, particularly in children. Although the development of vaccines has substantially reduced the incidence of Hib disease, there are still variations in disease susceptibility among individuals. Recent studies have investigated the role of immunoglobulin G2m(n) allotypes in modulating the immune response to Hib. This review explores the available evidence linking specific allotypes with susceptibility to Hib disease and discusses the potential implications for vaccine development and immunization strategies. Understanding the genetic factors influencing susceptibility to Hib infection can contribute to the development of personalized approaches to vaccination, improving overall disease prevention and control.

Effects of prostaglandin E1 on collagen diseases with high levels of circulating immune complexes. This study investigated the effects of prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) on collagen diseases characterized by high levels of circulating immune complexes (CIC). A total of 45 patients were enrolled in the study, with 25 receiving PGE1 treatment and 20 serving as controls. The patients' clinical symptoms, CIC levels, and immunological parameters were assessed before and after treatment. The results showed that PGE1 treatment led to a significant reduction in CIC levels and improvement in clinical symptoms, such as joint pain, skin lesions, and fatigue. Furthermore, PGE1 treatment also resulted in favorable changes in immunological parameters, including decreased serum levels of rheumatoid factor and increased levels of complement components. These findings suggest that PGE1 may be an effective therapeutic option for collagen diseases with high levels of CIC.

Acute syphilitic posterior placoid chorioretinitis.  Six patients with evidence of secondary syphilis presented with visual loss in both eyes caused by large, placoid, yellowish lesions with faded centers at the level of the pigment epithelium in the macula and juxtapapillary areas. Six patients with evidence of secondary syphilis presented with visual loss in both eyes due to large, placoid, yellowish lesions with faded centers in the macula and juxtapapillary areas. The lesions were observed at the level of the pigment epithelium and were characterized as acute syphilitic posterior placoid chorioretinitis. The patients all had positive serological tests for syphilis and showed improvement in visual acuity after receiving appropriate treatment with intravenous penicillin. Acute syphilitic posterior placoid chorioretinitis is a rare manifestation of secondary syphilis and can lead to significant visual impairment if not promptly diagnosed and treated. Ophthalmologists should be aware of this condition and include syphilis as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with similar retinal lesions.

Extrapyramidal features in advanced Down's syndrome: clinical evaluation and family history.  Extrapyramidal, frontal release, and other neurological signs were studied in 54 demented and non-demented patients with Down's syndrome (DS). Extrapyramidal features, including frontal release signs, have been observed in patients with Down's syndrome (DS). In this study, we evaluated the presence of extrapyramidal and other neurological signs in 54 DS patients, both with and without dementia. The patients were assessed using clinical evaluation and their family history was also taken into consideration. Our findings revealed the presence of extrapyramidal features in a significant number of both demented and non-demented DS patients. Furthermore, frontal release signs and other neurological abnormalities were observed in a subset of patients. These findings suggest that extrapyramidal dysfunction may be a common feature in DS and should be considered during clinical evaluation. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential implications of these findings for the management and treatment of DS patients.

Thoracoscopic treatment of spontaneous pneumothorax using carbon dioxide laser. This study evaluates the effectiveness of thoracoscopic treatment using carbon dioxide laser in patients with spontaneous pneumothorax. A total of 58 patients underwent thoracoscopic surgery using carbon dioxide laser for spontaneous pneumothorax. The carbon dioxide laser was used for the resection of bullae and pleural blebs. The success rate of the procedure, defined as absence of recurrence of pneumothorax at 1-year follow-up, was 94.8%. The average duration of surgery was 50 minutes, and the average length of hospital stay was 2.5 days. Postoperative complications were minimal, with only 2 patients developing surgical site infections. The use of carbon dioxide laser resulted in precise and efficient resection of bullae and pleural blebs, leading to a high success rate and low morbidity. Thoracoscopic treatment with carbon dioxide laser is a safe and effective option for the management of spontaneous pneumothorax. Further studies are needed to compare its outcomes with other surgical approaches.

Use of the metabolic tracer carbon-11-acetate for evaluation of regional myocardial perfusion.  The high first-pass myocardial extraction fraction of carbon-11-acetate suggests that its initial uptake depends on blood flow.  Accordingly, regional uptake of 11C-acetate at 4 min was compared to regional perfusion determined with nitrogen-13-ammonia in 119 segments in 15 patients with stable coronary artery disease by two methods.  A close correlation was observed between initial relative myocardial concentrations (segmental activity normalized to maximal activity) of both tracers (11C-acetate = 0. 88; 13N-ammonia + 0. This study aimed to evaluate the regional myocardial perfusion using the metabolic tracer carbon-11-acetate. The results showed a high first-pass myocardial extraction fraction of carbon-11-acetate, indicating its dependence on blood flow for initial uptake. The researchers compared the regional uptake of 11C-acetate with regional perfusion determined with nitrogen-13-ammonia in 15 patients with stable coronary artery disease. A strong correlation was observed between the initial relative myocardial concentrations of both tracers, suggesting that carbon-11-acetate can be a reliable indicator of regional myocardial perfusion. These findings highlight the potential clinical utility of carbon-11-acetate in assessing myocardial perfusion in patients with coronary artery disease.

Prehospital care: the future of emergency medical services. Prehospital care plays a crucial role in the management of emergency medical services (EMS). This abstract examines the future of prehospital care and its potential impact on EMS. Advances in technology and medical knowledge have paved the way for innovative approaches, including telemedicine, remote monitoring, and real-time communication between EMS providers and hospitals. These advancements have the potential to enhance the timeliness and quality of care provided in the prehospital setting. Additionally, the integration of mobile health applications and wearable devices allows for early detection and intervention, improving patient outcomes. Furthermore, community paramedicine programs aim to extend the scope of prehospital care beyond traditional emergency response, providing preventive care, chronic disease management, and reducing hospital readmissions. The future of prehospital care holds promising opportunities to optimize EMS and improve patient care across the healthcare continuum.

Colposcopic survey of Papanicolaou test-negative cases with hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis. A colposcopic survey was conducted on Papanicolaou test-negative cases with hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis. A total of [number] patients were included in the study. The findings revealed [details of the colposcopic survey]. The results suggest that colposcopy may be a valuable tool in the evaluation of Papanicolaou test-negative cases with hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis, providing additional diagnostic information that may have been missed by cytology alone. Further research is needed to investigate the significance and clinical implications of these findings, and to determine if colposcopy should be routinely performed in such cases to improve detection and management of cervical abnormalities.

Fluorosilicone oil in the treatment of retinal detachment. Fluorosilicone oil has been extensively used in the treatment of retinal detachment, particularly in cases where conventional methods fail or are not appropriate. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of fluorosilicone oil in the management of retinal detachment. A total of 80 eyes from 75 patients with retinal detachment were included in the study. The primary outcome measures were anatomical success, visual acuity outcomes, and complications. Anatomical success, defined as retinal reattachment without the need for further surgical intervention, was achieved in 79 eyes (98.8%). Visual acuity improved or remained stable in 71 eyes (88.8%) at the final follow-up. Complications occurred in 12 eyes (15%), with cataract being the most common. No cases of oil emulsification or ocular hypertension were observed. Fluorosilicone oil proved to be an effective and safe option for the treatment of retinal detachment, providing favorable anatomical and visual outcomes while minimizing complications in our patient cohort.

Human immunodeficiency virus-induced immunosuppression: a risk factor for human papillomavirus infection.  In a group of 92 women with genital condylomata, 15 (16. Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is a significant risk factor for the development of genital condylomata, but the influence of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) induced immunosuppression on HPV infection is less clear. We conducted a study involving 92 women with genital condylomata to determine if HIV infection increases the risk of HPV infection. Of the women, 15 (16.3%) were found to be HIV positive. HPV DNA testing was performed on all participants, and HPV infection was detected in 83 (90.2%) women. Interestingly, a higher prevalence of high-risk HPV strains was observed in HIV positive individuals compared to HIV negative individuals (86.7% versus 54.5%, p<0.05). Our findings suggest that HIV induced immunosuppression may increase the risk of acquiring high-risk HPV strains, emphasizing the importance of HPV screening and prevention strategies in HIV positive individuals.

Kinin/prostaglandin system: its therapeutic value in surgical stress. The kinin/prostaglandin system plays a crucial role in the body's response to surgical stress. This abstract summarizes the therapeutic potential of modulating this system for managing surgical stress. Activation of the kinin/prostaglandin system leads to local inflammation, pain, vasodilation, and increased vascular permeability. These responses, although initially protective, can become excessive, leading to tissue damage and other adverse effects. Several pharmacological interventions have been developed to target this system and attenuate the inflammatory response during surgery. This includes the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), selective cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitors, and bradykinin receptor antagonists. These interventions have shown promise in reducing surgical pain, improving wound healing, and preventing postoperative complications. However, further research is needed to optimize dosing regimens, minimize adverse effects, and evaluate long-term outcomes. Understanding the complex interactions of the kinin/prostaglandin system in surgical stress and identifying novel therapeutic targets will ultimately contribute to improving patient outcomes and reducing surgical morbidity.

Buerger's colour.  Cyanosis of the hands and feet in Buerger's disease is known as 'Buerger's colour'. Buerger's disease is a rare and debilitating condition characterized by chronic inflammation and occlusion of small and medium-sized arteries of the hands and feet. Cyanosis of the hands and feet, known as 'Buerger's colour', is a prominent clinical feature of this disease. The exact cause of Buerger's disease remains unknown, but it is strongly associated with tobacco smoking. Diagnosis is mainly clinical, with characteristic findings on physical examination and confirmed by angiography. Treatment involves immediate cessation of smoking, as well as supportive measures such as pain management and wound care. Immunosuppressive therapy and vasodilators may be beneficial in selected cases. Despite these interventions, the prognosis of Buerger's disease remains guarded, with a high risk of amputation and progressive disability. Thus, early recognition and intervention are crucial to improve outcomes in this challenging vascular disorder.

Computed tomography-guided fine-needle aspiration of retroperitoneal lymph nodes in gynecologic oncology. Computed tomography (CT)-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA) is a valuable tool in the diagnosis and staging of gynecologic malignancies. In this study, we present our experience with CT-guided FNA of retroperitoneal lymph nodes in gynecologic oncology patients. A total of 50 patients with suspected or confirmed gynecologic malignancies underwent CT-guided FNA of retroperitoneal lymph nodes for diagnostic or staging purposes. The procedure was performed under local anesthesia, and a 22-gauge needle was used for FNA. Adequate samples for cytological evaluation were obtained in 96% of cases. The most common indication for CT-guided FNA was the presence of enlarged retroperitoneal lymph nodes on imaging. Cytological analysis showed malignant cells in 40% of cases, confirming nodal metastasis. Among patients with positive FNA results, subsequent treatment decisions were altered in 85% of cases. Complications related to the procedure were minimal and included mild pain and small hematoma formation at the FNA site. In conclusion, CT-guided FNA of retroperitoneal lymph nodes is a safe and effective method for diagnosing and staging gynecologic malignancies, leading to appropriate treatment modifications in a significant proportion of patients.

Causes of death in hospitalized intravenous drug abusers.  The authors reviewed at autopsy the causes of death of 274 patients with evidence of intravenous drug abuse who had been admitted to a large public hospital. This study aimed to evaluate the causes of death in hospitalized intravenous drug abusers. A total of 274 patients with evidence of intravenous drug abuse were included in the study. Autopsy reports of these patients were reviewed to determine the underlying cause of death. The majority of patients were found to have died due to drug-related complications, including drug overdose, infectious diseases (such as sepsis and endocarditis), and drug-related accidents (such as trauma or poisoning). Other causes of death included cardiovascular diseases, respiratory disorders, and liver disease. The findings of this study emphasize the significant health risks associated with intravenous drug abuse and highlight the need for appropriate interventions and preventive measures to address these issues.

Occult vascular malformations of the optic chiasm: magnetic resonance imaging diagnosis and surgical laser resection.  Angiographically occult vascular malformations of the optic nerve and chiasm are extremely rare. This case report discusses two rare cases of primary osteosarcoma of the lung. The first case initially presented as undifferentiated carcinoma based on radiologic, clinical, and cytologic findings. In the second case, a lung nodule was detected during follow-up for lymphoma, but fine needle aspiration showed lymphoma cells. Despite receiving chemotherapy, the nodule continued to grow, leading to surgical resection. Microscopic examination of both resected tumors confirmed high-grade osteosarcoma. Flow cytometric analysis revealed abnormal DNA populations, characteristic of aggressive malignant neoplasms. Immunohistochemical studies supported a mesenchymal origin for the tumors. These cases exhibited similar clinical features to other reported cases of primary osteosarcoma of the lung, including large size, occurrence in older individuals, and aggressive behavior. In a separate case report, the authors discuss the diagnosis and surgical management of angiographically occult vascular malformations of the optic nerve and chiasm.

Cone cerclage in pregnancy.  We report a technique of cone cerclage and the results and outcome in 17 patients who required a diagnostic cone biopsy in pregnancy. Cone cerclage is a surgical technique used in pregnancy to prevent cervical insufficiency and subsequent preterm delivery. In this study, we present the technique and outcomes of cone cerclage in 17 pregnant patients who underwent diagnostic cone biopsy. The cerclage procedure was successful in all cases, resulting in cervical length stabilization and prevention of cervical dilation. The mean gestational age at the time of cerclage placement was 20 weeks. The average duration of the cerclage was 14 weeks, with 14 patients delivering at term and three experiencing preterm birth. No cases of cerclage failure or complications, such as infection or hemorrhage, were observed. These findings suggest that cone cerclage can be a safe and effective intervention for pregnant patients requiring diagnostic cone biopsy, preventing pregnancy loss and preterm delivery. Further studies are warranted to evaluate long-term outcomes and compare different cerclage techniques.

Regression of the left main trunk lesion by steroid administration in Takayasu's aortitis. Takayasu's aortitis is a rare inflammatory disease that affects the large blood vessels, particularly the aorta and its branches. Steroids have been used as the mainstay of treatment for this condition, but their effect on the regression of left main trunk lesions has not been extensively studied. In a case report, we present a patient with Takayasu's aortitis who showed complete regression of a left main trunk lesion following steroid administration. This finding suggests that steroids may play a crucial role in the treatment of Takayasu's aortitis by reducing inflammation and promoting healing of the affected blood vessels. Further studies are needed to establish the optimal dosage and duration of steroid therapy in this condition.

Successful control of bleeding from gastric antral vascular ectasia (watermelon stomach) by laser photocoagulation. Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE), commonly known as watermelon stomach, is a rare cause of chronic gastrointestinal bleeding. This study aims to determine the efficacy of laser photocoagulation in controlling bleeding in GAVE. Ten patients with GAVE-related bleeding refractory to conservative management were treated with laser photocoagulation. Successful hemostasis was achieved in all patients, with a significant decrease in bleeding episodes and transfusion requirements. No major complications were observed. Therefore, laser photocoagulation is a safe and effective treatment option for controlling bleeding in patients with GAVE, providing an alternative to surgery or other invasive interventions.

Fusiform dilatations of the carotid artery following radical surgery of childhood craniopharyngiomas. Fusiform dilatations of the carotid artery are a rare complication following radical surgery for childhood craniopharyngiomas. In this article, we present a case series of four patients who developed this complication after undergoing surgery for craniopharyngiomas during childhood. The mean time from surgery to the development of carotid artery dilatations was 9.5 years. The dilatations were identified on routine magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans and confirmed with magnetic resonance angiography (MRA). All patients were asymptomatic and unaware of their condition. Close follow-up with regular imaging was recommended to monitor the progression of the dilatations. Although the exact mechanism behind this complication is unclear, it is postulated that it is a result of disrupted arterial wall integrity during surgery. This case series highlights the importance of long-term monitoring for potential complications following radical surgery for childhood craniopharyngiomas.

Endoscopic treatment of biliary tract strictures in sclerosing cholangitis: a larger series and recommendations for treatment. Sclerosing cholangitis is a condition characterized by the narrowing of the biliary tract, leading to bile flow obstruction. Endoscopic treatment has emerged as an effective intervention for biliary strictures in these patients. This study aimed to evaluate the outcomes of endoscopic treatment in a larger series of sclerosing cholangitis patients and provide recommendations for treatment. A retrospective analysis of medical records identified 50 patients who underwent endoscopic treatment for biliary strictures. Success was defined as resolution of strictures or improvement in symptoms. The study found a success rate of 82% for endoscopic treatment, indicating its efficacy in managing biliary tract strictures in sclerosing cholangitis patients. Further studies and standardization of treatment protocols are warranted.

IgG and IgA antibodies to the collagen-like region of C1q in rheumatoid vasculitis. Rheumatoid vasculitis is a severe complication of rheumatoid arthritis characterized by inflammation and damage to blood vessels. In this study, we investigated the presence of IgG and IgA antibodies to the collagen-like region of C1q, a protein involved in the complement system, in patients with rheumatoid vasculitis. We found that 86% of the patients (n=50) had detectable levels of IgG antibodies to the collagen-like region of C1q, while 78% had detectable levels of IgA antibodies. The levels of these antibodies were significantly higher in patients with rheumatoid vasculitis compared to patients with rheumatoid arthritis without vasculitis. Interestingly, the presence of IgG antibodies to the collagen-like region of C1q was associated with more severe vasculitis manifestations. Our findings suggest that these antibodies may play a role in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid vasculitis and could serve as potential biomarkers for disease diagnosis and monitoring.

Ventricular responses to mental stress testing in patients with coronary artery disease. The aim of this study was to evaluate ventricular responses during mental stress testing in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD). A total of 50 CAD patients underwent mental stress testing using the Stroop color-word interference task. Echocardiography was performed to assess left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and wall motion abnormalities (WMA). Significant ventricular responses, defined as 10% decrease in LVEF or occurrence of new or worsening WMA, were observed in 24 patients (48%). The presence of ventricular responses was associated with older age, higher prevalence of hypertension and diabetes, and more severe coronary stenosis. These findings suggest that mental stress testing can elicit significant ventricular responses in CAD patients, which may have prognostic implications for cardiac outcomes. Further research is needed to evaluate the clinical significance and management strategies for these ventricular responses.

Immunoglobulins A, G, and M to cytomegalovirus during recurrent infection in recipients of allogeneic bone marrow transplantation. BACKGROUND: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is a common complication after allogeneic bone marrow transplantation (alloBMT), and recurrence is frequently observed. However, the role of immunoglobulins (Ig) A, G, and M in recurrent CMV infection remains unclear. METHODS: We evaluated the levels of CMV-specific IgA, IgG, and IgM in 30 alloBMT recipients during recurrent CMV infection. RESULTS: The levels of CMV-specific IgA and IgG were significantly higher during recurrent CMV infection compared to their levels before infection. Interestingly, the levels of CMV-specific IgM were significantly lower during recurrent infection. Moreover, the decrease in CMV-specific IgM levels correlated with the severity of the infection. CONCLUSIONS: Our findings suggest that the response of CMV-specific IgA, IgG, and IgM may play a role in the recurrence of CMV infection after alloBMT. Further studies are needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and explore the potential therapeutic implications of these findings.

Efficacy of doxazosin in specific hypertensive patient groups. This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of doxazosin in specific hypertensive patient groups. A total of 300 patients were included, divided into three groups: obese hypertensive patients, elderly hypertensive patients, and hypertensive patients with renal impairment. The patients were randomly assigned to receive either doxazosin or placebo for a duration of 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure was the reduction in systolic blood pressure. In the obese group, doxazosin significantly reduced systolic blood pressure compared to placebo (p<0.001). In the elderly group, a significant reduction in systolic blood pressure was also observed with doxazosin (p<0.01). However, in patients with renal impairment, there was no significant difference in systolic blood pressure between the doxazosin and placebo groups (p=0.342). Overall, doxazosin showed efficacy in reducing systolic blood pressure in obese and elderly hypertensive patients, but not in those with renal impairment.

Traumatic and spontaneous extracranial internal carotid artery dissections. Extracranial internal carotid artery dissections (CAD) can result from traumatic or spontaneous causes. Traumatic CAD usually occurs due to direct trauma to the neck or head, while spontaneous CAD is usually associated with connective tissue disorders or vascular abnormalities. This literature review aims to analyze the current understanding and management of both traumatic and spontaneous CAD. Traumatic CAD often presents with symptoms such as headache, neck pain, and stroke. Prompt diagnosis is crucial to prevent ischemic complications. Treatment options include anticoagulation therapy, antiplatelet therapy, endovascular intervention, or surgical reconstruction. Spontaneous CAD is more common in young patients and is often associated with connective tissue disorders such as Ehlers-Danlos syndrome or fibromuscular dysplasia. Antithrombotic therapy is the mainstay of treatment, and endovascular intervention may be indicated in certain cases. Further research is needed to refine management strategies and improve outcomes for patients with CAD.

Partial laryngectomy after irradiation failure.  Forty-three patients who had partial laryngectomies after radiotherapy were evaluated. This retrospective study evaluated the outcomes of 43 patients who underwent partial laryngectomy following failed radiation therapy. The main objective was to assess the success rate of this procedure and to identify any associated complications. The majority of patients had advanced laryngeal cancer (82%), with the remaining cases being recurrent or persistent disease. The overall success rate of partial laryngectomy in these patients was 74%. Factors associated with successful outcomes included tumor stage, site of involvement, and preoperative vocal cord mobility. The most common postoperative complications were wound infection (28%), wound breakdown (19%), and pharyngocutaneous fistula (14%). However, most of these complications were manageable and did not adversely affect long-term outcomes. In conclusion, partial laryngectomy can be a viable treatment option for patients with failed radiation therapy. Careful patient selection and close postoperative monitoring are essential for optimizing outcomes and minimizing complications.

Magnetic resonance imaging of experimental rat brain tumors: histopathological evaluation. The use of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to detect and characterize brain tumors in rats has become increasingly common in preclinical research. However, the histopathological evaluation of these tumors is essential to validate the imaging findings. In this study, we aimed to assess the correlation between MRI features and histopathological characteristics of experimental rat brain tumors. We observed that MRI accurately depicted tumor location, size, and shape. Furthermore, we identified distinct histopathological features, including tumor cell density, necrosis, and angiogenesis, that corresponded to specific MRI signal intensities and enhancement patterns. Our findings demonstrate the value of MRI in visualizing and localizing brain tumors in rats and suggest that specific histopathological features can be correlated with MRI features. This integrated approach holds promise for improving our understanding of brain tumor pathophysiology and for evaluating novel treatment strategies in preclinical models.

Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome.  A clinical case series of 21 patients. Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS) is a rare and potentially life-threatening condition characterized by eosinophilia and myalgia. In this clinical case series, we present findings from 21 patients diagnosed with EMS. The majority of patients were female (85.7%) with a mean age of 45 years.

The most common presenting symptom was severe myalgia, followed by fatigue, rash, and peripheral neuropathy. Eosinophilia was observed in all patients, with a mean absolute eosinophil count of 4,500 cells/L. The etiology of EMS remains unknown, but a possible association with the consumption of L-tryptophan supplements was reported in some cases.

Diagnosis of EMS requires a high index of suspicion and exclusion of other potential causes of eosinophilia and myalgia. Treatment mainly involves supportive care, including pain management and physical therapy. Corticosteroids may be considered in severe cases.

Our case series highlights the clinical features and diagnostic challenges associated with EMS. Greater awareness among healthcare professionals is crucial for early recognition and appropriate management of this rare syndrome.

Ichthyosis, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, impaired neutrophil chemotaxis, growth retardation, and metaphyseal dysplasia (Shwachman syndrome).  Report of a case with extensive skin lesions (clinical, histological, and ultrastructural findings). Shwachman syndrome is a rare inherited disorder characterized by various manifestations, including ichthyosis, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, impaired neutrophil chemotaxis, growth retardation, and metaphyseal dysplasia. We present a case of a patient with extensive skin lesions associated with Shwachman syndrome. Clinical examination revealed scaling and erythematous patches on the trunk and extremities. Histological analysis demonstrated hyperkeratosis, irregular acanthosis, and focal parakeratosis. Ultrastructural examination revealed disorganized keratin filaments and abnormal desmosomes. The patient was managed conservatively with topical emollients and systemic antibiotics for superimposed infection. In conclusion, our case highlights the dermatological features of Shwachman syndrome and emphasizes the importance of early recognition and appropriate management of skin manifestations in patients with this syndrome. Further research is needed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying the cutaneous manifestations of Shwachman syndrome.

mtDNA depletion with variable tissue expression: a novel genetic abnormality in mitochondrial diseases. mtDNA depletion with variable tissue expression is a newly identified genetic abnormality seen in patients with mitochondrial diseases. This condition is characterized by a decrease in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) content in affected tissues, leading to impaired mitochondrial function. The clinical manifestations of mtDNA depletion with variable tissue expression are diverse and depend on the specific tissues involved. Common symptoms include muscle weakness, neurological impairments, liver dysfunction, and metabolic abnormalities. Diagnosis is often challenging, as the presentation can be subtle or nonspecific. Molecular genetic testing, such as mtDNA copy number quantification and nuclear gene sequencing, is necessary to confirm the diagnosis. Management of patients with mtDNA depletion with variable tissue expression focuses on symptomatic treatment and supportive care, as no curative treatments currently exist. Further research is needed to better understand the pathogenesis and develop targeted therapies for this genetic abnormality.

SPECT imaging of pediatric brain tumor with hexakis (methoxyisobutylisonitrile) technetium (I). In this study, we aimed to evaluate the feasibility and potential diagnostic utility of hexakis (methoxyisobutylisonitrile) technetium (I) (Tc-MIBI) single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) imaging in pediatric brain tumor patients. A total of 35 children with suspected brain tumors underwent Tc-MIBI SPECT imaging, which was interpreted by two experienced nuclear medicine physicians. The results were compared to histopathological findings or clinical follow-up. Tc-MIBI SPECT imaging successfully identified brain tumors in 31 out of 35 cases, resulting in a sensitivity of 88.6%. The specificity was 100% as there were no false-positive findings. Additionally, Tc-MIBI SPECT imaging allowed for the detection of metastatic disease in 75% of cases. Our findings suggest that Tc-MIBI SPECT imaging holds promise as a non-invasive and valuable tool for the evaluation of pediatric brain tumors, providing essential information for treatment planning and prognosis assessment. Further large-scale studies are warranted to confirm these results and establish standardized protocols for its clinical implementation.

Pulmonary acinar development in diaphragmatic hernia. Diaphragmatic hernia is a rare congenital anomaly associated with pulmonary hypoplasia. We present a case report of a newborn with diaphragmatic hernia who underwent surgical repair. Post-operative imaging revealed persistent lung hypoplasia, characterized by decreased number and size of pulmonary acini. The histopathological analysis confirmed the presence of immature and simplified pulmonary acini, suggesting impaired lung development. Pulmonary acinar development plays a crucial role in gas exchange and respiratory function, and its alteration in diaphragmatic hernia can lead to respiratory distress and poor outcomes. Further studies are needed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying pulmonary acinar development in diaphragmatic hernia and identify potential interventions to optimize lung growth and function in affected infants.

Developmental dysmnesia in a poor reader. Developmental dysmnesia is a rare condition characterized by severe memory impairments despite normal intelligence and other cognitive abilities. This case report describes a 10-year-old male with developmental dysmnesia and poor reading skills. The patient exhibited difficulties in acquiring and retaining new information, as well as autobiographical memory deficits. Neuropsychological testing revealed normal language skills and working memory, but impaired episodic memory functions. Brain imaging showed no structural abnormalities. This case highlights the co-occurrence of developmental dysmnesia and poor reading skills, suggesting a potential link between the two. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop effective interventions for this unique combination of cognitive impairments.

Treatment of vaginal candidiasis: orally or vaginally? Vaginal candidiasis continues to be the most common cause of vaginal discharge. Vaginal candidiasis, commonly known as a yeast infection, is a prevalent cause of vaginal discharge. The choice of treatment route, either oral or vaginal, remains a topic of debate. The aim of this study was to determine the most effective treatment strategy. A systematic review of randomized controlled trials was conducted, comparing the efficacy of oral and vaginal antifungal medications in treating vaginal candidiasis. The results showed that both routes of administration achieved similar clinical cure rates. However, oral treatment was associated with a higher rate of adverse effects compared to vaginal administration. Based on these findings, vaginal antifungal medications may be the preferred treatment option due to their comparable efficacy and lower risk of adverse effects. Further research is needed to explore individual patient preferences and cost-effectiveness of the two treatment approaches.

Pseudocyst of the auricle: successful treatment with intracartilaginous trichloroacetic acid and button bolsters. Pseudocyst of the auricle is a rare condition that presents as a fluid-filled swelling of the auricle. Current treatment options include aspiration or surgical excision, but these have a high recurrence rate. This case report presents a successful treatment using a combination of intracartilaginous trichloroacetic acid (TCA) injection and button bolsters. Two patients with pseudocyst of the auricle were treated using this approach, resulting in complete resolution of the pseudocyst without recurrence. Intracartilaginous TCA injection helped to induce scarring and fibrosis, while button bolsters provided support and maintained pressure on the affected area. This novel treatment approach shows promise for the management of pseudocyst of the auricle.

Immunohistochemical demonstration of pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor in normal and neoplastic colonic mucosa. Pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor (PSTI) is a protein that plays a role in protecting the pancreas from damage caused by digestive enzymes. Recent studies have suggested that PSTI may also have a role in the development of colorectal cancer. This study aimed to investigate the presence of PSTI in normal and neoplastic colonic mucosa using immunohistochemistry. 

Tissue samples from normal colonic mucosa and various stages of colorectal cancer were obtained from patients undergoing surgery. Immunohistochemical staining was performed using an anti-PSTI antibody to identify the presence of PSTI in the tissue samples. 

The results showed that PSTI was present in normal colonic mucosa, with staining primarily localized to the cytoplasm of goblet cells. In neoplastic colonic mucosa, PSTI expression was observed to be significantly decreased or absent, particularly in advanced stages of colorectal cancer. 

These findings suggest that PSTI may play a role in the development and progression of colorectal cancer. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying mechanisms and potential therapeutic implications of PSTI in colorectal cancer.

Enveloping the bladder with displacement of flap of the rectus abdominis muscle for the treatment of neurogenic bladder. The treatment of neurogenic bladder can be challenging and may require surgical intervention. One surgical approach involves enveloping the bladder with displacement of a flap of the rectus abdominis muscle. This technique aims to provide support and protection to the bladder, thereby improving bladder function. A retrospective study was conducted on 20 patients who underwent this procedure for the treatment of neurogenic bladder. The results showed that 18 patients experienced improvement in bladder function, with reduced urinary incontinence and improved bladder emptying. Two patients had complications related to the surgical procedure. Enveloping the bladder with displacement of a rectus abdominis muscle flap appears to be an effective treatment option for neurogenic bladder.
